  2. Ok for beginners but is kinda cheap in quality

The soap is acceptably good but not amazing and you'd definitely want something better when you use it up. The brush is boar hair rather than badger, so you'll end up with some bristles on your face, especially early on. Still, it's a great way to get introduced to wet shaving.

Before he was using Barbasol shaving cream and Bic throw-away razors.<br /><br />It's a great gift, because of the low cost of this set it'll be no loss if the person doesn't like it, and if they do, it's a good base to start to build off of. Since he liked it so much, for this father's day I ordered him some of the higher line VDH shaving soap and a better brush (my dad seems to be a little rough with his brush, the hairs seems a little bent after a few months of use).<br /><br />I don't see how anyone can argue with the price of this kit; for less than $10 you get a brush, bowl, and soap. I guess my dad's not a picky person, but he really enjoys it and said it was the best shave in years. For those who complain about the kit and give it bad reviews, what do you really expect out of $10?

  25. This is an easy and clean way to lather your face for a good shave. No messy hands fumbling over the faucet to turn on or turn off the water, leaving shaving cream all over the faucet handles. All the shaving cream is on the brush, the bowl, and your face... Hands are as clean as a whistle.<br /><br />Look there are some reviewers that don't like the brush. Yet they say they enjoy the bowl, and the bowl alone is worth the price. For that type of mentality, i'd go to the dollar store to get a cheaper bowl.<br /><br />I recommend the brush too. Some of the brush hairs will fall out, but for the most part they stay intact. Just be sure to clean the brush after each use, which you can do by running some water on it while cleaning the bowl as well.<br /><br />Regarding the lather soap, I've used it a few times and I like it. But before I got this set, I had bough some shaving cream at Wal-mart, hence I want to use the shaving cream up first. So, I'll spray it into the bowl, and use it till it finishes. But I've been doing so for about 2 month and the shaving cream can still feel almost full. Geesh those cans of shaving cream foam really do go a long way, and they only cost about 1 dollar (Wal-Mart brand).

  28. Purchased this at my local big box store for 8.89. The soap quality is very good and has a very mild baby powder like scent that never lingers. The lather is creates is very creamy and the soap itself can be melted down to fit your bowl or any container should you decide you need to. The bowl is well made and attractive, however made is a bit small should you decide that you want to lather in your bowl. Works decent for the job. The brush is a plastic handled with much flash...boar brush sheds 6 or so hairs each time I shave and is very abrasive. I suggest a tweeserman pure badger or any badger for that matter over this. You get what you pay for in the brush...throw it in your travel bag for a back-up. Over all...all products will get you started and you cant beat that price!!!

I bought a name brand product and was blown away by the difference between the soap and the name brand product. You get what you pay for. Do yourself a favor and instead of spending 10 dollars on this cheap garbage spend 20 dollars. Search and find a 10 dollar badger hair brush and a name brand soap/cream. There is a huge difference.

  35. Item was everything I expected it to be and it came in packed neatly and also arrived in a prompt timely fashion! :)
  36. Got this kit for about $8.50 at a Wal-Mart.<br /><br />And, considering the price, its an awesome value.<br /><br />Here's the thing about brush shaving, its really nice. It feels good on your face, it results in a nice close shave, and its honestly kinda fun to do it the old school way.<br /><br />The bad part is, you go on the internet and find out that there's a super elite group of people who will tell you that THIS brand of shave soap is the best soap and you should only use THIS brand of badger brush because the other types don't compare and how you can only use THIS kind of razor because the other kinds will somehow destroy your face and make shaving the kind of unspeakable horror only sick, twisted people dare entertain their minds with.<br /><br />The point I'm trying to make is this: there is actually a community of shaving snobs. People who've actually invested over a hundred dollars in particular, elite equipment to SCRAPE LITTLE HAIRS OFF THEIR CHINS!!!!<br /><br />So they see this cheapo set and turn their noses up at it, because its ONLY EIGHT DOLLARS and you can BUY IT AT WAL-MART!!!<br /><br />I do like wet shaving. Its a good shave. I shave with a double edge safety razor (a Merkur) and this particular kit. And it works out GREAT!!!<br /><br />So here's my review:<br /><br />THE BRUSH: Its a boars hair brush, and its fine. It lathers well, it works the way it should, its not rough on my face at all. Yes, it has a plastic handle. WHO CARES?!?!?!?! Its the HANDLE of a friggin BRUSH!!! Do your hands start on fire if they touch plastic? Do you get an allergic reaction if your fingertips handle a brush thats not metal or wood? If you answered \\"No\\" to both those questions, then you're fine. Complaining about the material of a shaving brush handle makes you a snob.<br /><br />THE BOWL: Its a bowl. The soap sits in it, it holds steady when you lather. Its fine. You know why? Because its a FREAKIN' BOWL!!! How do you honestly complain about a bowl? It functions, it doesn't offend the eye, its fine. Don't be a snob.<br /><br />THE SOAP: Honestly, I've tried so many canned shaving creams its ridiculous. I'm a man with sensitive skin and it doesn't matter how moisturizing the cream was, I still had nicks and cuts and irritated skin. So imagine my surprise to find this soap to be a key part of a very clean, enjoyable shave. I seriously get better results from this soap than I do with my gels and creams. Way to go, VDH shaving soap. Are there better shaving soaps? Probably. Do I care? No, because this one leaves my face moisturized and refreshed, costs 1.80 per bar, and I can actually get it without ordering it over the internet.<br /><br />BOTTOM LINE: A great wet shave kit, especially for the price. Avoid the snobby opinions and give it an honest shot. If you're not a total tool you'll probably be surprised by how nice this kit is.<br /><br />There are plenty of things in this world where the level of craftsmanship and attention to detail make a huge difference. Guitars are such a product. Automobiles are another. Shaving brushes and bowls are NOT!!!<br /><br />Don't be a dumb shaving snob, just go shave your face, then start investing yourself in something thats actually important.on't be a snob. THE SOAP: Honestly, I've tried so many canned shaving creams its ridiculous. I'm a man with sensitive skin and it doesn't matter how moisturizing the cream was, I still had nicks and cuts and irritated skin. So imagine my surprise to find this soap to be a key part of a very clean, enjoyable shave. I seriously get better results from this soap than I do with my gels and creams. Way to go, VDH shaving soap. Are there better shaving soaps? Probably. Do I care? No, because this one leaves my face moisturized and refreshed, costs 1.80 per bar, and I can actually get it without ordering it over the internet. BOTTOM LINE: A great wet shave kit, especially for the price. Avoid the snobby opinions and give it an honest shot. If you're not a total tool you'll probably be surprised by how nice this kit is. There are plenty of things in this world where the level of craftsmanship and attention to detail make a huge difference. Guitars are such a product. Automobiles are another. Shaving brushes and bowls are NOT!!! Don't be a dumb shaving snob, just go shave your face, then start investing yourself in something thats actually important.
  37. To be fair i wasn't expecting much. I have been wet shaving for about a year. I generally lather with my hands, but i wanted to try a bowl and brush.   39. used this product for a week now and no complaints, brush works up a lather, apply to face, and shave... pretty simple. the brush will lose a few hairs but not a knock by anymeans and it kinda stinks at the first. i washed mine with shampoo a few times to get rid of the smell. bowl is good but a handle would be nice.. and soap is decent and not overbearing.. smells clean... nice shave with both a mach 3 and with my DE razor. you can spend more and you are welcome to, but in my humble opinion, a shave is a shave, get over it and get to work. btw. thick full beard, shave daily, not by choice so i make the most of it.
  40. TLDR: Just starting out? Buy this set now. /TLDR I picked this set up at the Wally a few years ago when I first started wet shaving. It's a superb value. I have been using the brush with only occasional bristle loss for about 3 years. I keep saying I'm going to get myself a more expensive synthetic brush, but time and again I can never really justify it with this one working so well. I didn't care for the bowl. My first shave bowl had little ribs on the inside to keep your soap from spinning around uselessly as you try to whip up lather. This one does not. I also found it to be a little small for building up a really nice lather. But at the time I was not aware that you could melt the soap into the bottom of the bowl, which conveniently solves both problems. Your soap will stay put and it will make the bowl seem bigger since there won't be a bunch of wasted space under your soap puck. If you are considering getting started with wet shaving just buy it. But it now. It's less than ten bucks! You can always upgrade later, but why agonize for hours (or days) over what brand of brush and soap to buy when you have a perfectly good set that you could run out to the store and pick up today.
  41. EDIT 8/24 - A hunk that consisted of 1/3 of the hair left in the brush fell out this morning while I shaved. I'm dropping one star from my review. Bowl- Great, it's a bowl. What more can I say? Soap- Great, it's soap. It smells nice and makes a nice lather. Brush- SHEDS LIKE CRAZY. I got this set because it was cheaper than the badger hair sets (this one is boar's hair I think) and I'm new at this method of shaving, so I didn't think I would notice a difference. The hair is stiff (but so might be better brushes, I'm new at this) which isn't that bad, you just kind of slather it all over your face. Produces a good lather, but when you put the brush against your skin, without fail you will get brush hairs stuck to your face. Maybe this is normal, but it stands to reason that they could do something in the manufacturing process to A) remove any loose bristles or B) just attach them so they don't fall out EVERY TIME. Go with a better more expensive brush set, it will cost twice as much (or more) but at least it won't ADD HAIR when you're trying to shave!
  42. I agree with Alex Nennig. The soap is on bar with Colonel Conk's soap, and the brush is just as fine as any other that I have used. The bowl fits the soap very well. For the price, this is a great started set. I recommend this set and will use this as a gift in the future.

  44. For the price, this is an excellent set of shaving gear to get started with. The brush or bowl alone is worth the price of the kit. And the soap is very good to boot, rivaling many of the more expensive and exotic brands. It would make for a great gift, to someone who has never tried wetshaving, or has never used a brush to apply lather. The brush, while not luxurious, is still a decent boar hair brush -- it will certainly get the job done. At this price, it won't hurt to try out a new way of shaving, be it with your old trusty double edged razor, or a new-fangled Fusion or the like.<br /><br />By the way, I noticed some complained about the smell of the brush. As with any brush, it should be cleaned thoroughly before using it. Give the bristles a good working with some dish detergent, soak for several minutes, rinse well. Some say to also soak new brushes in a weak solution of vinegar, and cleanse with shampoo and conditioner. Just be sure to clean it somehow - this is true of any brush.

Pro's Gets it done if you aren't too picky Cheap Less waste then the spray can shaving cream IMO it works better then shaving cream since you can push the hairs into your stubble and lift up on the facial hair, making it easier to shave. Con's Really it's kind of bad quality, but I can't complain too much The hairs fall off the brush and get stuck on your face The soap lathers kind of thin, just don't add as much water try to wet the brush, shake it out really good and swipe up some thicker stuff that fell off the side of the soap. All in all it's all right, you can't complain for the price, but you will want to upgrade eventually.

  51. It seemed like a great purchase at first. The bowl and soap were great, but unfortunately the brush fell apart within a few weeks. From the onset, every time I lathered up, I would get an errant hair which would come loose and stick to my mug. I thought it may be common for a new brush, but when a large clump of hairs came loose I quickly realized that it was all over. I bought a Tweezerman brush as a replacement and have had no issues.
  52. The Van Der Hagen set is a nice set for starters. The shave soap smells nice the brush smells good and it is inexpensive to boot. I only have one problem with this, the brush, its boar hair and a sub par brush, the bristles come out of it fairly easily and its obviously of cheap quality. One of the nicest things about \\"wet\\" shaving is having a smooth soft badger hair brush massage and exfoliate your skin. This brush kind of takes away from that. But to get a proper brush can cost hundreds of dollars, and most people starting out do not want to spend that. Even with the brush, it's so cheap that I was impressed by the over all quality of the set! If you are a shaving aficionado then don't buy this because you'll want the nice brush and there are better soaps out there. That said, take this for what it is, a beginners set that is an inexpensive way to break into the world of wet shaving!
  53. I've had this set for about 3 months now, I love the way the bowl looks and feels, even though its so simple. The brush is okay, i've lost about a handfull of bristles, but for how cheap the entire set it I was surprised at its quality. The soap is good stuff too, I like the scent and it does a pretty good job for wet shaving. Overall if you're looking for a cheap way to enter the world of wet shaving I would go with this. The soap and brush aren't the best out there but its $15 if you want high end items you're going to have to pay more, but if you're unsure of wet shaving, or just want something cheap until you find a good deal on a badger hair brush, this set is perfect for you.
  54. I bought this as a gift for my fiance and he said he liked the brush and the bowl was fine, but the soap didn't lather the way he liked. I put some on my hand and rinsed it off. My hand did feel soft, but I didn't shave with it.
  55. I'm new to wet shaving, and wasn't really sure if I wanted to put in the money for a really nice set, so this seemed a good fit for me. Indeed, when I received it, I was impressed. Granted, I don't a lot of experience here, but for the price, it did seem a good deal. In fact, it was indeed, because the bowl that was included is rather nice. It appears well made, and is heavy enough to not get pushed around the counter too easily. The coloration works well with my bathroom as well. The soap certainly doesn't disappoint. It's got a mild scent that I find clean and pleasing... and it lathers up quite well. The only disappointment here was really the brush. While it looks good, and is soft enough for me, it has a bit of a shedding problem. In only its first use, I found it was already losing an awful lot of bristles. This doesn't make it any harder to use, of course, but it's clear that it won't last very long... and you may have to deal with getting rid of the shed bristles, of course.<br /><br />Over all, I'd say it's a great buy for the money, especially if like me, you're just getting into the whole wet shaving routine and don't want to spend a ton of money to do so. The brush detracts a bit from it, but not so much as to be useless. Look at it this way - you're getting a rather decent soap and a great bowl... and a free cheap brush.

  59. This is great value, it includes everything to get you going in WETSHAVING.<br /><br />Highly recommend it!<br /><br />This is the best way know if wetshaving is for you
  60. This is a cheap set. Plain and simple. But it's usable.<br /><br />Wet shaving is cheap on the long run, but like buying anything in life, you have to put some money down first.<br /><br />This is the perfect set for you to see if wet shaving works for you. You can get this at a CVS/Wal-mart cheap, under $10 dollars. The more expensive items will not be leagues above this, so if this is \\"unbearable\\", don't bother wasting your money buying the better stuff.<br /><br />Now on the flip side, this should not be your long term set. It's good for a few months, but if you're gonna continue wet shaving, invest in better.<br /><br />The Brush:<br />- This set: It's fine, it's a plastic handle with some hair on it. It gets the job done, just don't expect a \\"facial\\"<br />- Expensive sets: Search silver-tip brush. Don't expect magic, it will just feel softer. It holds more water so supposedly is better for lathering. Should cost you 60-120 dollars.<br /><br />The Bowl:<br />- This set: Cheap ceramic bowl. It's a bowl...<br />- Expensive sets: There's the mug version, and the bowl. Then ceramic or Chrome. No point other than aesthetics, I like my things looking the same. Clearly you don't need to buy a new bowl.<br /><br />The Soap:<br />- This set: Its an aloe soap, this set is meant to be universal, so its a gentle hypoallergenic soap. It's alright, some people with sensitive skin love it.<br />- Expensive sets: Proraso cream or soap is the best. Some people like some brands out there, but that one is the generally considered best. It's cheap, unless you absolutely love the other soap, there's no reason why not to upgrade. A tube of the proraso is like $5, and will last you months or like an year or more... So even if it glides a fraction better, why not? There's a mutton fat soap for the tradition fanatics.<br /><br />The Razor/Blade:<br />- Buy Merkur, should be $30 dollars or under $50. Try for long handle version first, it will be closest to what you're used to.<br />- Blade is \\"feather\\" blade. It's the sharpest, which is also the most unforgiving. Yeah everyone has a \\"favorite\\" brand, but this is noones least favorite that I know of. Or buy a variety pack and try out different ones till you like one.<br /><br />So in General, an expensive set should cost you:<br /><br />Mug: N/A use anything<br />Soap: $5<br />Brush: $70<br /><br />So about $90 with shipping.<br /><br />If it's something you'll use for years to come (after trying out this pack to see if you will), even it it's a tiny fraction better, why not? Why are some people here acting like $100 means life or death?...<br /><br />Where you'll save in wet shaving is the blades. The general consensus for a good shave is each blade lasts you 3 shaves, or 3 days. A pack of 100 is about $22 dollars, about. So that's 300 days, or close to 10 months for $22 dollars. $22 dollars wont even buy you a Gillette fusion refill these days where I live... And let's be honest, we usually take such bad care of it that those blades last like a week or two. At least with this you can just throw away the blade.<br /><br />Someone said \\"blah blah to use to scrape hair off your chin\\"... If only it was that simple, as most of us men know, shaving is an every day thing, a part of our lives. If you're going to do something EVERY... SINGLE... DAY... and you've used this box to see if you like this method, why not spend $60 dollars for a brush even if it is a tiny little bit better, and $5 for a soap that will last you 5months to a year... The $5 dollars is worth just the fun of trying out a new thing...<br /><br />Just DON'T expect this magical thing with the expensive versions, and if you're on a tight budget, this will hold you through for a while!<br /><br />EXTRA: If you find a way to hold the brush upside down (the proper way), the water will seep down and extend the life and use of the brush. Water running into handle ruins it faster.
  61. for the most the product is good except the brush would have to be upgraded bristles fell out after a couple uses.... delivery was fast
  62. For what brushes, bowls, and soap costs elsewhere, this is an excellent deal. Great starter set to begin wet shaving, and you'll be doing your skin and your wallet a favor by giving up the aerosol cans.<br /> I found the bowl to be a good size, holds the soap well and not too many suds escape the top. The brush works well, too, though you may notice one or 2 bristles come out every time you shave. But its not a big deal. The soap is a great soap to learn on, it gives a good lather and moisturizes the skin well. My only complaint is that it doesn't lubricate as well as I like, but it still does a good job (I spent a couple of extra dollars and bought Col. Conks).<br /> For the price, you really cannot go wrong. I recommend it, and each piece is a good product. Try this product out, and you can always upgrade later.
  63. I got it for a stocking stuffer...for this coming year - lol. Yes, I buy ahead :) On to the review...it seems pretty cool. If I were a guy...I don't think I'd mind the brush...but, since it's going to be a gift...the look kinda makes me nervous. So, I may just buy another brush to replace it. With that said...this is a good deal. I have badger bristle make-up brushes...& they aren't real cheap. I feel blessed I got a discount from school. To me, any REAL animal bristle brush is good...they last longer than anything synthetic. ***UPDATE: Well, I couldn't wait to give it as a stocking stuffer - lol. I gave it to my dad for one of his Valentine's Day gifts. He LOVED it. We popped the soap out of the plastic container and into the nice heavy black dish. It melted and then hardened to the container. He used it today...and loved it!!! The smell of the soap is really nice! Yes, the boar bristle has a plastic handle...but, that didn't seem to bother him. It did me a little, b/c he's my dad and I always want the best/coolest for him. Turns out, it was perfect as is...couldn't have done better. He is already wanting more soap - lol. I think he's hooked - yay! :D Now, I just need to find some more of this good smelling soap for him.
  64. I purchased the set primarily for the bowl -- I use the bowl and a badger brush to generate lather for shaving. You simply cannot find a shaving bowl for double this price. The brush is a stiff, cheap boar hair brush. I always had trouble making a lather with boar brushes, and this one was no different. The soap is adequate for shaving. Some people swear by it, others don't. I fall into the last camp and use it in the shower.
  65. I have to say I agree with Alex, the guy talking about the snobs, 100% At first it's hard to believe that there could be a community of \\"elite shavers\\" but after looking them up online he was not exaggerating one bit! It's crazy, I know, that there are people who'd be snobs about shaving, of all things, but if you don't believe be go ahead and look them up. IT IS EXACTLY the way he said it was: \\"this is the only soap that works, and you should only use that brush, and this one after shave is the only one worth it of our faces, and if you pay less than X for this razor blade then your face will rot, etc...\\" It's hard to say anything original after someone said something you agree with 100% (Alex, not the snobs) so let me be brief. The bowl: It's a bowl, looks good, holds the soap, nice size, sturdy. Again, it's a bowl. The soap: It's soap, nothing fancy, no complex electronic equipment inside, no secret formula, it's soap. Does what it's supposed to do, does it well, lasts a while, it is available everywhere (both locally and online) and it is priced like a soap. The scent is very very mild and soapy, which is fine with me since I don't need to smell like a million bucks in the shower. The brush: It's a brush, it works. I would not buy another brush because it does fall apart quickly. For the same price I could get a Burma Shave Brush and it lasts a little longer. - If you are a normal guy who wants to shave this is for you. - If you are a normal guy and want to try the whole old style shaving thing then this is for you. - If you like a good product at a reasonable price then this is for you. This is NOT for you if: - You are a tool - You think soap should only come from another country - You are too good to try something cheap - You spend countless hours online discussing the important matters of the shaving world - You can only use a brush properly if the handle is made of ivory, incrusted with diamonds, and the hairs are of an extinct animal.
  66. it works well and it smells amazing, the person i bought it for thinks its the coolest thing ever.
  67. I bought this product as my first foray into more traditional shaving techniques. Overall, I am very pleased with the set and I actually enjoy shaving now! It seems that the brush helps clean your face and the soap offers more resistance to nicks and cuts than typical shaving gels. It lathers up well and washes away clean. I will be using this product or ones like it from now on in my shaving routine.
  68. Bought this brush and Soap at Bath & Body works. I skipped the bowl as i had a nice wide coffee mug that has filled it's place. I like it. The soap has a very clean scent to it and lathers up nice. I've had it for two months and its still going. Although to clarify, I couldnt totally take Alex's advice and made some upgrades (more on that later) so my girlfriend took it over. I did find that it lost a few hairs in the beginning but that stopped after the first week of daily use. It makes a good lather and has an exfoliating feel to it, which I like. I've recently switched to the Omega Stipely Badger brush and I'll give you a true non-snob comparison. The Omega is softer and feels soft like something a woman could use to apply blush with while this boar brush feels more firm like an outdoor paint brush, a little firm but still smooth at the tips (you can wash your car with it and it wouldn't scratch the paint). Some say badger brushes smell like...well, dead badger. Mine didn't but it did lose a lot of the die they used to make the hair black. This lasted for 2 shaves and stopped completely. To be clear it wasn't like emptying a pen in the sink it was more like a light graying of the typically white lather when I rinsed out the brush. Oh, and the brush is still black. The big difference between the brushes is how they lather and how they wear. The Omega makes a smooth thick warm lather than holds well on your face and lasts the whole shave. With the same effort the boar brush produces a thinner more watery lather. I can work at it longer but it just doesn't get there and/or stay warm. If I never bought the badger brush I doubt this would have really mattered but it is a noticeable difference. All in all I give the boar 3 stars and the Omega 4 as I wish it was a little more firm. As for wear, the badger brush dries like a used paint brush curled at the ends and stuck together, it never goes back to the straight hair look of day 1, where as the badger returns to looking new, daily. (I always rinse my brushes thoroughly and hang them bristles down to dry.( So if the badger lasts 3 times as long the price difference is negligible.) I wont spend more than $30 on a brush so this is where my journey ends. If you're interested, I'm using an Edwin Jagger 89de razor with Astra superior platinum blades and the c.o. bigelow shave creme (same as proraso tube) with the bigelow After shave balm. I'm very happy with all the products mentioned but still use cheap gillette custom plus 3 disposables when I'm in a hurry. The head of this disposable comes off and fits my gillette sensor excel handle and are cheaper than the sensor excel cartridges. Although I may cheat with the razor, I never pass up the brushed shave creme experience. It's a great way to start your day.
  69. I picked this up at the drug store a few weeks ago. The brush is made of boar hair with a plastic handle. The bowl is glazed ceramic with no handle. The soap is just soap. The Brush Aside from the cheap plastic handle, it is really no better or worse than any other inexpensive boar hair brush. This is the best part of the set. If you really want this brush, just buy it on its own. The Bowl Just a bowl. Too big to fit in my medicine cabinet and close the door completely. No handle. Just use a coffee mug or invest in a better shave mug/bowl. Not worth buying the set for. The Soap You're better off shaving with a bar of Ivory. Doesn't have a very nice scent. Dries out my skin. Doesn't lubricate very well which causes nicks when combined with my safety razor and would probably massacre your face when used with a straight razor. Makes a very thin later that absorbs/evaporates quickly. Spend the $4 on Colonel Conk instead. In Summary Why bother? The word Premium does not belong attached to this set. For about the same price, you can get a better boar hair brush and a much better soap. Throw the soap in an old coffee mug and you're good to go or spend a little extra on a nice shave mug/bowl.
  70. First, brush shaving may not be for everyone, I can't see how though. If you want to introduce a friend to brush shaving, this is the way to go. If they don't like it, no loss, if they do, this will carry them through until they get a better set. As far as brushes go, if you're buying boar, you aren't going to waste your money on a metal or wooden handle brush! You're going inexpensive (not cheap). The soap in this kit is actually quite nice. I'm currently using a EJ Sea-Buckthorn soap, but the VDH soap must've been loaded with aloe, because it always makes my skin smooth, it doesn't have a strong scent though. The bowl in this kit (not a mug ~ a bowl) is very deep, which I actually really like. I place my brush in the bowl and fill it to the brim with STEAMY HOT water and let it soak for 15 or 30 seconds. It softens the soap for getting on the brush quickly and gets the brush nice and warm to the core. At this price, pick up a few and pass them around to guys who are still in the dark about brush shaving, you'll make some converts. I like to leave my Edwin Jagger set at home, I have this VDH set packed in my travel kit. For the money, it should have more stars, but compared to other shave brushes, it could have less. Factor the cost and the product and it gets 3 stars. Don't mind spending $25 or more? Go with badger.
  71. I got this at Wal-Mart. It worked very well for the price. I do recommend it to get you started if you find badger brushes out of your price range. The brush consistently sheds but it wasn't a huge issue for me. The soap was pretty nice. Here's the thing, its not being a snob as some other reviewers infer to appreciate a nicer brush. I was able to get a real badger brush for not much money and it is a huge step up. I get much better lather and no shedding. It is also much more comfortable on the face. For me it was definitely worth an upgrade once I had committed to wet shaving. I still love the bowl and will keep the brush around as a backup. Don't let the fact this is boar hair keep your from trying wet shaving - get this and go for it. Be prepared to really enjoy it and want a better brush, though.
  72. I bought this set from the drug store after reading good things about shaving with a brush and soap. For the price, it's a good gamble- if you discover you like wet shaving, you can upgrade later; if you don't, you're not out a small fortune. Like another reviewer has stated, this set works. As a matched set, the soap is the perfect size for the bowl, which is small enough to sit on a shelf in my shower. The soap produces a workable lather with just a wet brush- and you can get a better lather by soaking it in hot water in the bowl for 30 seconds before starting. The brush lost some bristles during the initial wash, and a few more during my first few shaves, but it didn't fall apart in clumps. Although I've since upgraded to a pure badger brush, I managed to find a silicone lid that fit the bowl, and I'm now using this set in my travel kit. I plan to pick up a few more of these sets to give as Christmas gifts for my friends and relatives who've never tried wet shaving.
  73. I figured I could use this set until I got around to ordering a badger hair brush. The very first time I used it, hairs fell out, forcing me to pick them off of my face. The soap doesn't lather well, and left my face feeling a bit dry. The bowl does it's job, I suppose. I got mine at walmart, because its the only think around that I could pick up from a store. I plan on returning it as soon as I can.
  74. The brush is \\"finest\\" (lower quality) boar bristle which are slightly rough and tends to smell like a pig. Has a cheap looking plastic handle, but hasn't lost many bristles though. The bowl is actually nice. It's just like a tea cup without the handle. The soap foams and shaves moderately well. We bought this in town because it was the only set available. I would hardly call it premium quality or gift quality, but it will help get you shaved.

  76. I find this brush a huge improvement the Badger Hair is soft and the brush doesn't shed much at all. It sells here on amazon usually around 13 bucks.

Well, one problem, the brush is already leaving loose hairs on my face as I use it. As in, the brush hairs are falling out. It's frustrating because they come out as I lather, they're hard to pick out, and obviously this shouldn't be happening so soon.   78. This boar bristle kit is okay for a starter set. The bristles are stiff and feel coarse on your face. I received a badger bristle brush as a gift about six months after purchasing this boar bristle model; there is a night and day difference. The badger bristles are soft and help to build a much better lather than the boar model. I would recommend a higher quality badger bristle model over this boar bristle model. The included soap cake is just okay. If you end up getting this model, then get yourself a creamier alternative, like that available from Proraso (Proraso Shaving Soap, Eucalyptus & Menthol, 5.2 oz (150 ml), New Formulation), as soon as the included soap cake is consumed.
  79. Firstly, I've been shaving since I was a sophomore in high school. I've hated shaving ever since. Razor burn, cut zits, and the sting of embarrassingly enflamed face were all aspects of shaving I dreaded. It literally got to the point where I simply grew a beard in frustration. However, in the past two years I have had to hold decent jobs at my college and now face life as a graduate. I've been using single disposable razors because they are cheap, but they do not get the close shave to look truly respectable (the stubble makes me look like I should find work as a cowboy, not a office worker). Well, I wasn't going to blow a load of cash over the next few years on the Mach 3's cartridges and I want to feel like a real man, you know, like my great-grandfather. I gave this product a shot as my first old-school style of shaving. I don't know what people are complaining about! The boar bristles aren't that harsh (unless I truly do have a face like sandpaper) and the soap smells amazing! It's a great starter set. Yes, I will probably purchase a Tweezerman badger brush after the glue has popped the top off. So far, i am pleased with the trendy bowl, brush, and soap to go with my Lord razor and Derby blades. I totally recommend this product to anyone going to start shaving with an classic safety razor or the modern razors today.
  80. I use these shaving kit and one thing you NEED to know is after cleaning the brush shaken off the water you Hang it upside down, you have to get a kit with a razor and brush hanger or it will be worthy less in a month.
  81. This is a good set either as an introduction to shaving or as a keeper. I've always been a wet shaver and used canned lather and cartridges in the past. Now I use this exact set except when travelling from overseas where I work. I've actually used the soap from the plastic packaging when I travelled because I didn't want to further risk breaking the bowl. For the record, I've been using it for about a year and a half so the set brush is plenty durable with any basic care. Yes the brush loses a hair every once in a while but that's why you have a replacement on hand right? The plastic handle is fine unless the snob factor comes in to play. Just store it hanging from the knob with the bristles down. The bowl is a good height in which to work up your lather (coffee mug is too tall) but a handle might be a good idea. Lathering up is easy...just wet the brush under the hot running water and don't shake out too much of the excess...work the brush around the bowl until you obtain the lather of your desired consistency. The soap is fine unless again, the snob factor emerges. Next up for me is an old fashioned safety razor instead of these WAY TOO EXPENSIVE cartidges and a decent shaving stand that will actually ship out to me. Overall, if I could give 4 1/2 stars I would but...not 5...nothing ever gets a perfect score huh. Addendum dated July 15th - been using this set with my Merkur Saftey Razor and a variety of DE blades for about two weeks. I've used Merkur, Derby and Wilkinson blades to date with Feathers upcoming. I can say that the entire routine of shaving oil, brushed lather and a good DE safety razor shave is a weclome part to shaving and a nice way to start the day. This set works fine. The bowl is a good size and fits my hand well, the brush also fits my hand well and the soap has a pleasant yet not overpowering scent. The brush isn't prickly at all in my opinion. I've had no problem other than the brush doesn't fit the stand I have (like the Colonel Conk), even at the base of the knot but I read about that anyway. I have an improvised stand that I use to hang-dry the brush and I use the stand to stage my other brush leaning it against the prongs and the cap nut on top. I rotate between the two-use one this day the next one the next day and back between the two again. The only soap that I have used is the \\"regular\\" soap but I may try a different VDH version. I see no need to \\"upgrade\\" as this set works well enough for me. Hope this helps. Happy Shaves.

I would but a new brush because you never know about sanitization. The brush here in this set has worked okay for the 2 or so years I've owned it. It looks like the glue gave or perhaps enough individual hairs came out so that it was not as tightly packed and reduced the strength.   91. Found this soap at Walgreens and for $2.50 I couldn't leave it on the shelf. It lathers up very nicely.   92. I started using this set about five months ago. I really do like the soap and will continue to use it. I have sensitive skin and a tough beard and this does a great job of softening the hair and lubricating the path of the razor. It lathers easily and neither dries the face nor leaves a nasty film. That is worth four stars. The bowl is a bowl. The soap fits it well enough and it's deep enough not to spill but not so deep that it is awkward to make a lather with your brush. I am not considering it in the number of stars for this review, though, as it is as good as any mug I had lying around that I would have otherwise used for this purpose and if you were to buy the soap and brush separately it would probably cost the same as this set. The brush, though, is what brings my review for this set down to two stars. It makes and applies lather well enough, and did it not fall apart then I'd probably consider it decent. However, for the past five months it never stopped shedding hairs. It was horrible at first, shedding like a cat, but even five months later it was shedding at least one hair per use. Finally, a few days ago, the knot came out of the handle. I certainly did not use it in a rough manner so I have to assume that it was shoddy construction. What's worse, looking into the part of the handle in which the knot sat I could see a number of flaws, holes and irregularities and whatnot, in the plastic that definitely imply poor manufacturing. As a set, this isn't very good and, while I do recommend the soap, I have to suggest that anyone in need to buy the soap and then pick up a different brush separately. A person certainly doesn't need an expensive badger hair brush just to prepare and apply the soap, but one that actually holds up is certainly preferable.
  93. I bought this set because I wanted to try out shaving \\"old school\\" with a safety razor, brush, and soap. In this set you really get what you pay for. The best product in this set is the soap itself, as I have found that it does a good job of lathering up and not drying out my face. The bowl is just ok--it could be a bit larger. The brush, however, is where the biggest issue is. The bristles started falling out during the first time I shaved with it. It is annoying to find bristles on my face, in my bowl, or in my sink. It is obviously made very cheaply, so don't expect some nice badger brush experience here. I have used it for about 2 months and I am now ready to upgrade my experience with a more high quality brush. When you buy this just keep your expectations reasonable so you aren't disappointment.
  94. After poking around at prices, it seems like the bowl alone is worth the price (especially if you can get free shipping). If you're looking to get into the world of wet shaving, this is a great place to begin. If it's for you, you can spend a bit more on a nicer brush and keep the bowl as, essentially, a free gift.

  97. As said by others, this set of brush, bowl, and soap will meet all shaving needs adequately. Are there better soaps out there? Undoubtedly. Brushes? I'm pretty sure. Bowls? I must take exception to my own question. No, a bowl is a bowl is a bowl. It holds a cake of soap, you hold it in your hand and don't think too much about it. It's perfectly sized to hold a standard shaving soap.<br /><br />The soap - nice fragrance, does not result in an allergic reaction when lathered on to the face, and spreads well.<br /><br />The brush - nice handle, the bristles hold their form (albeit, it has only been a week since I received this set). Unlike plastic bristles, which score the face, the soft bristles on this brush have a very gentle action.<br /><br />The bowl - it's green. It's a bowl.<br /><br />The price is the most attractive feature of this product. For this price, I would recommend this product to all and sundry. A good soap and brush are must-haves for those venturing in to the exciting world of straight and/or safety razor shaving.

  104. I used to shave with straight razors and safety razors, and of course I used a brush and soap. I then went for speed and used the multiple blade outfits and canned foam.   107. I'll start out by saying I'm not a shaving snob and this is my first attempt at wet shaving with a DE razor. I figured I would try this kit out to see what I think of going old school with a brush, bowl, and shave soap. I have been using a Mach3 with Headslick as a shave cream on both my face and head.<br /><br />The brush: I didn't realize going in that it would smell like a boar's @$$ coming out of the box. I almost pitched it after the first use due to the smell. A quick google search about the smell of shave brushes showed that Boar brushes (and any animal based brushes) like this often stink when new. I followed the advice of some random internet stranger who said to shampoo and condition it a few times to get rid of the smell. That worked great and also made it feel a bit softer. I would advise this if you are sensitive to smells as I am.<br /><br />The bowl: It's a bowl. It looks and feels solid.<br /><br />The soap: As I mentioned earlier, I'm a bit sensitive to smells. I couldn't stand the smell of this soap. Smell is very subjective obviously, so YMMV. I did a side by side test of the lubrication it provided against my favorite shave cream, Headslick, and the Headslick killed it. I pitched the soap after that and think I'm going to continue to use the bowl & brush with the Headslick, as the brush helped lather it up much better than I've ever been able to do with my hands.<br /><br />Overall, it's not a terrible package for the price. It's a cheap way to see if you're going to be into using this kind of equipment to shave.
  108. Wetshaving with a brush is a great way to improve your shaving routine. Whether you're using a classic double edge razor or a disposable, adding the shave brush can give you a cleaner, closer shave and leave your skin feeling great. If you're looking to improve your shaving routine, I highly recommend adding a shaving brush.<br /><br />If you're new to wetshaving or looking to try a shaving brush without having to clean out your wallet, the Van Der Hagen shave set is a great starting point. Not, this is not the best brush you can buy, but it probably is the best you can buy at this price level. I've found that this brush does take a bit more effort to work up a good lather, but it does help you practice and perfect your technique. And even though it's not the best brush you can buy, it really does improve your shave. Once you get used to wet shaving and you want to improve your tools, then I'd suggest investing in a higher-quality brush and a nice shaving soap. But for those who want a good way to start, this is a great set.<br /><br />Wet shaving fanatics can list dozens of reasons that this brush is not as good as their handmade silvertip badger brush, and they're generally going to be right. This is not the best brush you can buy. But if you're just looking to but a decent brush at a low price, this is a good option and a great way to get into the world of wet shaving.
  109. The brush sheds a bit at first. Not in clumps, though. Initially, several bristles fell out. The brush is quite thick though and losing a few won't hurt. The problem does diminish after a few shaves. To get rid of the loose bristles I ran the brush under hot water and moved the bristles back and forth. That helped a lot. Now only one or two bristles comes out per shave and sometimes none. It doesn't chafe my face like someone else mentioned. On its own, I give the brush three stars. The bowl is okay if you like a bowl. I knew it didn't have a handle when I bought it and it's not fair to give it fewer stars for making my choice. However, as the soap lather spills over, it gets a bit slippery and loosens my grip. As someone else mentioned, I think I'll switch to an ordinary mug lying around the kitchen. **Edit: I tried a mug but it's too tall and interferes with the back and forth action of the brush while attempting to make a good lather. It still possible but annoying. I immediately went back to using the bowl but I am looking around for a short mug with a wider brim than its base. They have them here on Amazon but if I can find one at a garage sale all the better. I read more than one review that claimed the soap did not lather. It makes an extremely nice lather and has a pleasant fragrance without being overly scented. When I lather up the soap, I put hot water on the brush and shake off the excess. I use vigorous back and forth strokes kind of like making whipped cream (and it looks like it, too) but I don't have to work as hard. For me, the soap is the star of this kit. It lubricates extremely well and I get almost no friction from my shaver. It's better than any gel or foam I've every used. By the way, my shaver is a Gillette Power Fusion.
  110. Generally a pretty good product... nice bowl to use roomy enough but not so large that so soap slides around... good soap... if your staying at a decent price this does the job.
  111. Just received my kit and used it for the first time with my new safety razor. This is a fine quality set that works plenty well. I suppose if you could convince someone to buy you a fancy expensive brush, go for it; the brush in this kit is of good quality. Experiment with soaps if you like and seriously a bowl is a bowl. For the \\"everyman\\" this is a fine quality set. I recommend this product.
  112. This kit has everything you need(except a stand for the brush) to start wet shaving. I started shaving my head a year ago and shave every two days. I used foam shaving cream and had problems with razor burn on the back of my neck. There is also a lot of waste with shaving cream. I looked around for a shaving brush and of course Amazon had what I needed. This is great for starting out and the soap will last a long time. The brush needs to hang down to dry properly so buy a stand. You can lay it on it's side to dry but hanging down is better. The soap lathers nicely but you will need a cup to put the soap in and make lather in the bowl. There are other methods such as building lather in your hand or on your face. I use the bowl to make lather and it works well. No more bumps or rash and the soap smells great. It contains moisturizers and my skin is much softer.
  113. Great kit for starters.
  114. Third set I bought. One for me, one for my two sons. We all love it.
  115. Well this is my first brush set and I'm still using it after several years. The main problem with this set is the brush. The hairs slowly come out and and can be somewhat annoying to have a long hair on your face when shaving and applying your lather. Otherwise, the soap works alright and you can't really mess up the bowl. Anyone needing something to start with, don't even think twice about this set, go ahead and pick one up and give it a try. I actually enjoy using the brush instead of my hands to put shaving cream or gel all over my face. It's less messy too.
  116. Used it today and was very pleased. Very soft brush and soap lathered well and very easy to use. Got a smooth shave with no burn.
  117. This has to be a must buy for any man who shaves. Bought it with my first Safety Razor (Lord Premium Safety Razor Model LP1822L) I plan on upgrading it. I have to agree with Alex Nennig on how people look down on stuff because you can buy it at Walmart (plus it's cheaper there) or because it's not expensive. Some of the best things in life are cheap so enjoy them. In time you will no matter what have to replace the brush and bowl and soap so this is a great buy. And I love the SOAP smells nice and doesn't bother my face at all.
  118. Using soap and a brush rather than aerosol shaving cream is a great idea, but this is not a great brush. The bristles are very coarse, but you can live with that, and they are constantly appearing on your face, which is not easy to live with. Lately the brush has lost bristles in clumps and I am concerned that it will lose most of its bristles with time. I will switch to a badger hair brush soon. I recommend drying any shaving brush with the bristles/hair hanging down, to avoid water retention that lead to bristle loss.

  120. Really gets the job done.
  121. The package is a good value. Sure the brush lose some bristles while in use and the soap lather be could be richer, but I got what I paid for, A decent product at a decent price.
  122. I returned to this style of shaving after 40 years of fighting with electric razors and disposables. This kit along with Williams pucks and a Merkur safety razor has been fantastic. The set is a great buy and the brush and bowl serve their purpose well. A little olive oil on my damp face pre and aloe post shave and the whole process takes no longer than an electric shave. Buy it.
  123. Purchased one years ago at Walmart, I gave it to my brother, who seemed to like it. This is a great starter kit, more so if you know you going to wet shave only once or twice a month, which is what I plan on doing. Will be purchasing another set on Amazon soon.
  124. The reviews that I read of this set was that it was a good beginners (which I am) who needed an easy intro to wet shaving. While this may be true, there are some things other beginners should know before purchasing: 1. The Brush: I expected it to be less than stellar, but I feel like I'm scrubbing my face with a wet broom, or a big tooth brush. It's bristles also started coming off right as I opened the packaging. However, it worked really well for the technique I used for lathering (see below). 2. The Soap: I initially had trouble getting a good lather from this bowl because I was trying to get the tips of the brush soapy, and then lather into a hot bowl. However, I got much better results by soaking the puck in a coffee mug with the brush for in hot water for a few minutes, pouring out the water, and then lathering directly on the soap in the mug (for a demonstration of this, check out sombercoyote's video on Williams Soap lathering on YouTube--it's exactly what I did). With this technique, the boar hair bristles are pretty effective so I may not pitch it quite yet. 3. The Bowl: The bowl is actually pretty nice, though it may be too shallow for the lathering method I used. It may work for others, but I think my bowl will just be used to hold my razor and brush for now. In short, if you're looking to start DE or straight razor shaving, this is an okay set. However, there is the [[ASIN:B004VW59DG Van Der Hagen Men's Luxury, Shave Set, **BONUS**, set includes TWO full size 3.5oz scented soaps]] which seems more legit. It's gotten better (albeit fewer) reviews than this one. It also comes with a stand that holds your razor and brush, which is neat. It also has a mug that seems a little deeper than this bowl, which would be ideal for me. But it's also almost quadruple the price. The set I'm reviewing is good for practice, but I'll be upgrading as soon as I can't stand it any longer (starting with the brush!). One last note: now that I've started to figure this set out, I wish I had simply found the components separately. Instead of buying another kit, I may just buy better components separately one at a time, especially since the mug that I'm using was essentially free. This would be much easier than dealing with the disappointment of a cheap kit like this one ;-) Good luck!
  125. The brush lasted for about a year before it fell apart. The bowl and soap are great. I have actually bought more of the soap since my original purchase.
  126. Man for 12 bucks you get all this, it works great just started using de shaving stuff and I have the smoothest face, I got this the Lord DE razor and the shark razors, I have a super tough beard and this is great. Buy it now.
  127. I know what you are thinking, I am considering wet shaving, how they use to when men were men, and I want to know if this is worth getting, when there are so many more options and they all cost more. Well, I suggest this one to you. This is great for starting because, if it is just a phase, you spent less than twenty bucks. No worries. If you are hooked, as I am, you are still getting a cool little set that gets the job done. What you will find: 1. A pleasant, very light scented soap, containing glycerin which is good for most skin types. It builds up a good lather, which is very important for a good, safe shave. 2. A cool green bowl which is designed to hold this soap perfectly for building that lather that you need. It does lack a handle, so be cautious with your soapy hands, boy. 3. A boar brush, which will be used to develop your lather and will get it under your stubble to help give you that excellent shave. The important thing is to dry this brush correctly. You must wash it out with warm or cold water. Then, let it sit on its side or upside down (buy a brush holder also available on Amazon}. If you choose to rest it on its handle, it will be more apt to hold water causing hairs to shed more rapidly. The complaint of hairs falling out is true but, if you take care of it correctly, it is fairly minimal after the first couple shaves. Update: It has been six months sinced I purchased this set. It still works well. I have replaced the soap only once. The brush lost several hairs in the beginning, stopped then, it started acting up again last month but, only momentary. All in all, it has more than enough to last for a few years. Now I am getting such close shaves that my wife is impressed.
  128. The bowl works like a bowl. The soap works like shave soap. The brush...well it seemed to leave a lot of hair on my face when that's what I was trying to get rid of. A lot of the bristles fell out my first time shaving. Other than that I can't complain. I got what I paid for.
  129. Husband says he will never use shave gel again. He as always had a problem with the gel getting clumped up in the razor and hard to shake out and this soap just wisks right away with water on the razor. Just a note, this soap product does contain Sodium Laurel Sulfate for those concerned with this chemical. There are probably higher end soaps disks out there to use that have organic and natural ingredients but for the price, it was a great introduction to using a brush and soap. Recommend for people who are just starting out with shave soaps, or for those not concerned with SLS.

  133. This is admittedly the only brush and soap I've used as of yet so I am only really comparing to canned gels and creams, but this is leaps and bounds better than any canned product I've tried. The brush feels softer on the face than I thought it would from the picture and it seems like the soap may last forever. As others have said, the bowl is a bowl. I am very new to wet shaving and I haven't had any problem getting a nice lather with this soap and brush. Soak brush, shake dry, some circles on the soap to pick some up, then whip in the bowl with a few drops of water. I'm sure there are nicer soaps, and I look forward to trying them, but I like the scent and the lather of this one for now. Of course there are better (more expensive) products out there but I have to give this 5 stars as it might be the best ten bucks I've spent on amazon.

This is a great starter kit, and is giving me a chance to learn the basics without making too much of an investment.   140. Not a bad set. I didn't use the soap that came with it (yet), instead I purchased Col. Conk Lime soap. As expected, it's from real boars, so it stinks until you get some soap into it. Did my first wet shave with a Parker 99R and the Shark blade. Nicked myself like crazy, but I have to admit it did leave me closer than my twin cartridge ever did, and aside from the small nicks, I didn't have any red irritation/razor burn. All in all, a good set if you're getting into wet shaving and you don't want to spend a ton of money getting started. I definitely recommend you buy an alum block/styptic pen if you are new to wet shaving.

  142. My first shave kit I also bought the Parker Shavette with Shark blades. For those make sure to get a good amount on your brush and I use a separate SS bowl (pet food kind) and slap the brush side to side up and down and swirl right then left. That's a lil hint for you beginners not getting a rich lather. If you are getting thin lather then try my way the slapping really fluffs it well and swirl to thicken it. I usually get enough to do a 3-PASS shave.

  146. After getting tired of paying tons of money for triple-blade razors every month, I decided to try doing it the old-fashioned way. I bought a [[ASIN:B000LY2AKI Merkur Classic Safety Razor, Straight - #178 - Made In Germany]] and this kit.<br /><br />The kit itself is not bad for the price. The ceramic bowl, while not stylish, does the job just fine. The soap is a bit thin. It doesn't lather terribly well, and tends to evaporate off the skin rather quickly.<br /><br />I can only give the kit three stars because of the brush. After using this setup for a couple months, the base of the bristles snapped off from the handle this morning. It's just a plastic base for the bristles glued onto the plastic handle; the glue apparently became brittle and broke under normal use.<br /><br />If you want a cheap introduction to shaving, this is a decent start.   149. As you can see in the picture, this kit has 3 parts: - The soap - The bowl - The brush The soap: This is a cheap soap that gives you an excellent lather. The scent is very mild and (in my opinion) is very nice. If you use correctly, it can last for 2 months and a nice thing about it is that since it's a glycerin soap, you can melt it in the bowl (or another bowl) or even mix it with another soap or anything you can think of to change its scent.. but the important thing is the lather, I already said it is an excellent lather and It never fails to give a comfortable and smooth shave. The bowl: It's made of ceramic, dark navy blue in the outside and green in the inside. Slightly bigger than the soap (In diameter) and about 1 inch taller than it. It easily fits in your hand and is really cute (My sister told me \\"awwww I want it\\" of course I said no) I melted the soap inside this little bowl in the microwave and it didn't suffered any damage. 8 secs and 8 secs in \\"hi\\" sill do it. The Brush: Well, this is a boar brush. It is stiff by default but it softens with the use, The smell is a bit weird at first but what I did was to wash it with shampoo and let it rest for one day. It didn't soften it but when I shaved for the first time with it the smell was almost gone. Being a boar brush, it holds less water but it grabs more soap (IMHO) so you don't need to swirl too much. Also if you need water just soak the tip of the brush in water and continue swirling. The brush is stiff only at the very beginning of the process, I feel it gentle on my face when building lather directly on it and also I feel it gentle when applying lather from the bowl to my face. Last but not least, the handle. You'll see people complaining about it being cheap plastic, well is not. It is solid and not slippery, I find it trusty and I'm not afraid to drop it. Not that I will do it but I feel there is no danger. All in all a trusty brush. As someone said, don't be a snob. This set is trusty and nice. The price is awesome. 5 stars without a doubt.
  150. great, just as I wanted
  151. I'm 23 years old and I bought this as a \\"starter\\" for wet-shaving. All-in-all, I was fairly pleased with the product, but it does have its caveats. The brush, for instance, is of a good quality, but it does lose a few hairs with every lather (I don't know whether this is true for all shaving brushes, however). The bowl is, well, just a simple bowl - no real complaints there. The shaving soap seems to be a good quality as well. My only major beef with the product, having been using it every day for about a month now, is the difficulty with which a good lather is created. I've yet to discover if it is the soap, the brush, or a combination of both - whatever it is, you need to be a patient man to work up a good, thick lather. It could be my lack of technique, but after all the tutorial videos and articles I've consulted about it - I think not. Whatever the case may be, I think it's an excellent starter kit and it definitely met my expectations (for the price). I would definitely recommend it to a friend getting started in wet-shaving.
  152. Just now, when I was using this kit for only the second time, the bowl slipped out of my hands, off the counter, and onto the floor, shattering into several pieces. Users of this product need to be especially careful when their hands are wet. It makes me wish the designers had thought to include a handle on the bowl or even made the bowl out of plastic. True, plastic is less elegant or classy than porcelain, but it is also less breakable. A less expensive plastic bowl might also allow the designers to include a lid for the bowl which might be useful when packing the damp soap and the kit for travel.<br /><br />On the plus side, using a brush to apply the shaving soap or foam is much less messy than applying it by hand, which is what I was doing before I bought the brush, but the soap doesn't seem to lather up as much as I would have liked. In sum, the product is OK but not great, a less pricey alternative to some of its more expensive competitors.
  153. Great set, especially for the price. I wouldn't hesitate to buy another one if needed.
  154. I purchased this shave set off of Amazon, because I could not find a set in my local stores. The more you use the brush, the better it works. As for the soap and bowl, very nice, but I found that I prefer shaving cream over face soap, doesn't dry my skin as much.   156. The brush is your standard fare boar bristle, which can be slightly stiff upon arrival, just follow the pre-shave instructions on the side of the box,for extra softness, I recommend soaking the brush in very hot water for about 5-10 minutes just to soften the bristles a bit more. pro tip: if you don't want the soap to move around too much while working up a lather, try melting it into the bowl.
