  163. Great soap for shaving
  164. I've been a user of the VDH Shave Set for years (yes...the same brush and bowl). My kit has survived flights, cruises, road trips, toddlers, curious teen age brothers, 3 ex's, and 3 moves. This kit has been on more vacations than Chevy Chase and seen more Face Time than an iPhone. I enjoyed it so much that I purchased a second kit a few months after my initial purchase because my local W-Mart didn't have have any soap cake refills in stock and I thought it would be a great idea to have a kit just to take on Vacation or leave in my gym bag. I also use shave creams as well([[ASIN:B0006O2K1C Geo F. Trumper Violet Soft Shaving Cream 200g cream]])([[ASIN:B002QFZ1QK Taylor of Old Bond Street Avocado Shaving Cream]])([[ASIN:B0031OXOBE Taylor of Old Bond Street Almond Shaving Cream]]) but shave soaps are so much easier to take on vacation or to the gym.<br /><br />This is the GED graduate of shaves sets (General Education Diploma aka the \\"Good Enough Diploma\\"). It's not that $300 chromed shave set, but in the neighborhood of $10.00 it's definitely good enough. In the right hands this kit will give you a great shave. Are there better sets on the market? Probably. Are they going to improve YOUR shaving experience to the nTH degree...probably not. Are they marketed at this price. No. Save your money and spend it on a decent razor and blades. Once you have that down...then you can experiment with pricier sets if YOU want.<br /><br />I own several brushes that I've collected over the years because I'm just that kind of a person. The VDH set is my work horse and I now rotate brushes for the sake of rotating brushes. Some brushes are softer...others more coarse. Some brushes are not PETA friendly, some are. In the end, the brushes I own all give me a great lather and serve their purpose. The VDH brush is no exception. Decent brush, great price and it comes with a bowl and a soap cake.<br /><br />I used to break out horribly after shaving using the mass marketed stuff with rash and irritation. I then discovered wet shaving with a dual edge safety blade([[ASIN:B002CLDUZM Merkur Heavy Duty Razor with Slant Bar #198 3\\"]]) and WOW what a difference. If you are able to use the Mach-50 or whatever they call them these days more power to you.<br /><br />Back when I first started shaving I'd use the same razor cartridge for the entire school year...rust deposits and all. I also used to feel light headed after half of a bottle of beer. Sadly those days are gone and my beard would now give a cheese grater a run for its money. Canned shaving cream also seemed to fall short and made the whole shaving experience a royal pain in the patella as it became more drying and irritating to my skin as my beard matured. Again . . . if you can get away with the canned stuff count yourself very fortunate. In my late teens a can of shaving cream would last me a whole year. Go figure.<br /><br />To each his own as far as his methods are concerned. I will share mine, but I think everone's skin/hair is different. Here's what I think of this kit.<br /><br />The Brush:<br />My VDH brushes look nothing like the exploded cigar sunflower thing in one of the pictures above. Hmmm...(stroking imaginary chin hair...you know...because this is a review about a shave set). I can't speak for VDH's quality control BUT I do own 2 separate sets purchased from 2 different stores in 2 different counties.<br /><br />I've gifted a few of these to young men in my family new to shaving and it gives me great pleasure to see these kits on their sinks when I stop by for a visit. Maybe I'm just really lucky...even though I play the lottery weekly and never win anything. I would think that if a brush fell apart within a few weeks that I would be able to return/exchange the product quite easily due to a manufacturer defect, but some people aren't into returning things.<br /><br />If you're new to wet shaving and don't know how to use and care for a shave brush then google is a great resource. Basically don't be a mongoloid and it should give you many years of great use (barring any manufacturer defects that I have yet to experience on my end).<br /><br />How do you use it? Wash your face first! Do you really want to scrape a piece of metal across a dirty, oily layer of skin? The handle of the brush fits in your palm and your fingers should grip the sides of the bristles near the base of the handle.<br /><br />You don't need to crush the bristles in an attempt to create a lather. After you're done shaving gently wipe the sides of the brush on a towel to remove any water from the surface. Place the brush on a shaving brush stand ([[ASIN:B0006O4NRQ Muehle Tortoise Shaving Brush Holder]]) and allow it to dry properly in an open location (not in the medicine cabinet). The stand does not need to be super expensive. I own one similar to the link I provided that I found on ebay for a few dollars shipped. You do need a stand. Placing the brush on its handle will definitely ruin the bristles in a hurry as the moisture won't have anywhere to go but into the handle.<br /><br />I've experienced the loss of a stray bristle here and there and chalked it up to wear and tear. Do I scream \\"shenanigans!\\" when I need new tires on my car after 60,000 miles despite good upkeep, frequent alignments, and regular tire rotating and balancing? Negative. At this price I don't see why anyone would complain about replacing a brush after a few years of use.<br /><br />I usually wet the brush and use it to moisten my face. I then wet the brush again and work up a lather on the brush using the soap in the bowl. This action allows for exfoliation and helps lifts the hair away from your face prior to shaving. I then apply the lather for a minimum of 2 shaving passes. More often 3. When I have a date night planned I go the extra mile with a 4th pass. Yes. This means shaving multiple times in different directions. More passes paired with poor technique will leave you with nicks, cuts, and possible razor burn/rash. Use caution. If you do cut yourself it is wise to invest in a Styptic Pencil([[ASIN:B000YM76VU Pinaud Clubman styptic pencil for nick relief - 0.25 oz, 2 pack]]). They can be found for under $2.00 at your local W-Mart. They stop bleeding fast, disinfect and don't take up much room. They work wonders! They're advertised as sting-free. But this should be read as \\"stings for free.\\" Nevertheless...the thing works!<br /><br />I shave in a certain order. Top to bottom. Back to front. Front to back. Bottom to top. Shaving against the grain is the most irritating step if you're not careful or if your skin just isn't ready for it. If your skin is already irritated don't irritate it further by shaving against the grain right away. Wait until the irritiation goes down.<br /><br />Follow up with a toner based bump preventer ([[ASIN:B000S92OCK B&C Skin Tight Product for Razor Bumps & Ingrown Hairs-Extra Strength(12 oz)]] - can be found at W-Mart for fairly decent price) on a cotton pad if you're prone to razor bumps and then after shave if you'd like ([[ASIN:B002PIPIHK Shea Moisture, Tea Tree Herbal Bump Preventer After Shave Elixir 4 oz Nubian Heritage]]). Lastly apply a shaving lotion ([[ASIN:B007OCA3UE Shea Moisture Shave Anti-aging Moistuizer & Bump Preventer 2fl Oz]]). If you stick with a routine your skin will be clear, your face soft, and your woman happy.<br /><br />Another option to after shave is to use an alum block after you're done shaving (I used one when I first started wet shaving and go back to it from time to time if I experience any skin irritation or acne). Simply rinse your face with cool water. Wet the alum block with cool water. Rub the alum block on your face. Air dry. This does a few things. Disinfects, stops any bleeding, and dries to form a protective layer on your face for those of us prone to break outs or irritation post shave. Air drying keeps any lint, dust, or bacteria present on our less than fresh face towel off of ourface. If your too heavy on an application, just rub it off with clean hands and apply a thinner coat next time around. The alum block's mild sting doubles as a critique of any flaws in your shaving technique or a dull blade that needs to be changed. Here is a link to the product available on Amazon: [[ASIN:B004QVCIKE Alum Block by Osma - 2 Pack Value]].<br /><br />The Bowl:<br />Ummm. Yeh. CHECK!<br /><br />In all seriousness the bowl fits pretty nice in the palm of your hand while you're lathering up. It's easy to clean. It's round. I've never eaten from it. Great job on the bowl VDH!<br /><br />The Soap:<br />The soap is of pretty decent quality and if it causes you irritation then it's simply not for you. I have very sensitive skin and this shave soap has never really caused me any grief. There is a learning curve to wet shaving so be careful not to blame a poor technique and routine on a good product. VDH soap has a pleasant fragrance to it and it leaves my skin feeling refreshed. It is my opinion that its fragrance is mild enough that it will not clash with an after shave. I usually use an aftershave, and it's the only thing I can smell after application.<br /><br />Using quality products like this make shaving a little more enjoyable. If I had another face I'd be in for 2 more sets!!!<br /><br />I shave with the Merkur Slant Razor that uses safety dual edge blades, for those that are curious. The other products I've listed in my review have all worked well for my skin although I have used others depending on sales and availability of products.<br /><br />5 stars for this kit, its price range and for its quality.
  165. I bought this set a while ago at my local supermarket for about $11, and now I see it at other chains and Walmart for about $9.<br />The best part about this is the soap which you can get for $2 or less retail.<br /><br />The soap is good. I have yet to try other soaps/creams but it is leaps and bounds better than all the Gillette gels I used to use like Mach, Fusion, etc. To get the benefit you need to spend at least a full minute working the lather compared to the 5 seconds it takes to put a canned gel. Don't use too much water, just soak the brush, shake off the excess water, work the tips gently against the soap and when it starts to lather, move the action to your face. It is time well spent. My face feels better and the final judge, my wife, commented that my skin looks better.<br /><br />The brush is poorly made. It sheds bristles all over the place at first and less after 4 shaves. I don't care much for the boar bristles and I find that the handle shape makes it uncomfortable to hold. I got a basic badger hair brush for less than the price of this set (tweezerman brand) and it is simply better on all accounts: it creates better lather, it feels nicer against my face and it is easier to hold. I threw out the original brush to the trash without looking twice.<br /><br />Which leaves the bowl: it fits the soap cake nicely and because of the curvature the soap will stay put as it runs out. It looks nice.
  166. Decided to try shaving with a DE razor after deciding the Mach 3 blades were simply not cost effective nor did they give a particularly good shave. Purchased the Retrorazor and the the VDH set from Amazon and began my quest for a good shave at a fair price. Must say that the VDH set is a pretty good deal, all things considered. The soap has a pleasant aroma and makes decent lather with the brush. In fact the lather is far superior IMHO to anything that you will get in a can or tube from the corner drugstore or super market. The bowl is easy to hold and has a nice weight. The brush does a good job of applying the lather and it didn't loose too many bristles when I washed it prior to my initial use, For the money you will be hard pressed to find a better set.
  167. Mu husband decided to switch to the old fashioned art of shaving so I bought him this and it was perfect. What a great value. I still cannot believe how cheap it was for all that you get.
  168. This is a nice shave set. I love the soap so much I bought another 4 bars so I will never run out. Its a boar brush and while not as soft as my low end badger I find its fine and great as a travel brush. In some ways a boar brush is better for soap. It picks it up better. Its bigger than my badger and I like that. Bowl is a good size, holds the soap (I don't bother melting it or anything ... some guys have too much time on their hands.). The soap is fantastic. The lather is slippery. It smells nice and clean and doesn't stick or leave a residue on the razor. As long as VDH can keep a handle on their pricing, at $2.00 a bar they will have me for life. In short a great set, I recommend it and will be buying some more for my friends.
  169. This set was good enough for someone learning the pleasure of safety razor shaving. Seven months later, I've learned there are better ways.<br /><br />The brush in this set works, but constantly drops bristles and doesn't fit on a normal brush stand (handle is too thick). I'm told that quality (boar) brushes don't drop bristles and create a better lather, so I'll be ordering one of those soon.<br /><br />The bowl has no handle, so it becomes very difficult to hold when you're fresh out of the shower and there's soap involved. It slipped from my hand once, just a few inches into the sink. Now it's chipped and has a big crack down the side. I replaced it with a $1 coffee mug from the thrift store. That mug has a handle and is much easier to hold.<br /><br />The soap was nice to use. It smells great and made a pleasant lather. I did run out of the soap very quickly (possibly due to a lack of experience with the safety razor/shave soap process). I replaced with with a well reviewed puck of shave soap that has lasted months so far with plenty more to go.<br /><br />Purchasing this shave set buys you a puck of soap that'll be gone soon, a bowl that you'll drop and break, and a good enough brush. I'd suggest shopping around.<br /><br />Buy a nicer boar brush (some sell for exactly what this kit does), a two dollar puck of shave soap, and grab the old worn out coffee mug you never drink out of. You'll wind up with a better setup than this kit.

  171. I was worried at first buying this because I was worried price = quality. I was wrong. It great quality. I would definitely suggest this to someone wanting to give this a try. Good soap, nice dish, and the brush works great.

  173. The fact that this kit contains a bowl, a brush, and soap makes it a great deal for people not yet skilled enough in the art of shaving, but who want to learn. There are better bowls, better brushes, and better soaps out there, to be sure - but all of them are more expensive and need to be bought separately. The brush looks as though it is made of cheap plastic in the images, but it has a nice heft to it, and weighs sufficiently more than it looks like it would. The bowl is ceramic and painted in an appealing mix of blue and green, though slightly brighter than in the images. The bowl is also sufficiently deep - something I had been (unnecessarily) worried about due to the description. Finally, the soap creates a good lather that is more than decent for shaving, and it is enclosed in a small plastic container, so no worries about finding a mess when you open the box. This is a good deal for the average person who wants to learn the basics of wet shaving - for whatever reason (for me it was the price of replacement razor heads, for others it might be different) - but has no shaving bowl, brush, or soap passed down by a father or uncle or such.

  178. I bought this as a gift for my husband. This is a great starter kit for the price. If you know anyone that wants to try this method of shaving, this is a good way to do it without making a large investment. The bowl in our kit was ceramic (it seems some people had plastic), which is very nicely weighted and a great size for the soap. The brush is not a long lasting one, but will work fine for a few months if you are just looking to try this out. The one thing to take notice of is that although the brush has a base for sitting it on the counter with the bristles up, that is not the right way to dry it if you want to keep it in good shape. It is best hung upside down, so if you purchase this kit, I would also recommend a small stand to hang the brush with the bristles down. After purchasing this kit, I also bought him a straight razor for a real old fashioned shave, but we haven't tried that razor with this soap yet, so I can't say how well it works with a straight razor vs a traditional razor. His face does seem to be nice and smooth and less irritated since switching from the shave gels and creams to this. Another bonus of shaving with soap is that shave creams and gels in particular tend to clog up the drains in our house, and I hate having to pour chemicals to clear them or remove them to clean all the build up out. Shaving with soap makes drain maintenance much easier.
  179. Maybe I just didn't get the concept. My face is irritated by regular shaving and I thought the soap might be better. It just didn't lather equivalently to shaving cream and felt like I was almost dry shaving. The kit is nice.

  194. I started with this exact set about a year ago. Since then I have moved on to other, more expensive items like Taylor of Old Bond Sandalwood cream, Silvertip Badger brush, Edwinn Jagger DE89 Double Edge (DE) razor and Prorosa pre-shave cream and post shave balm. Total cost for all was just under $225 (brush and razor were the most expensive, but I wanted to have great stuff and not have to work about anything but blades for a very long time) though you can do better at certain times and I could have cut the brush cost in half by going with a Pure Badger instead of the Silvertip Badger. I have not spent a single penny in 6 months since the razor came with a 10 pack or Feather blades and I bought a 50 pack when I bought the razor and I get about a week per blade<br /><br />But for starting out, this kit is good for figuring out if you want to give it a try and I highly recommend it. It does work with any kind of razor so you can continue with whatever razor you have right now. The soap also did wonders for my face and I have dry/sensitive skin and as others have said, mine lasted around 6 months. If you want to continue using the soap, most Walmarts carry it in the shaving section. The box is small so look carefully<br /><br />I still use the bowl, I let it sit in hot water with the brush in it as well, I prep my face and then empty the water out but do not shake out the brush. Take the brush, put the soap just on the tips and run it around inside the bowl for about 1 minute and you will get lather like you have never seen or felt before. You can also put the soap in an old coffee mug then get the brush tips soaped and move to the bowl to create the lather or just create the lather in the cup. Either way works but doing it in the bowl keeps the soap clean that is in the mug and you can get way more lather with very little soap, in other words, you do not need much soap to get the rich lather going and since you had the bowl in the hot water, the lather will be nice and warm<br /><br />Consider most brushes like this.<br />Boars Hair = good starter brush,<br />Pure Badger Hair, middle of the road brush, but definitely better than Boars Hair by a mile<br />Silvertip Badger brush, definitely the top end and can be very expensive but it does make a difference<br /><br />Also, don't just paint on the lather on your face, do it in circular motions for about 1 minute or two until you cannot see any skin, then to get an even coat, paint the lather on lightly, this lifts the whiskers, softens them and gets them ready for the razor. When actually shaving, do not press the razor into your skin, especially a DE razor, just let the weight of the razor glide over your skin and use short strokes, like and inch or a tad more. I typically do two passes, one north/south, the second south/north and I do not get any razor burn or bumps. On date night, I'll do a third pass,which is across the grain. My GF loves when I do the third pass, I end up with a very smooth face and my 5 o'clock shadow comes around the next morning<br /><br />Finally, all brushes should be hung with the hair pointing down, if you put them on their handle which points the hairs up, the hairs will spread out, the water will soak into the handle and you could and will prematurely wear out the brush and possibly end up with mold or mildew in the hairs, especially if you do not shave every day. You can also clean the brush with a good shampoo, remember, it is actual hair, not fake so it can be cleaned and conditioned just like your own haird warm<br /><br />Consider most brushes like this.<br />Boars Hair = good starter brush,<br />Pure Badger Hair, middle of the road brush, but definitely better than Boars Hair by a mile<br />Silvertip Badger brush, definitely the top end and can be very expensive but it does make a difference<br /><br />Also, don't just paint on the lather on your face, do it in circular motions for about 1 minute or two until you cannot see any skin, then to get an even coat, paint the lather on lightly, this lifts the whiskers, softens them and gets them ready for the razor. When actually shaving, do not press the razor into your skin, especially a DE razor, just let the weight of the razor glide over your skin and use short strokes, like and inch or a tad more. I typically do two passes, one north/south, the second south/north and I do not get any razor burn or bumps. On date night, I'll do a third pass,which is across the grain. My GF loves when I do the third pass, I end up with a very smooth face and my 5 o'clock shadow comes around the next morning<br /><br />Finally, all brushes should be hung with the hair pointing down, if you put them on their handle which points the hairs up, the hairs will spread out, the water will soak into the handle and you could and will prematurely wear out the brush and possibly end up with mold or mildew in the hairs, especially if you do not shave every day. You can also clean the brush with a good shampoo, remember, it is actual hair, not fake so it can be cleaned and conditioned just like your own hair
  195. Been using this for a long time now and it has all held up great. The brush does loose some hairs at first, but after that it holds up great. the bowl is a nice size to hold and makes great lather.
  196. I think this shave set is very good for beginners<br /><br />I was interested in learning how to shave with a straight razor, but most sets are fairly expensive, and I was worried whether I would like it or not. I decided to try a cheap set to see if this is something I would want to invest in, and I was not disappointed.<br /><br />For the price, it is a nice set. You get a fairly decent boar hair brush and a bowl that fits in the palm of your hand, which is nice for building up a lather. In addition, the soap is good. It is moisturizing and has a nice scent to it. If you are thinking about getting into traditional shaving, this is a great place to start. Stop thinking about it and buy it. Its inexpensive, but good quality and great for beginners.<br /><br />However, just some things to consider. I bought this to see if traditional shaving was something I would make a ritual. After using it, I am very satisfied, but I've been using it for roughly two months and I'm ready to invest in higher quality products. There are some slight downsides to this kit:<br /><br />- The bowl is very small. You can make a very decent lather with it, but because of its size lathering can be a bit messy sometimes. Lather tends to spill out over the sides fairly easily. You could use a bigger bowl or a large mug from your kitchen if you have one.<br />- The brush will wear down with time. I notice this the more I use it, even after about two months of usage, shaving once every two to three days. Its great for those just starting and its something you can learn and practice with, but if you're going to make brush shaving a daily ritual, then i suggest investing in a brush of higher quality made from badger hair. Badger brushes are much more porous, which makes lathering easier, and they are much softer and feel much better. Boar hair brushes can be a little prickly. If you go easy on this brush and be gentle with it, it may last you a bit longer while you learn the basics.<br /><br />All in all, great for beginners. I gave this review 4 stars because i don't think of it as a long term product, but an initial investment to see if this method of shaving is something i would be interested in. If you're thinking about buying this kit to learn how to brush shave, just do it. If you don't like it, you didnt waste a lot of money. If you fall in love with this method of shaving as I have, I recommend one of the kits from [...] Think of it as 'level two'.

  199. Purchased this set after hearing about the advantages of traditional shaving soap over the modern day gel/foam products. Overall, very happy with the quality and value of the purchase. Some shaving tips that will help, regardless of how you shave. 1) Use Conditioner on your head/face before shaving. 2) Wrap your head/face in a hot towel for 10 minutes. 3) After shaving, use Tend Skin to completely eliminate all razor burn and any potential in-grown hairs. Following the process above with the shaving soap and brush in this kit, and a disposable razor, I get perfectly smooth shaves with little to no irritation. I have come to prefer shaving soap and will invest in a higher quality brush, but for the money you cant beat this set. Great starter set!

  202. I purchased this shave set as a compliment to the [[ASIN:B000NL0T1G Merkur Model 180 Long Handled Safety Razor]]. Well, I know it's cheap, but I wasn't expecting it to be THIS cheap. The bowl and soap are actually nice, but the boar brush is terrible! Mine shed HEAVILY and after 3 shaves the knot partially loosened from the handle and during the 4th shave it completely broke off. I emailed Van Der Hagen and a nice lady replied and said they would send me a replacement badger brush, which came 2 days later. I commend VDH for their quick response and attitude, however..the new badger brush is horribly cheap as well, the knot is thin and floppy, it creates extremely airy lather, and the handle is cheaply varnished wood and after 2 shaves the varnish is already peeling and water is seeping into the wood..I foresee this one dying soon as well.<br /><br />If you're new to wet shaving and want a cheap introduction, do yourself a favor and buy your soap separately, toss it in a coffee mug and invest in a [[ASIN:B000G647Y8 Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush]] or a [[ASIN:B000CBBYW0 Black Handled Omega Professional Boar Hair Shaving Brush]] if you want to try boar.<br /><br />Again, I have to hand it to VDH, they tried to make things right with a new brush and offered a refund as well, so the company isn't bad..just some of their products!
  203. I love it very nice and reAlly good
  204. I would not buy this again. The brush is already falling apart after just a few uses. The soap is okay but don't believe it's better than regular cream just because of the razor type. I bought into that but now I'm back to regular gel cream and there's no difference besides the gel is faster and easier. I will keep using a shave cream brush though - that just feels really good and gets cream under the whiskers I think. I'll buy a better quality brush and be happy.
  205. Seriously, this stuff smells amazing. I keep finding myself sniffing this shave soap every time I goto the bathroom because the smell is so addicting. Not only does it smell great, but it leaves your skin moist and clean.Try the oldschool shaving way, its awesome.
  206. To begin with, I have some criticisms of this product. First of all; the brush. The brush is cheaply made. Saying that, though, does not make me a snob as some other reviewers might suggest. The truth is that it frays easily and the hairs start falling out of the handle after only a few uses. Don't expect the brush to last more than a month or so, even if you take care of it properly and store it upside down. Also, this brush is made from Boar hair, rather than Badger hair. Boar hair is more scratchy and prickly on the face, and doesn't hold water as well as Badger hair. Secondly, the soap. The soap is not bad, it makes for a smooth shave and has a nice, very subtle scent to it. The only negative I have to say about it is that it would be better if the kit came with a glycerin soap. Van Der Hagen does make a glycerin soap, but apparently not as part of a kit. The bowl is fine, it has a nice weight and I really have nothing bad to say about it. Despite my criticisms this product is still great for guys who are new to the wet shaving technique and want to try it without spending too much money. Even with the somewhat mediocre brush, this will still give you a closer and smoother shave than normal shaving cream. If you use a safety razor as well it's even better. Try this kit and if you like it after a few weeks upgrade to a real badger brush, there are some available on here for less than $20. Wet shaving isn't for everyone though, so if you try it and decide to go back to shaving cream you haven't wasted much money. At a price this low there is really no reason to hesitate to try it.
  207. My title pretty much says it all. I am relatively new to wet shaving with a DE safety razor. I wanted to try out the skill before I invested a ton of money into razors, blades, and other accoutrement.<br /><br />That said, this is an excellent little set for the money. I'll break down the individual items in the set here:<br /><br />Bowl: It's a bowl. No handle, and it got to me in one piece. Easy to clean, could be a bit deeper. All in all nice little bowl but doesn't really add much value to the set as a .99 plastic cereal bowl or coffee mug would do the same job.<br /><br />Soap: Nice puck of soap. At first was hard to get a good lather but then it \\"broke in\\" and now it lathers great. Dries quickly in the bowl and doesn't leave much, if any, scum. (I wash the entire puck before I store it). Not much scent but I didn't expect it to have much of one.<br /><br />Brush: Breaks in well. I've done about 10 wet shaves with it so far and it feels pretty good. At first it shed about 5-6 bristles per shave, now about 1 per shave, hoping that will decrease to zero soon. Takes awhile to dry, and dries all \\"crazy\\" not in a nice, uniform dollop. Might be contributing to the shedding. All in all comfortable but I wouldn't want to stay with it forever. Also the handle is a bit hard to grip when wet.<br /><br />This said, it's $10. It's a good beginner set. Get it, try it, pass it on, but don't expect too much. This might also make a good travel set for experienced wet shavers. I've already ordered this [[ASIN:B004L4EING Van Der Hagen Men's Luxury, Shave Set]] to replace it.
  208. I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of this set. The soap bowl is ceramic and it has nice feel to it when you make a soap lather. The shaving brush has held up so far after a few shaves and it is still in good shape.
  209. Great looking kit and the soap is high quality. Very old school and works well. Would recommend a higher end razor because this will not lather as much as the more modern stuff.
  210. Very nice quality on the shaving bowl, brush and soap. The only thing aggravating is getting the hang of making a nice shaving foam from the shaving soap...it just takes practice. I highly recommend this product to anyone...have a great shave.
  211. Pros<br />--Cheap: This shave set does not cost much, and will definitely pay for itself when it takes much longer to finish off one shave soap, than one aerosol can<br />--Works better: Shaving soap works a whole lot better (at least for me) than aerosol based shaving cream. You also get the feeling that you're a whole lot more classy than anyone who doesn't use it<br />--Bowl: The bowl really helps create a much better lather. Don't be afraid to take the plastic off of the soap and place it in the bowl. It will work a whole lot better<br /><br />Cons<br />--Boar Hair comes out of the brush and gets into the shaving blade system. It also can cause an itch on the skin, which can be irritating when trying to shave.<br />--Brush: Sometimes it retains water (even after shaking off) which can be a pain when applying the lather.<br /><br />Verdict<br />--Well worth the price if you want to change up, and upgrade the way that you shave.
  212. First let me point out that i just got this just under 3 hours ago used it the first time and the brush is already loosing its hair, the brush is just garbage, im going to have to get a new one. the bowl on the other hand is perfect for me fits in the palm of my hand comfortably and is the perfect size for me. the soap is good not great but not horrible, didn't dry my skin out, is slightly more difficult to get a good lather with it, but that may be the brushes fault. all in all im giving 2 stars but i recommend for people who need a bowl and soap, just get yourself another brush pronto.
  213. Lathers good brush still holding bristles, cup is good fit in my hand.
  214. I paid about ten fifty and that seems to be a bargain for this nice little package. I've been shaving about 50 years and have pretty much run the gamut on the methods used. My Norelco electric will no longer hold a charge (though it lasted about 10 years) or rather than paying about two hundred for another, and probably getting less than quality, I opted to try a blade again. This decision was partly based on having found many packages of Atra blades hiding in some drawers that I long forgot that I had.<br /><br />I have wet shaved with a brush and soap before but wasn't willing to pay an arm and a leg to do it again. I checked other items, vintage items on an auction site and decided to give this a try. Yes, you can buy better but since you're just slathering some soap on your face in under a minute why bother if there's a viable alternative to paying a lot more. The brush is good, the soap is good and the bowl is OK though slippery when wet. If you don't like the soap you can easily replace it but its mild scent and easy lathering are fine for me. The hotter the water the better the lather process will go.<br /><br />I'm now shaving three times a week because I'm retired and don't care anymore. I want a wet slippery surface when I shave to avoid bloodshed and this gives it. others have a love hate relationship with this item but it's just shaving so give it a try and for the price I can't tell much difference between the pricey brush and soap I used years ago that are now each about three times the cost of this complete kit.
  215. hey guys,<br />so i decided to try out this shave set to see what wet shaving was all about. I definitely prefer this type of shave to the normal slather and whack. The soap produces a good lather, the bowl is very sturdy and strong, BUT the brush has lost a lot of bristles. I have had this for about 7 months and they;re is already a large patch of bristles missing. However I don't have a brush stand and there is a little more to working up a lather and post care for the brush that I didn't know about. The brush does provide a good lather and feels pretty nice on the skin. ANY man who has not tried a wet shave definitely needs to step it up. It feels so much better and looks a whole lot better.

Nice surprise!<br /><br />Bowl is sturdy and easy to whip-up a good lather. The bowl looks exactly as depicted, flat black exterior that easy to hold onto and a gloss green interior easy to clean. Low profile fits easily in small bathroom drawer.<br /><br />The $9 price is an amazing value for all you get!!!! Don't you love getting something that far exceeds your expectations?!!!!

The handle is plastic, and the bristles do come loose a little with use, but nothing terrible. The soap works well, and it smells nice- nothing too soapy, just a clean fragrance. I would give it five stars if the brush was badger hair, but I've only used boar bristle brushes, and they work fine for me.

  252. I bought this set at a supercenter after I lost my very, very cheap boar brush that I had had for years. They didn't sell the brush by itself, so I bought the whole kit. Here's my review: The bowl is fine-- I mean, it's a bowl, and it does what bowls are supposed to do. The soap is awesome for it's price-- better than Williams, Colgate's, or Col. Conk's (except in scent on Col. Conk's). It lathers well, it's smooth-shaving, it's moisturizing, and the scent is pleasing. However, The brush lost it's bristles after only a few months of use. I don't mean just a few bristles, either. It started out that way, but one day the entire center half of the bristles came out on my lips like a disfigured mustache. Now, I'm not aggressive with my brushes. Just look at the fact that my cheaper brush lasted for years. Maybe I just got a bad one, but I'm not going to take my chances with another one. I've bought a $22 brush and will probably give a review on that one after a few months.

  260. This was a fun set to buy. Using it made me look forward to shaving in the morning. The bowl and the brush and the activity of wetting the soap and building a lather makes it more of a ritual than just blasting out some shaving gel and starting. The only problem is the brush fell apart. The clump of badger hair detached from the handle. It looks like it's very poorly glued... in fact the glue doesn't even go all the way around the hair. The bowl and the soap are nice. Having this as a low price comprehensive introductory set was great. Now I'm going to get a higher quality brush, hopefully one that will last. I think ultimately I'll get another bowl as well. When the soap gets slippery it tends to slide around the bottom which makes it harder to get a lather going. A bowl with some texture at the bottom to hold the soap in place would probably be nicer.
  261. About 15 years ago, a co-worker turned me on to brush shaving, and I never turned back. I broke in with the brush and soap from Van Der Hagen (they were separate, not in a set). I would recommend this set for anyone wanting to start brush shaving. I've since moved on to nicer sets, and bought a nice brush, razor and travel bowl to put together my own travel set, but I still use this brand soap. I'm tempted to get this set just for the bowl (the ceramic bowl that came with one of my sets broke, and another set I have didn't come with a bowl). I no longer have to bother with canned shaving creams, and I just love the old school feel of shaving with a brush and soap. In the end, it's less expensive, as the soap cake lasts much longer than a can of cream/gel and are individually less expensive. I'd love to start using a straight razor also, but I'm a little scared...HA HA! The brush will last if you care for it properly - after use, rinse and shake it out, and store it hanging bristles down (gravity will draw water/moisture away from the base, as otherwise it rots out the base and causes the hairs to fall out prematurely). So if you want to start brush shaving, or maybe are looking for a low-cost travel set, I'd go with this set.
  262. Good Product , Good Price
  263. I'm done paying massive amount of dough every month to shave...

I emailed the company and they actually sent me the badger brush for free or asked me if I wanted to return the entire product for refund. I chose to try the badger brush and it is much better than the boar brush that the set comes with. Not only are the bristles softer, but they don't come loose and stick to my face.

The soap smells good and does its job. The only problem I see here is the brush. It is stiff even for a boar brush. While the brush did its job, it was not enjoyable. The bristles seem to irritate the skin more than those of slightly better brushes. The brush also seems to continue shedding excessively with each use. I would recommend this kit to anyone who is not sure whether they want to start Wet Shaving. If you think wet shaving is for you, spend just a little bit more on a brush. A few extra dollars now will provide a brush that can stay in your collection for years instead of weeks.
  269. Are there better kits out there? For sure. Are there better kits for about $10? Nope! I bought one as a travel kit because I didn't want to cry if it got lost or broken. Maybe I don't have an overly sensitive face, but I find that it works just fine for me and use it more than my badger brush. The bowl was odd at first compared to a mug, but it's handy and not overly large. The soap is decent quality. I find that I like to put a dab of Proraso shave cream on the brush and make a hybrid lather. The Proraso isn't necessary, but I like it. Overall, this is a really good value-oriented kit and I recommend it without reservation. And if I'm wrong and you hate it? You're out $10.

  282. Quite good for a shave set and an incredible price. You don't need a fancy soap or brush or a fancy bowl to build a great lather. I am one of those people who joined one of those forums filled with shaving enthusiasts and my goal was simple learn from them but not get swallowed in by the ridiculous acquisition disorders of needing fancy silvertip badger brushes or fancy soaps. I just wanted to learn how to use this and a DE razor. And I can tell you that can be done with this set.<br /><br />It's not fancy, pretty, or will smell as good as the other stuff but it will get the job done as long as you learn how to use your tools. For me that means I melt the soap down into the bowl and load up the brush in there before I face lather and get a good lather going. After I am done with each area shaving I re-apply lather there by painting it on as I noticed I get a better shave doing that as it keeps my beard moisturized and some of the ingredients in the soap soften the beard, so better shave. After I am done with all areas i whip up a proper lather on my face and go for my second pass and any touch ups I need to do afterwards and I am good.
  283. Yes, the brush is not good, but the bowl and soap worth it. The value exceed the price.<br />Like another user wrote, put it in microwave and it will get the shape of the bowl. Just take care not to over heat it.
  284. I'm new to safety razors (been shaving with an Edwin Jagger DE89 for about two weeks) so I decided to pick this kit up to see what all the hoopla was about using a brush and puck soap. My verdict so far? Inconclusive. The brush: the first thing I noticed about the brush the first few times I used it were all of the hairs that separated from the handle while I was lathering up. So, I had to pick out the boar hairs from my freshly lathered face before I began my shave. I did like the feeling of the bristles against my skin. I can't say if that brush massage helped get a better shave or if it's just a \\"feel good\\" routine. The soap: Before I got this soap, I used a canned shaving gel and applied it to my face using my hand. The gel felt much better against my skin and moisturized my skin way better than the included soap. Oil of Olay bath soap does a much better job at moisturizing my skin than this puck soap. After my shave, my skin felt more irritated and my skin felt drier using this puck soap than using the canned shaving gel. With the gel, the razor seemed to glide smoothly across my face. It seemed like there was a bit more resistance against my face using the puck, which could be the cause of my irritated skin. The bowl: It's a bowl. Unlike a mug, it doesn't have a handle, so it can be a little trickier to hold if you have slippery hands. I could have pulled out an unused mug and been happier and saved some money. So in the end, I spent $10 for a brush massage and irritated skin. I'm right back where I started. I still don't know if using a brush is for me. To find this out, I may have to bite the bullet and spend the money on a quality setup. But until then, I'm perfectly happy using my canned shaving gel.
  285. I wanted to try the brush and soap. I will never go back to shaving cream again .soap lathers up nice no mess that you would get with the cream.It seams to give you a closer shave
  286. Its a nice soap set, but I should of looked at walmart first, it was a few dollars cheaper there.
  287. This shave set works great for a beginner. I didn't want to invest the money into a more expensive set without knowing if I'd like the DE shaving method.   288. This shave set is worth it's money but nothing more. The boars head drops a lot of hair with each shave and lathers pretty &#34;meh&#34; (it could just be because I'm new to the game). The bowl is just a regular bowl without a handle so it's pretty replaceable. For twelve dollars you could do worse- consider this your crash course.
  289. It's a good product that I would recommend to someone who wants to try a safety razor/brush shave for the first time. This is my first time using a brush and I have an average face. I did not have my safety razor yet as I ordered it after my wife got me this from walmart. So the only option I had was a USED disposable razor (not a cartridge razor but a plastic bic that had probably been used 2-3 times). I was expecting a face melting shave but I lathered up and, to my surprise, the shave was pretty good. I didn't even need to use aftershave and I got closer than expected. Only thing I don't like is the bowl. Yes it works but I would really like to see an handle. (I'll use an old coffee mug next time) Don't listen to the bad reviews! If they moved from a $15 brush and $5 soap to this $8 set than that is their own mistake. If you want to try wet shaving for the first time and don't want to break the bank this is the set to buy.
  290. The included soap cake is of good quality with mild scent. There are obviously better soaps available. The brush works nicely but it is only temporary, for it sheds a decent amount of bristles. A replacement will be required at some point. The ceramic bowl is good. This is something worth keeping around, although it should be noted that it is made in China. All-in-all, it's a worthwhile kit to start with and see if you want to continue brush shaving, albeit an easy decision to make.
  291. Recently, I've decided to try old fashioned shaving, just straight razor and shave soap. I picked this shave set up at wal-mart, more or less on a whim, and I haven't seen it there since. The soap taht comes with this set is wonderful. I have very sensitive skin, and it actually made my skin feel better after shaving. Occasionally, some of the bristles will fall out, but that's sort of to be expected, especially with natural boar bristles, but usually, it only loses about 5 a week, so it'll last a while, not to mention, it feels great when you brush on the soap for the very first time.
  292. For $10 I find it hard to complain. The brush itself is decent. If you are starting out in wet shaving or trying to save a few bucks I haven't had any issues with it. While it's not the softest, I wouldn't call it uncomfortable by any means. I can't really speak to the bowl as mine was totally demolished on arrival. Again, for $10 I'm not going to complain. The shave soap is not my favorite. If you are just starting out like I was when I purchased this, you will probably have an easier time with shave creams. But, to each his own. If I had to do it over again, I would probably just get the brush by itself and get another shave soap/cream such as Proraso. If you have the money, I would probably pay a bit more for a nicer brush, but you can certainly do worse than this one.
  293. I like the soap. I don't like the brush. The cup is ok. Get what you pay for.
  294. Good starter kit. Took me about a month to learn to make good cream from the soap puck. I'd recommend using a tube of cream to learn, then move on to the soap puck after you've learned to use a brush appropriately.
  295. This shave set is great for your first set. There is nothing functionally wrong with this set, and the soap it comes with is alright and has a pleasant smell. This is certainly no &#34;premium&#34; set, as others have mentioned, since the brush handle is plastic and the bowl is neither attractive nor unattractive. If you are on the fence about using a brush and shaving soap for shaving, do yourself a favor and try this out. It will cost you less than a can or two of shaving gel/cream, and I guarantee you will prefer the soap and brush regardless of which kind of blade you shave with.<br /><br />If having a wooden handle is a deal breaker, you're going to spend a lot more money.
  296. This was a great starter gift set. I did not like the soap but it works to see if you like lathering with a brush. Brush will only last a short time but again great way to see if you like it before drop coin on a better brush. the bowl is a bowl, I used a coffee cup for years before this and that worked too.
  297. I've used one of these since August 2013. in that time I've used one complete buck of soap and about half of a second one. the brush occasionally drops a bristle or two but is IMO even better now than it was new. The Cup being shorter than a mug helps get the lather going better and wastes less soap. save the plastic blister clam shell the soap comes in and you can melt down and make your own puck out of any good and sudsy soap you want. You can be high society and spend a bunch on a better mouse trap or you can use this and get the job done just fine.

  299. I was tired of canned jels running out of propulsion before the can was empty. Thought I'd give shave soap a shot. Glad I did. This soap gives a smooth close shave. The scent is pleasant but not assertive. There's something about lathering up with a brush and soap rather than squirting some chemical brew out of a can.

Obviously this won't compare to $30 or $60+ brushes, but it does what I (and most people) need it to do.

  306. I love the soap, the smell, and the bowl. However, this cheaply made brush started falling apart after the second use. I turned ut upside down to dry and never pulled on it. I noticed that I would have the bristles on my face and in my razor. If you already have a better brush I would recommend.
  307. This is my first wet shaving set. I found it to be a good intro to wet-shaving since I didn't really know if I'm committed to doing it over using an electric razor. The bowl is nicely shaped and works well with the brush. It's not too deep that the brush can't reach the bottom, which I find to be a problem when I use this brush with a different mug. The soap is not bad and lathers up decently. Creating a good lather with this brush and soap was little challenging at first but I eventually figured it out. You really have to work it with the brush and add plenty of water.<br /><br />The brush is not bad but a bit on the short side. Some bristles fell off during my first few shaves. I eventually replaced the soap with a Proraso cream and the brush with a Parker badger brush, which are nicer but probably not worth the price difference.
  308. This is a good set for a good price. The only down fall is it does not come with a brush holder.
  309. I just bought this for my fiance to go with his straight razor. the bowl is blue and green, which was nice because i thought it was blac and green.However, the soap fits well inside of it, and is a good size to work up a lather. the brush is good, and does not loose hairs, i can't say anything about the soap. it hasn't been used yet but i bought a few other brands/scents just incase he didn't like it or it irritates his skin. IT shipped quickly and the box was in great conditioning considering it went through usps.Excelent product for a very low price

  311. You're going to want to upgrade as soon as you start to really like wet shaving. I bought this product and it's a pretty good product for it's price.The soap is actually pretty good, not the best for lather but for the price and for a beginner, it gets the job done. The brush itself is nice but after three weeks my brush has lost so many hairs that it's lost a lot of its effiency. I've ordered a badger brush and it's great so I suggest a Parker Badger brush for your next purchase. The bowl is the bowl. Nothing to it, gets the job done but I personally don't like the fact that it doesn't have a handle.
  312. The soap and bowl in this set are good but the brush (the most important item in the kit) leaves much to be desired. It's stiff, doesn't hold water well, and doesn't make great lather. That being said the kit isn't a great deal after you take the brush out of the equation. A better setup can be put together. I found the VDH soap at a local store for $1.50. You can use an old mug, or find a bowl/mug at a thrift store. And the $13 badger brush here on Amazon is 100 times better than the brush in this kit.
  313. My main thoughts: This product costs what shaving products should cost. It's nice to see this in a market that seems wildly expensive to newcomers. All elements of the kit are durably made. Good way to see if you like shaving with a brush, which you probably will. 1. About the physical product: Brush: - Not too rough or too soft. - Well-glued. In my case, the brush looked nothing like that poorly glued specimen in the product photos. - Takes a little while to dry. Make sure to dry with the bristles hanging down (see below). Bowl: - Solid and a lot heavier than I expected. I could probably drop this and it would be fine. - Nice thick glossy finish. Soap: - Subtle, pleasant smell. - Good for sensitive skin. Better than my Aveeno can. - Builds lather decently, might take more time than some are used to (see below). - Perhaps as many uses as a can of shaving cream. 2. Tips to make the product even better: - Make your own brush stand. Take a coat hanger from the dry cleaners, fold the shoulders in, and kink the hanger loop forward. It will exponentially lengthen your usage time and will allow the brush to fully dry after use. Yes, this is a lower quality brush, so you'll quickly destroy it if you dry it by balancing it on its handle. - Take your time building lather. At first, you'll be terrible at building lather in the bowl. Take your time with it and really develop it before putting it on your face. The boar's hair will also take a few more uses to become effective. I bought this, along with a Concord DE razor, for a cheap introduction to safety razor shaving. I'm very happy with the start of things. I recommend it, along with some care.
  314. Fast shipping, just what I wanted
  315. I am no expert of these products and I can't even say I am moderately good with straight shaving yet but it is my understanding that the brush should not be loosing its Hair faster than my chin.
  316. my hubs switched from $12/4 razors to an old fashioned razor and decided to go all out with the brush lather too. Its kinds sexy.   318. I got this on the recommendation of a straight shaving website, and I have to say I'm really glad I listened to them. The brush is good quality. Half a dozen or so hairs came out the first time, but after that I maybe get one errant hair every 3 or 4 shaves. The bowl is very nice and well glazed, no globs or imperfections really, and my wife really likes the way it looks on the vanity, as opposed to an old, rusting can of shaving cream. The soap smells great and lathers very well, goes on smooth, and feels good. The only issue I have with the soap is that if I apply it to my whole face at one time, I'll have to freshen up the second half after finishing the first. That, however, may be with my lathering technique and how wet I have the brush, so don't be afraid to give it a shot and see for yourself.<br /><br />All in all a great product. I even tracked down the individual soap cakes and bought a 12 pack, I like it so much!

  321. The people that keep complaining that it's a cheap set bought it because it's a cheap set (that's why I bought it). I've used it for months and it is absolutely a great value. The brush gets softer the more it's used and the soap and bowl are exactly what they should be with no offending properties. The one thing I'd change if I could would be the inclusion of a brush stand, that would make the whole set really complete. If you want higher quality, pay for it. There's nothing wrong with this budget kit and I'd recommend it to a friend.
  322. I had been meaning to get away from canned shave cream for quite some time. About a week ago I saw this at walmart, for what it cost I figured I had very little to lose. The very first shave convinced me to ditch the cans. Is it the best there is? Obviously not, but at the price I don't care if I replace it all in two weeks. If I get such marked improvement with such a cheap kit it is absolutely worth investing in some quality kit.<br />The bowl, it's a BOWL! As long as it doesn't have spikes that shoot out skewering your hand while you lather I really don't care. Does it hold the soap? Yeah. Does it fit in my hand? Yeah. WIN!<br />The brush, it's cheap and cheesy but does it work? Yeah, it works. Am I looking to replace it? Sooner rather than later. But for the price, I have no regrets whatsoever.<br />The soap, it works. What more can I say? If a cheap block makes my face feel that much better after shaving than the stuff in cans then I'm on the right track. I learned how to lather with this soap, is there better stuff out there? Yeah, but this soap is like a set of cheap training wheels, use it till you get figure out what you're doing then move on to bigger & better.<br />All in all this is a great value, I would not hesitate to purchase this again or recommend it to someone looking to give wet shaving a try. The only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is because this is still just a starter kit, there's better out there but this gets the job done quite nicely.

This soap and brush will give you really great lather. There are more expensive products out there that may offer a bit smoother shave, but mostly you're paying for the luxury of how those products feel on the face. If you have any doubt at all, don't.   334. Lets start with the shaving mug, which is really more of a bowl. Cant say much bad about it, it's taken a beating as I use it when I travel and its held up well. This is the best part of the kit.<br /><br />The soap, well, it makes a decent lather. To me it spells like bug repellent though. This is why I go with something cheaper, that works better, with a much more pleasant aroma. There are MANY alternatives, a few of which I easily find in local drug stores.<br /><br />Now to the brush...<br />The handle on this thing is very poor quality. It is also not badger, but boar's hair, which to me just isn't as good, but it's a decent start for someone wanting to use a brush for the first time. However, the bristles fall out.   340. I have been using this shaving bowl and brush for a couple of years now, and it has served perfectly.<br /><br />I bought this mainly because I loved the two-tone green bowl. It it simple, but very nicely finished and it has served me well for a couple of years with no cracks or chips. The bristle shaving brush that this kit comes with is a little on the cheap-side in that is has a plastic handle. However it very rarely loses hairs and once it is loaded up with soap it feels incredibly soft when brushed against your face. The somewhat stiffer bristles make it easy to build up a nice rich lather and as I have said before I have been using mine for a couple of years and it is still in great condition.<br /><br />The only downside to this kit is the soap that the set comes with. It is serviceable and works up a decent lather but it has a scent that is completely repellent to me. Instead I use Williams Mug Shaving Soap. William's has a very clean perfume-free scent, works a really nice lather that doesn't dry on your face and one cake can last for nearly a year even if you shave daily like I do.<br /><br />For the price I would really recommend this shaving kit though. It is sturdy and easy to clean and you don't have to worry about fingerprints, water stains or any of the other easily visible blemishes you get with metal shaving bowls.

  354. Edit: after using the set for a few weeks, I can say the brush is holding up well. The bowl is very slippery when holding with a wet hand. I have dropped it twice, but it didn't break. The soap does lather well, it just takes a little more work than proraso cream.<br /><br />i bought this set to keep at the 'office' as I often shave at work. At first I thought the boar brush was going to be much coarser than my other badger brush--it felt that way dry, but in actuality it is very soft when wet. The first (and only so far) time I used it about a dozen or so bristles fell out, which as long as it doesn't keep happening is fine, because the brush is very lush and full. The soap is ok--I like the subtle scent, but it isn't as full of a lather as I get with the tubes of shave cream. The bowl is a bowl and a good size when you don't have lots of space. I would reccomend it to a buddy who had never tried to shave this way--if they aren't into it they are only out a couple bucks, and if they are, well they will upgrade.

  356. The bowl is a bowl and at being a bowl it is quite eloquent; the green and the black colors are admittedly superfluous but otherwise it performs admirably without traditional capitalist stylistic decadence.

  373. I recently purchased this brush at Walmart. It was on sale for $1, so the price was amazing. My only complaint is that I don't think it's completely made of badger hair. I also own a tweezerman brush, and all of the bristles have the dark markings about halfway down the bristle just like the ones on the outside of this brush. The tweezerman brush works great! This one works ok, but doesn't produce nearly the amount of good foam that the tweezerman brush can produce. I think the bristles on the inside are synthetic, and don't seem to produce the same about of lather as my other brush.<br /><br />My advise for the beginner is to spend $15 and get a good brush, don't mess with the shave soap, and purchase some decent shave cream. It produces a much better lather, and feels better on the face. I buy mine at bath and body works.<br /><br />I have been using a badger hair brush daily for the past two years to shave, and i just used bar soap. i bought the shave soap pucks, but was never happy with the lather, so i used the bar in the shower for convenience. I will be ordering different brush and cream. Nothing wrong with this, it is what they claim, but it is a cheap shave set and performs like a cheap shave set.

  378. When i met my husband he had no particular style, he had a bad hair cut and wore clothes that neither flattered him nor fit him. I thought it would go with his style he likes....this kit did the trick, he is hooked on lathering up a brush and loves the feel and smell of soap. He is thinking straight razors. Could be next. He is really happy with the soap that came with the kit and I got him some fancy soap in addition...he doesn't like one over the other so he'll likely get the cheape soap when he needs another. He has no complaints with the equipment...keep in mind he has nothing to compare it with other than his hands and gel...but he isn't really particular and he is really rough on his stuff so I don't think ill shell out a bunch on nicer stuff any time soon. This kit was a great buy for us...I think any guy who shaves should give it a try.

  392. I bought this set two weeks ago as my first foray into brush shaving with a safety razor. I have to say, this kit actually served as a really good introduction into the art that is old school shaving. I don't have much facial hair, so I've actually only done about four or five shaves with it, but I can already tell that I'll definitely be looking for something with a little more quality. Still, I'll happily recommend this set.<br /><br />The weak point is most definitely the brush. It's boar hair, which is lower quality than badger hair (or so I'm told) and tends to not lather very well or very quickly. Additionally, hairs are still coming out occasionally, which is somewhat bothersome, but what can you expect from a $10 set?<br /><br />The soap itself seems to be of pretty good quality, and I can already tell it'll last me quite a while, even if I'm not using it in the most efficient way. If I have a gripe about it, it's that it seems to dry my face a bit, but it's not horrible.<br /><br />The bowl is quite simple, and I find nothing wrong with that. It's got a good weight to it, which makes it feel sturdy, but it's not so heavy that it's a bear. It fits nicely into my hand, which makes it easy in which to build a lather. And, you know what? It's a bowl. There's really nothing to complain about with a bowl.<br /><br />All in all, I'd certainly point new wet shavers to this set, but only to get you interested and see if you like this style of shaving. Once you decide you do, as I have, you'll probably want to look for something a bit better.

  395. Great kit. You get what you pay for though. Would have gotten 5 stars if the bristles in the brush didn't come out so often.   396. Alex hit this right on the money with his review. This is basically all you need to start shaving or \\"wet shaving\\" whatever the heck that is supposed to mean. This is the way your dad did it and his dad before him since probably the romans or greeks or something. You can avoid constantly buying cans and getting little rust rings on your sink counter. I think it does a better job than the canned stuff anyway and for less dough. The brush is boar, it's nice and stiff and manly and whips up the lather good and quick unlike the often scary expensive badger brushes that feel like a limp artist's detail brush and take 10 minutes to get a good lather. The soap is one of the best I've used and it's available separately, in fact you can buy all this stuff at Walgreens, Walmart, Rite-aid, or wherever. It's my go-to shaving soap, I've bought others and they've been sitting around turning to crust for years now. I hope Van Der Hagen stays in business for a long time! The bowl is also the perfect size and matches the brush, what more can you ask for honestly? I wish Van Der Hagen or Gillette or somebody would make a good inexpensive double-edge razor similar to this set.
  397. The soap works well and the bowl is very nice. Only minor complaint is the boar brush is a little prickly compared to a badger brush and the plastic handle just really cheapens the look of it, so the brush is certainly nothing to show off on your counter. For the price however, it's a great starter set.<br /><br />Tip: They give instructions on how to get started, but leave the &#34;how to get the lather you like&#34; up to your experimentation. If you like a thicker lather, shake out the brush well after wetting it. The less water, the thicker the lather. Enjoy!

Well made for the price. It was pushing all the soaps away from my face. I didn't even put pressure on the brush itself, but i found out that instead of wetting your face, put a hot/very warm towel over your shaving area for about 30 seconds and then apply usually minimizes the lathering reduction from this brush.<br /><br />After thoughts: I want to try out the silvertip now, but i won't be doing so until i get use to the whole safety razor techniques and what not.   406. Wet the brush well with hot water, put a little water in the cup with the soap. lather it up and spread it on your face. Let it stand for about a minute or so to soften your face and beard that has been washed with a hot wash cloth. Shave away and then wash your face with the rinsed out hot wash cloth. Nothing to it. Very inexpensive way to soap up for a good shave. No can to dispose of either. Liked it a lot. Recommend it to anyone who shaves their face. Splash on a little witch hazel after and you feel good about life. Incidently, I bought my brush, soap and bowl at Walmart for $8.52 plus tax (6.53%). Target has the more expensive Van der hagen soap and brush set with the fancy little cup with the nub handle that sticks out. I like the less expensive cup because I can put into a water tight plastic container for taking on trips with me. Great shaving soap to say the least. Just brush it on and let it stand for a moment before shaving.<br /><br />Regards, Pag

I purchased several of these to give out as gifts for Christmas, so they served that purpose fairly well.<br /><br />You have to remember one thing; this is a basic beginners set, so don't expect anything too special.<br /><br />I'll preface this review with the fact that I've been wet-shaving for several years, and am used to nicer things.<br /><br />Pro's:<br /><br />-The cost is obviously why you are here, and you do get a good deal.<br /><br />-The soap is acceptable, and usable. More on this later.<br /><br />-The brush isn't too bad, and will break-in with continued use.<br /><br />-The size of the bowl is about right for lathering the soap that it comes with.<br /><br />Con's:<br /><br />-The quality of the brush handle is... junk. I'd suggest upgrading to Proraso creams or glycerine soaps.<br /><br />- The bowl doesn't work too well for soaps that lather really well, it's a bit small for that.<br /><br />Overall:<br /><br />- I would buy these as gifts again, and possibly as a cheap travel set for myself, but most wet-shavers will get the urge to upgrade quickly.

  420. Size is fine and doesn't look stupid in the bathroom.<br /><br />Brush is just fine. Doesn't come with a holder, so mine has been drying bristles-up, which is bad, but I shake as much water out as I can, and it has been holding up for a couple of months just fine.<br /><br />For the price, in a pinch, or for someone new to wet shaving, I would recommend this set. Once the soap runs out, you find good soap to put in the bowl. Once the brush is destroyed from drying upside down, you replace with another cheap brush with a stand. Once the second soap runs out, get a decent mug if you want a handle, or if you've gotten used to this, then whatever, it's a ceramic bowl, not much to complain about.<br /><br />Not great as a gift, not much luxury here, but as a necessary hygiene product, it is just fine.

  427. When I first started experimenting with the wonderful world of safety razors (now moving to straight razors), shaving soap and brushes, this is what I started with. It's great! Don't let the price fool you. I leave the soap in the ceramic bowl and use the brush to lather it up before applying to the face.<br /><br />Here's why it's 3 stars and not 5: The brush doesn't last. I've purchased two brushes from this brand and both of them have lasted a couple of months. I don't know if that's normal for other brands, but I doubt it. I am investing in a better quality brush, but I still use this ceramic bowl and soap. The soap lasts a LONG time and it's really cheap. If you're getting into the traditional shaving method, I'd recommend this as an economical starter option.

  429. I gave this set 4 stars because it is quite nice for the money, however if you're a little clumsy - like me - you might drop it in the sink and break it, like I did. I ordered a stainless steel bowl to replace it, I might dent that one but I won't break it!
  430. This shaving set is obviously designed for first time wet shavers to get their feet wet (bad pun intended) at a cheap price. Being a first timer, I fell to the appeal of it as well. Now, don't get me wrong, it's not bad at all. It gives you a nice little bowl, a bar of soap, and a boar's hair brush all for the cheap price of ten bucks. It's a great idea to have all these items packaged together so first-timers don't get overwhelmed at having to purchase everything separately. But if you just take a step back, you might see that it's no big deal to get these three items separately, and in fact it might be in your own benefit to do so. On the other hand, you might enjoy the learning experience you get from this package. I'll share my critiques of each item and what I learned.<br /><br />1) the bowl: It's a great bowl, but I find it a little small and sometimes lather can start foaming out of it during your mixing, no biggy. The thing I like most about this bowl is that it has a nice contrasting color to shave cream. I actually found it hard to keep track of all my created lather when I tried making it in a white bowl, but I have no trouble at all with this bowl.<br /><br />2) the boar's hair brush: Ohhh, you'll hear the \\"pros\\" always hating on boar's hair brushes and saying badger hair brushes are better. I actually completely agree with them; I find a badger hair brush to be much better suited to creating and applying lather. However, I still had a lot of fun comparing the two in my shaves and learning for myself the actual differences between them. It's not like a boar's hair brush is useless, you can definitely still make lather with it. But if you're a no-nonsense kind of guy and don't want to experiment, I strongly urge you to not buy this set. You will definitely replace this brush with a badger hair brush and you'll feel like you wasted your money.<br /><br />3) the soap: It's fine. You can purchase it on its own for like 2 bucks on amazon. A good idea is to remove the puck, place it in the bowl, and then microwave in spurts of ten seconds until it melts. Now let it reharden and it will be formed to the bottom of the bowl making lather creation easier (microwave melting works fine with this type of soap, but it doesnt work for certain other types so be careful). If you're like most people, you'll find that lather making from a soap takes more time and is harder than creating lather from a shaving cream. If you don't want to deal with the hardships of turning soap into lather but you still want to wet-shave, you're probably better off buying a cream. I find it a fun skill to practice and master so I'm happy with the soap.<br /><br />Conclusion: For someone who literally wants to get it right the first time with cheap but quality products, I couldn't recommend this set. You really are better off getting the cheap tweezerman $10 badger hair brush, getting a cheap bowl/mug from wherever, and just buying this soap separately. However, for someone who is interested in learning and doesn't mind trying out a boar's hair first, then I whole-heartedly recommend this set. I don't see boar's hair brushes sold individually on amazon, and they're like 10 bucks at stores, so this set really is a great deal. In addition to it, I still recommend you buy the tweezerman badger hair brush. You'll have a much better understanding of the comparison between a badger hair and a boar hair brush if you try both out for yourself, and at twenty bucks (10 for this set and 10 for the additional badger hair brush) it's a great affordable way to get into the world of wet shaving.
  431. Awesome Soap and bowl, the brush is on the lower end of quality but this was my first attempt at wet shaving so this was a great deal for just trying out, the handle of the brush did not fit well in the Mission Style Wood Shave Stand for Razor and Brush - Walnut Finish but you couldnt beat the price, i have passed the brush onto my lil brother for him to try but i am still ejoying the wonderful soap and bowl... great starter but if you enjoy the wet shave you'll soon move onto a pure badger hair brush
  432. I was frustrated with the cost of canned shaving creams and the inexpensive ones did not do a good job at all. In fact, for over a year I was using hair conditioner for beard shaving because it did a much better job for much less money than any of the expensive canned creams (yes, hair conditioner makes a great shaving cream for your face). I made an impulse purchase when I saw this at Wal-mart, although I really liked the shave I got using hair conditioner, I didn't care for the smell and it didn't leave my face feeling clean. If you are not a shaving snob and just want a better shave than you get with canned shaving creams at a lot less cost then give this a try. I did and I am now hooked on soap and brush shaving. Pro: It is inexpensive. It gives me a better shave than I have gotten with any canned cream. Saves me a heck of a lot of money on shaving cream. The bowl holds the soap so well that it doesn't move around when building a lather. I really like the size of the bowl. It fits great in my big hands, I'm 6'5\\". Smells good and leaves my skin feeling soft yet clean. Brush bristles are firm enough to produce a good lather but not foamy like canned creams. Con: I shave in the shower and since the bowl doesn't have a lid, I have to keep the bowl on a shelve outside the shower but within reach while I'm in the shower. Neither pros or cons: The handle of the brush is plastic. I don't care that it is plastic because I care more about \\"expensive to quality of shave\\" ratio but if you are a shaving snob and want to waste you money on a wooden handle when a plastic one works great (even better than wood if you shower shave) then go else where. There is no brush holder but you don't need one since it stands upright on the handle. I start by running the brush under the shower then start to build the lather in the bowl but finish lathering on my face. I've watched videos on YouTube that show how to lather (like this one [...] ) but I think the guy in the video is nuts because I don't need to push the brush that hard on my face or bowl as to dis-form the brush to get a good lather but then I prefer lather to foam so in my opinion the guy in the video over lathers and produces way too much foam. Foam does nothing to increase the quality of your shave. The oils in the soap help the blade glide over your face and the brush helps lift up the hairs. Producing a lot of foam is just a waste of time and will cause your brush to wear out quicker.
  433. Nice for the price. It's my first shave set and it works wonderfully. The soap smells good and makes good lather for a good shave.
  434. I received this shave set today. The SHIPPING was FAST! I used the shaving soap, brush, and bowl. I am PLEASED with the results. I like the scent of the shave soap. I am VERY happy with this purchase.
  435. We bought these as part of groomsmen gifts at our wedding, along with some vintage safety razors. The brush is not very soft and it will be replaced in the long term. The soap smells awesome. A nice addition to this set would be a stand for the brush and razor.
  436. This is definity a cheap beginner set. It works ok. I really wish that the shaving soap worked better but that might just be user error.
