  437. Despite the mixed reviews I thought this set was worth the price.<br /><br />Soap - this shave soap is above average in quality. The cake is nearly double the thickness of what you get from Williams and lasts an extremely long time. With the right technique the lather is good, though a bit thin, and does not appear to dry out the face. 7 out of 10.<br /><br />Bowl - nicer than what I was expecting, this bowl is heavy and well glazed. It's a great size for building up lather and while some have discounted it do to its lack of a handle or its depth I really like it. 9 out of 10.<br /><br />Brush - a very basic brush which is of decent value to get you to your next brush; I'd give it an approximate life of 6 months to a year depending on technique and care. Note that Van Der Hagen makes two types of boar brushes, the \\"natural\\" boar brush (blue handle) is what comes with this set and is the cheaper of the two. The nicer one is sold individually and is the \\"deluxe\\" boar brush (white handle). The deluxe actually lasts substantially longer and, with proper care, will last for years in my opinion. You can find this brush here on Amazon, Walmart or CVS. It's around 7 to 8 bucks. 4 out of 10 (blue handle) 6 out of 10 (white handle).
  438. If you're wanting to get into Wet Shaving i don't think you can go wrong with this set. It's not high end, it's not the best money can buy, but it also doesn't break the bank. The bowl is perfect. It's simple, and it gets the job done. It could've used a handle of some sort, and maybe a little wider, but it's no big deal.<br /><br />The brush is not of the highest quality, but if you're worried you might not permanently change your shaving technique, it's a good enough initial investment to test out the pros/cons of wet shaving. On first use maybe about a dozen hairs fell off, but since then, maybe 3 have fallen in the last 4-5 months.<br /><br />The soap does not really have a scent, but it makes a great later. I find that the lather on this soap is better than that of Arko soap, although it does not provide the same soothing/menthol-ish sensation on your skin. Like the rest of this set, it's good, especially for the price, but it's not amazing.

  448. I originally bought this product for my husband - he never used it, silly man, so in the spirit of 'waste not, want not', I gave it a try! Five years or more and I have never looked back. The brush and soap give a thick, creamy lather, and leave my legs and lady bits as smooth as silk. Fewer nicks, never an ingrown hair and skin so soft and smooth that it literally shimmers! I have since replaced the husband, but I am still using the same brush and bowl daily! I have given kits to my daughters and close friends, and they all agree this is an elegant and indulgent way to handle the necessary evil of shaving!
  449. comes with every basic thing you need. the soap has a nice, light scent and doesn't dry out the skin. bought this for my boyfriend for our anniversary and he loves it
  450. amazing price... fast delivery .... the product is excellent quality . I love it since I have problems shaving, this product will be great ...
  451. this works great, this is a great started to shaving like my grandfather did. I am realizing that shaving is more than running a blade across my fave. Get started and enjoy a good clean shave.
  452. Love the feeling of this soap, it's smooth and just right in thickness. Leaves my face smooth after a shave and is worth getting if your looking for a great shave. Only thing is the bristles tend to come off the brush but is worth the price and you get more than what you pay for.
  453. I bought this kit to begin shaving with a safety razor. I would highly recommend spending a little extra for a better set. The bristles began to fall out of the brush every time I lathered up and the brush soon broke in half. Soap was mediocre.
  454. I bought this set when i started with a safety razor and its a great set for beginners, the soap works great for lather and after some practice you get the hang of it. I give this only 4 stars because the bowl is a bit to small when you what to lather up and because the brush is a bit stiff. I would recommend this set if you are looking to start using a safety razor or a strait edge, or just want to try to make your own lather when you are shaving. I would also recommend to buy a badger brush if you like to use this.
  455. The perfect shave kit for a new shaver. I have purchased more expensive shave kits in the past and the real different is the quality of fur used in the brush. But $15 for a shave kit is a great price to get a new shaver interested (my 16 year old nephew) in shaving. He loves it.
  456. If you are the guy that is just getting into wet shaving and wanna dabble a bit before spending more $$, or a guy that likes basic no frill stuff, then this is for you! I switched to a double edge wet system and I have used this set daily for about six months and it has held up very well. Kinda funny, we get into wet shaving to save $ and then spend lots of $$$ on custom items. I have some exotically scented soaps my wife got me, and I do use them and each has its own merits. Everyone ends up liking their own particular style of razor, blades, brush, and soap. My point for this product review is that this basic set works very well, has great value and does the job. I wouldn't hesitate to buy it again, and really, no need to up grade. I'm not a shave snob!

  466. Overall I am very pleased with this set. It's a great introduction to shaving with soap and brush. Both the brush and bowl are made of sturdy plastic. After a couple uses the soap sits firmly in the bottom of the bowl and doesn't fish around. The bristles on the brush are comfortable and clean easily with a quick rinse. I would recommend this to anyone looking to try out using a brush for the first time.<br /><br />Recently, after a good 7 months of use, my brush did break: the bristles and their base came detached from the handle. I may have dropped it on a hard floor at one point, so I'm not sure I can blame the manufacturer. The break was clean, and after a little bit of superglue it seems to be as good as new.
  467. Good beginning set. The brush is pretty decent for the price.

The shaving soap is just OK for the sample but I'm looking for a more lathering and one with more of a moisturizer in it for my preference .<br />Over all it's just what it is a good starter kit.
  472. If you already wet shave and have a decent brush, a stand to hang it from to dry, and a good soap that you use, I would definitely buy this to get the ceramic bowl it comes with. It is the perfect size for melting a puck of glycerin soap into, like Colonel Conks.<br />That being said, beginners may want to look elsewhere. The boar brush is of very low quality, and mine in particular sheds a LOT of hair. I wouldn't count on this set because the shedding would make it annoying to shave with. Also this set doesn't come with a stand to hang your brush up to dry. The same brand has a higher quality set for like 30 bucks (25 at Walmart). the brush is much nicer (badger hair), the soap is better and smells very good, and it comes with a stand for your brush/razor. It also comes with a cool mug, but I like the bowl of this set better (why I got one). I would highly recommend that beginners get that set, as it is good enough to really set your wet shaving experience off right (look for the orange set).
  473. Great stuff. Should have done this years ago! I am a woman and use it for my legs.
  474. This shaving kit was a good buy for me. I'm just learning how to straight blade shave and I didn't want to spend a lot of money and this fit the bill. The brush is not all that great it did start to lose some of the hair on the first use. What do you expect at this price. The bowl is ok and works, and really you can use any kind of mug and it will do the job. The soap is not bad either but I have no other soap to compare it to but it seemed to work for me. I would recommend this product to anyone who wants to learn how to straight blade shave to start off and see if you would even continue to straight blade shave since it does take time to learn how to do it. I gave it a 4 star rating for the purpose of it being a learning tool at a cheap price.

  479. I purchased this set from my local Wal-Mart almost two years ago. To be honest, it was an impulse purchase, being that it was the first time I had seen such products locally. The lack of propellant chemicals and a can to throw away later prompted the purchase. To be honest, I haven't looked back to the can! Two pucks of soap have lasted a LONG time (granted, I don't always shave daily). This is, simply put, one of those products that is friendly to both the planet and your wallet!<br />I'm in the process of upgrading--wet shaving with a double-edged safety razor seems like a logical next step. I intend to order some of the &#34;name brand&#34; soap along with the new razor. I also intend to upgrade the brush and mug. The brush is boar hair with a plastic handle, and sheds a little bit.   499. If you are worth a few dozen million, then do go ahead and buy that $200.00 set. If you are like me, however, and you want quality but at a decent price, then here we are. This is an excellent shave set. Of course, one could argue that an old coffee cup from the thrift store works just as well as the shaving soap bowl. That being said, the key to the set is, of course, is the brush. This brush--in spite of the remarkable price--is just fine. Great, in fact. Some of the shaving forums go on about the different type of boar bristles available, and how this type or that type starts at $150.00, etc., but that is all nonsense. The boar's bristles in this brush are great, and the handle, while not made of a rare African hardwood, is just fine. The soap included in this set is very nice, as well. And, make no mistake, this stuff beats the heck out of that canned shaving cream all day long. Some believe that this method is better than using the canned shaving cream for environmental reasons...you know, &#34;saving Mother Earth,&#34; and all of that. Well, that's really nice, I guess. For my money, good old &#34;Mother Earth&#34; will keep rolling along nicely with or without shaving cream cans (but, we won't get into politics here LOL). The plain fact is that this traditional method is better because it is better. So, save your money and consider this great set at an unbelievable price, and forget the $200.00 sets.

  502. Premise: I started the world of shaving a whole year ago just before my senior year of college. I shaved daily, but skipped a month or two because of travel. I have a med to strong beard grown. Only about 10 mins tops for shaving available each day.<br /><br />This Kit for the most part was an awesome addition to my ensemble for two reasons. 1) The brush was been a faithful companion from the first day. 2) the price was really good.<br /><br />My shaving style is simple: I soak the brush while I shower. After I step out, I then lather the brush in shaving soap for about 2-3 minutes (for a thick lather) and then I shave. After the shave I wash the brush and hang it upside down on a (hanger made) brush holder. One year later it works very well.<br /><br />It is a bit stiffer than a badger (I believe) but honestly with a good lather it is quite soft (manly soft lol) on the face.<br /><br />The Bowl broke within 5 months of ownership lol, but a trip to the Good will found its 59 cent cousin and the partnership has been going strong. Really you are purchasing this kit for the brush.....everything else is the icing on the cake.

  534. I purchased this set because I switched back from an electric shaver after a few years because I was tired of expensive replacement blades and the internal battery died.<br /><br />This set has reintroduced me to the joy of wet shaving.<br /><br />The bowl is a nice little bowl. It fits in my hand nicely and the high wall keeps most of the lather in the bowl without creeping out all over the place.<br /><br />The brush is a really solid brush. I soak mine in hot water for a few minutes while i get everything ready and it feel great and works up a nice lather. It has dropped a few bristles since I've had it for a few weeks but nothing really noticeable. I wish the handle was shorter but that's just my preference. The handle is comfortable.<br /><br />The soap is ok. I had a hard time getting a rich lather out of it in the bowl. I had much better luck working it up in my hand. I soak the soap, still in the plastic container, in hot water until is a little mushy and pliable. Then i load the brush up by messing it around in the soap a while. If you get it hot and wet it makes a surprisingly good lather.<br /><br />Would have been five stars if it were not for dropping a few hairs from the brush and the time it takes the soap to soak.

Along with a leather sharpening belt and a display stand for the razor and brush, this Shave Set by Van Der Hagen goes perfectly with it. It came in a timely manner and definitely on time for the Holidays!
  545. You can't compare the quality of the soap and brush to individual items which cost more than this entire set. I bought this for my husband who was switching from a Mach 3 to a Merkur. There's still plenty of soap, however.

I've had the brush since February 20th. I would have maybe 1 hair come loose every 3 shaves. For this price though, you can't beat it. I know that I like shaving with my safety razor, and it's time to upgrade.<br /><br />Great product!
  547. its a wonderful product my face felt wonderful during and after my shave the brush feels great and really massages your face
  548. It's a soap bowl and brush. That's what I wanted. However, it tells you how to use the product. For years I have always thought you ran hot water into the bowl. I have learned that you wet the brush and then swirl it on the soap. The wetter the brush, the more the lather. The soap should last longer too. Thank you..
  549. The shave set was purchased as an introduction to DE shaving. It is the quality that you would expect at this price level. The brush sheds quite a bit, even after using for a month.   556. Good value. Doesn't break the bank.
  557. Ordered this for my husband and he loves it!
  558. Obviously this is not for old school die-hard wet shaving enthusiasts yet still easily beats using canned shaving foam/gel. The dish is exactly as it appears, decent looking but nothing too exciting. The brush is a low grade boar hair brush that is unlikely to last more than a few months. I've used mine about 6 weeks and it is shot which is what I was looking for when I decided to write this review. The brush should be hanged upside down(bristles down) to allow for proper drying and prolong it's life. I did not do so and merely turned it up on it's end when done shaving, consequently the hairs have prematurely worn. Personally I like the soap, it has a very mild yet pleasant odor and contains Aloe and Shea Butter. My skin is moderately dry and this helps lubricate for a comfortable shave while moistening my face simultaneously. This shave set is nothing that will last years but is ideal to get a sense of if you wish to pursue wet shaving/using a brush and soap in the future. It does not lather nearly as well as a quality brush but is sufficient for a comfortable and close shave. The soap will likely last you 3-6 months so coupled with the bowl it is worth the price. You can find double edged razor blades for a safety razor in local stores for less than $2.00/10 blades. These blades offer a much closer shave than any cartridge I have used and are significantly less costly. I would encourage all men to at least try it so you too can rid yourself of the burden of a lifetime of expensive razor/cartridge replacements. Actually this is a brilliant marketing idea for a company who sells higher grade safety razors/straight razors/shaving soaps/bowls/shave kits as it is enough to experience it at a low cost.
  559. Worked great for about a month (using it 2-3 times per week), then the glue that held the bristles in place failed causing chunks of the hairs to fall out of the handle. Not worth the aggravation. Going to pay double for a better quality brush.
  560. Very good product!! The brush feels good on the skin, the soap lathers well and smells nice without being perfumy. The bowl is the perfect size, large enough to stay put on the counter and small enough to fit in the hand. I've tried both ways and both work. I use mine with my Parker Razors, nice smooth shave and I'm not throwing away a can or using any propellant. Wish it came in choice of color.

He even stated that I'd better not steal his soap to use for my legs! The brush is holding together just fine and it has been used for more than three months now. I don't know what other people are doing to the brush to make it fall apart, but it only gets used for a few moments every day. The bowl works perfectly. I think I will buy one for my \\"green\\" son-in-law who is jealousy eying the set. Here is a case where going green is cheaper and BETTER! Update: After using this set for a year and a half, it is still going strong. My husband just opened his second bar of soap and the brush...yes the cheapo boar bristle brush...is still working just fine. My son and my son-in-law are now converted to this method of shaving, and their sets are also holding up with no problems. Makes a GREAT gift!

  575. You will not find a set better at $10, so some credit should be given where credit is due. Just be aware that the brush may fall apart after a few years.<br /><br />I'm making this review after over 3-4 years of use. The brush head fell off since it's only glued on. I attempted to epoxy it back on, and then driving a nail through both brush head and handle, and then epoxying it back on which helped for a while but it eventually fell apart again. I'm not complaining too much because it did give me many years of service. If you're unsure of using a brush and bowl to start shaving then this is a decent starter set. If the brush fall apart on you like it did for me at the very least you get to use the soap and the bowl you can probably use forever.<br /><br />But if you are in it for the long haul go ahead and buy a Tweezerman brush and Tabac shaving soap. I love these two items. The soap is adequate, but really there's no turning back once you've tried other shaving products.<br /><br />You just can't expect that much at this price point. The tweezerman brush alone cost as much as this set, and Tabac shaving soap cost twice that, albeit it's at a much larger quantity, but you'll be able to get a good lather very quickly with very little soap with these two items.

  591. I bought this approximately one year ago with a safety razor and blades. I absolutely love the move to the safety razor- the shave is wonderful once you get used to it, and the cost per blade is under 10 cents.<br /><br />It was my understanding that it's best to move to a brush if you use a safety razor. After a year of use, I can say that the brush makes no difference at all. High quality gel works far better than the old school brush and soap (I use Gilette gel sold in 4 packs at Costco). Shaving immediately after a shower (or during if you're skilled) makes the biggest difference of all.<br /><br />Regarding this product:<br />-The SOAP smells like my grandfather's basement, and my girlfriend hates the scent it leaves on my face.<br />-The BRUSH looses bristles after the first few uses, and the bristles get stuck on your face.<br />-The BOWL is nothing extraordinary.<br /><br />Save your money and buy high quality gel. Old school razors are great and cheap. Old school lather is unneeded and overrated.
  592. This is a basic shaving set, nothing fancy just what is needed, which is exactly my style. Overall I'd recommend this set to anyone looking to upgrade their shave routine.<br /><br />Eventually I might purchase a nicer set and keep this one as a back-up for travel but for the foreseeable future it's exactly what I wanted.

  599. Yes, you can get better quality. As is always the case. But this set, for the price, is a great way to get into wet shaving and to make shaving a more pleasurable experience.<br /><br />The bowl is a bowl. Nothing really to review. It doesn't blow up when you touch it.<br /><br />The brush is a little hard right out of the box, and needs to be soaked in warm soapy water and you need to inspect for loose bristles. I worked up a good soapy lather on mine and then let mine soak in hot water for ten minutes. Then let it dry out. After that I pulled out any loose bristles, which I found about ten or so. The next day I used it for a shave after the same routine. I have fairly sensitive skin and the brush, when well lathered did a good job of applying without irritating. Not the softest thing ever but none of these brushes are in my experience. They have to be firm to work up a lather. Over all good job if you don't mind losing a bristle on your face every now and then.<br /><br />The soap. It did lather up well and smells really good. Got a good shave with it. The only thing for me is that my skin felt very dry after. Not sure if that's a personal thing or if it's just not good quality. I won't be finishing off the soap, and will be trying out others due to this. Have shaved a few times with it and my face feels much better after with other shave products. Even with other products I still use the brush and bowl, which work well.<br /><br />So in conclusion. If money is of no object, and you are really into shaving, get better gear. Get a good quality brush and a really quality soap. If you are low on cash and just want to try out the experience of wet shaving, then give this a shot.
  600. I've just started shaving with a straight edge razor. Before I used this kit, I wanted to use up some of the can shaving cream I had. I've found the soap in this kit works much better.   605. I just started manual shaving and needed shaving soap, a shaving brush, and a bowl.   606. If you want to get into wet shaving this is a great way to start out. It comes with everything you need, soap, brush and a nice little soap bowl. The soap smells great and will leave your face soft. The brush may feel a little rough at first but it softens after a good washing with the included soap. The brush handle is made of plastic so for those of you that can only touch gold you may want to stay away or you will melt and die as some other reviewer said. For those that don't have a problem with a little black plastic handle on the brush i highly recommend this!
  607. The boar brush in this kit is basically like a broom. It takes longer to make lather, doesn't hold as much water, and then tears up my face to the point that I can have moderate \\"razor burn\\" just by working the soap on with the brush and then washing it off without shaving.<br /><br />That being said, the bowl's decent and the soap is decent. You can do it with a $1 mug but I find having a decent shave bowl makes things more pleasant. There's better soap, like Saint Charle's Shave, but VDH isn't exactly bad; soap is a pretty personal preference anyway.<br /><br />The main thing I'd recommend with this is to spend the $12 for a Tweezerman brush and abandon that boar brush. Unless your skin is as sensitive as a brick, scrubbing your face with what amounts to a stiff toothbrush is going to hurt. It's like having a sandpaper, cotton, or silk handkerchief; you definitely want cotton, unless you're going to throw the $100 for a 10 inch square of silk (and the $120 for a Shavemac brush, which I personally would but not as my first brush).
  608. I think this shave set will make a GREAT addition to your shaving routine. For yourself or as a gift, you couldn't go wrong either way. If you've just discovered the old/new world of wet-shaving or you're an old hand at it, this 3 piece set WILL find some good use. The brush is your typical 100% natural boar brush. It's inexpensive and does the job without frills. It might not soak up as much water or feel better on your face than a badger brush but it does what it was intended to do. When you absolutely can't have anything synthetic touching your face, you'll be happy to know that it even comes with that wonderful wet animal smell in the beginning. A few hairs will fall out, the handle is plastic and if you drop it or lose it....who cares!? I have found the Van der Hagen soap provides a better and closer shave than some Italian imports. I can best describe the smell of this soap as having a very slight baby powder fragrance. The smell quickly dissipates and it is not overpowering. This soap lathers up better than my $9.00 Omega Menthol and Glycerin soap. It's also slicker and doesn't dry out as quick. For guys with sensitive skin, if you haven't tried VDH soap, give your wallet and face a break by trying this stuff. The ceramic bowl looks nice and appears well made. Based on the picture here, I was expecting the brush and bowl to be black but the dark color is actually navy blue. Still it looks very good. I no longer see this set sold locally. If you purchase through here, you should feel confident knowing that it should arrive in perfect condition as it was WELL packed with bubble wrap. For only a little money, you can get a nice bowl that will last forever, an excellent soap everyone should try and a good brush. If you absolutely have to have a badger hair brush to shave, this brush makes a great utility brush as well...think computer keyboard and computer tower, car console etc...

I wouldn't expect much damage from such a short distance to fall but the thing nearly cracked in half. The brush itself is good and the soap is also fine.   612. I got this starter kit when I bought my first safety razor to begin on my trip through wet shaving. I have had it for at least three months, and I can say that this has been a great starter kit.<br /><br />Pros: Has everything that you need besides the safety razor and replacement blades. Comes with it's own bowl, shave soap, and brush. The soap is nice and mild, and reminds me of a barber shop. The bowl is perfectly sized to fit in my hand. The brush, despite having a plastic handle, still has plenty stiff bristles, which is the way I like my brushes.<br /><br />Cons: The bowl, despite the finish, can still be slippery in a wet hand. Would have liked for the finish to be a bit tackier or have a handle. The brush still sheds, despite months of use, and the plastic handle feels flimsy and cheap.<br /><br />Final thoughts: So far I believe that the kit has been a great introduction to wet shaving. However, I would recommend that when you receive the kit, before you use the brush, that you soak it a bit in hot water to soften it up a little bit. Then, you should probably melt the soap into the bowl, since otherwise it will slip and slide around when trying to use it with the brush. Just keep an eye on it when you do, since it will bubble. When the time comes for me to buy new soap, I will be buying a new brush as well. Not because it is necessary, but because I am tired of the shedding. Also, I recommend that first time wet shavers you go to youtube and look up the user mantic59. He has an excellent series on the basics of wet shaving and how to get started.

The brush is okay, it holds a minimal amount of lather, has a somewhat wild scent, and leaves bristles when used the first few times. The really nice part is that the soap isn't all watery; it foams up really well. I just made my own stand for the brush out of an extra wire hanger I had (felt good to use something that was just laying around).
  628. this set cost me $9 total including shipping. so i didn't have high expectations. after looking online i saw that the soap that come with it goes for about $3.5 and bowls around $8 up. by the way the also sell the soap and bowl set with out a brush for ten bucks. a dollar more then this one.<br /><br />yea i read the review that said the brush that come with it tends to fall apart a few weeks to months. so bought the set with the intentions that if i enjoyed this type of shaving i would upgrade to a better brush and if i didn't i would only lose $9. i used the set for two week and enjoyed it enough to invest a whole $20 on a nicer brush and am very satisfied. although i do have to wonder. i've been reading on wet shaving forums that losing a few hairs in the beginning is common and that if you break in the brush properly before hand after the first week or two you shouldn't lose any more or very few.<br /><br />http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=Semogue<br /><br />i wonder if people are breaking in properly.<br /><br />i really like the bowl, it is a simple one with out a handle that fits nicely into the palm of my hand and into the medicine cabinet after use. if it had a handle like is common then it wouldn't fit into the cabinet. it is very thick porcelain.<br /><br />i really like the soap but don't have any experience to compare it to. so plan on using different soaps to find which one i like best.

  637. I found this on the related items tab when i bought my straight edge. i've been shaving with a disposable single blade for over a year and now i'm venturing out to the solid shave soap now. it is a pretty heavy, ceramic bowl. didn't break without any extra packaging, and i am overseas at an APO so it was handled a little extra more than usual mail. the brush feels good after a good wash with hot water. i let it sit in some hot water for a little bit just to soften up the bristles as i imagined it was a cheap plastic. it is actually a synthetic hair brush which makes me think of the three stooges when i lather up. a few stray fibers fell out on my first try but its good now. the soap is pleasant without any pungent odor and moisturizes as well. thickness of the lather is based on how much water you add so its all a matter of preference. all in all, a good set to start out with that is affordable.
  638. This kit does exactly what it is supposed to do. The bowl is (obviously) the right size for the soap. The brush needed to be broken-in, and lost a few bristles the first few times I used it, but works very well, now that I've been using it for a few weeks. The soap lathers well, has a pleasant scent, and seems to have an excellent moisturizing effect that helps to prevent razor burn and doesn't dry my skin. This is a great starter set.

For me the bowl is the best part i don't use it to make a lather i just leave the soap their. I prefer to make the lather straight in my face when I shave. For the first year this brush worked as well as a shaving brush can. In retrospect I really didn't want to order a new brush each year and most folks want a longer lasting brush. So, buyer be ware.

  653. My husband loves this set. Lathers very well and nice looking set.
  654. I've been using this set for about a week and I'm pretty happy with it. The brush seems to lose a bristle or two each shave, but I'm not that worried with it. If I keep at this, I'll probably step up to a nice brush long before this one would deteriorate. I don't follow the directions on the box, but instead use some tips I read online... I grabbed an old coffee mug and dropped the soap in there and kept the bowl just for lather building. Run HOT water into the bowl/brush to get it all warm, add enough hot water to the soap to just cover the indented area. Squeeze out the brush and begin working it into the soap and get it really loaded up- takes me 30secs or so of plunging/swirling it on the soap. Then I empty the hot water from my bowl and begin working up a lather in it, adding just a trickle of hot water to it as needed (you'll have to experiment to see what works here). Once you get it how you want it- it takes me up to a minute to get a nice lather- apply it to your face using up/down strokes. Anyway, the set seems like a good value for the money- don't hesitate to try it for the price.
  655. I purchased from Rite-Aid my very own Van Der Hagen Shave Set today and could not wait to use it. WOW! I hate to say it but that boar brush felt better than my Art Of Shaving Pure Badger brush. It was strong and made a great lather with the soap it can with. Not to thick, but just the right amount on my face. The brush really made my face come alive with every swirl. And then I painted my face with the lether after that. The shave was done with my Parker 22R Butterfly Safety De razor and man did I get a close, clean shave that left my face feeling smooth, clean and refreshed. I don't beleive you have to spend a lot on getting something good. I like to try out new and inexpensive products and more times than few, they are better. I lost a few hairs from the brush, but so did my pure badger. But a ceramic hand dipped bowl, soap and brush for $9.99, come on...you can't beat that. This will remain in my wet shaving line up collection as a weekly product alone with my Taylor Of Old Bond Street cream, Art Of Shaving Cream, Williams Mug Soap and Col. Conk soap. I look at it like this, if the shoe fits, wear it. Once you go outside and people see the finished product(Your face) they won't know you used a $2.00 soap or a $5.00 brush. It's your own little secert.

  676. I started wet shaving with this set and an Edwin Jagger DE89LBL. The bowl is nice, the soap is nice and brush is ok... it's not too rough on your face. With all of that being said, the brush is a lot more effective at creating a lather with soaps as opposed to creams. Very easy to make a thick and very nice lather with soaps, but it takes quite a bit of time to get that same thick lather with shaving creams. I've tried to use it with Proraso shaving cream, Taylor of Old Bond Street, Art of Shaving shaving cream and it just takes forever to get a thick lather. I would recommend this set if you plan on staying with soaps, but if you wanna go with shaving creams, badger is the way to go.

  693. I've seen a few reviews on this product complaining about the plastic handle, the boars hair brush, and the bowl not having a handle. I was looking for a cheap set to travel with and there were enough positive reviews that I gave this one a shot. The plastic brush handle did not bother me in the least, in fact the actual brush has a lot more heft and is sturdier than it appears in the images. With proper care it should last you a long time. As for Boars hair vs. Badger hair, The boars hair feels just fine on my face and I didn't see that it hampers my ability to make a nice lather either. So if Boars hair makes the product more affordable then that is fine with me.<br /><br />This is the first time I used a bowl without a \\"mug\\" like handle, but after using it I think I actually prefer it to using a handle. I am a pretty ham handed guy so I get a more stable grip holding the bottom of the bowl than I do daintily holding by a handle. I can be a little more aggressive in working up a lather with this bowl without worrying about losing my grip and having both bowl and lather flying across my bathroom sink.<br /><br />This kit is a great value for the price and I would have given it 5 stars except I didn't care too much for the soap. It lathered up just fine, but I didn't care too much for the scent and was not as pleasant to shave with as some of the others I've tried, but that just a preference. If this is your first set and have nothing else to compare it to, this soap may be just fine.

  701. I purchased this when I got back into DE shaving and recently for two people who I bought DE shavers for as a gift. The mug is large and deep and the soap smells good. The brush is perfect for a beginner set, and with proper care, I can see lasting for a long time. The brush is a bit rough at first, but does get a little softer once broken in. I now use a softer, more expensive brush, but I use the one that came with this kit for road trips and when traveling, just in case I lose it or forget it. The only downside to this kit is that it tends to want the brush coated really well with soap before you can really get a great lather going, however, when switching to more expensive cream soaps, the technique you build with this kit makes the cream soaps much, much, much easier in building lather. For the unbeatable price, I recommend this kit as an excellent beginner kit or a great kit to carry on the road.

  717. This was the first set I tried when I got into brush shaving, and I still think it's great. Seriously, you could just stick with this set and not upgrade to all the expensive brands. It's also a little on the wide side, and I found out later that it won't fit into some brush holders (even the plastic one that comes in the VDH Luxury Set).<br /><br />Another note: I love the color of the bowl, although the outside is actually a really dark blue and not black. Last Father's Day I got my dad a vintage Gillette Super Speed as a memento.<br />I picked up this set at the supermarket as a last second addition just in case he wanted to use it.<br />Terrible brush.<br />I have a Van Der Hagen Luxury brush made of badger hair and borrowed this brush for a week to test it out.<br />Short story, Im glad he just kept the razor for show.<br /><br />I gave this brush every chance.<br />I washed it with shampoo to break it in, soaked it in hot water for 5min before use, and worked it in the bowl for several minutes.<br />I was able to work up a lather, but it was weak.<br />The soap stayed in the brush and was difficult to put on my face.<br />Once it was on my face, it dissipated quickly and wasn't very slick.<br /><br />As a comparison, I used the van der hagen badger brush and was able to quickly work up a much thicker, slicker, easier to apply lather after simply running hot water over the brush instead of soaking it.<br /><br />I giving the set 3 stars because the bowl and the soap are well worth $10.<br />The soap has a very mild pleasant scent and lathers well.<br />The bowl is ceramic, fits nicely in your non dominate hand, and holds heat well.

The brush isn't all that bad either. Yes, it is boar's hair, but it does a fine job and I personally don't find it to be all that rough. The soap is adequate--nothing special, but it gets the job done. The scent is nice, it lathers perfectly well, and it give a nice shaving experience.<br /><br />If you stick with wet shaving you will most likely upgrade your equipment down the line, but this is a great starting point.

It is what it is for the $10 I paid for it. The bowl is great, nice and small enough to fit easily in my medicine cabinet. 5 stars The VDH soap is wonderful, great lather and very comfortable shave with both a DS razor or Fusion. 4 stars The boars hair brush was TERRIBLE, at least mine was. I expected it to shed SOMEWHAT during the first few weeks I used it but the shedding did not stop ! I was pulling boar bristles of my face continuously with each shave. For this I give the brush ONE STAR. Enter Vanderhagen Enterprises who was fantastic and stepped up to the plate. I sent an email to their customer service department. I received a prompt response asking for my name and address so they could send me either a refund OR their better badger brush. I asked for the brush which I received. Although it is not part of this review, the badger brush is significantly better than the boar brush; and it doesn't shed.

  737. If like me you're looking to try out wet shaving without spending too much money, this is the kit for you. The brush: At the time I bought this, by brother bought a $10 wooden handled boar hair brush at the store. The Van Der Hagen has a plastic handle, but more bristles. My brother's brush has lost half its bristles in three months, whereas my Van Der Hagen brush barely sheds at all. It's not a badger hair brush, but it still whips up a decent lather. The bowl: A coffee mug would work, but the shaving soap fits perfectly, and the bowl fits well in the medicine cabinet. The soap: It is the only shaving soap I've ever used, but it is better than any canned shaving cream I've tried. It lathers great, but you need practice to do it right. Although some have complained about the smell, I find it mildly pleasant. I really can't see what the problem is. The soap also washes off the face very easily, even with cold water. If you're just trying out wet shaving for as low a price as possible to see if you like it, I recommend this kit, plus the Feather Popular safety razor, which shaves great. Together they only set you back about $30.
  738. Much better shave than using any shave cream I have tried. I feel like I am getting a better, smoother shave with less irritation. I saw Walmart sells the replacement soap cakes (same brand) as well for less than $2 so I can easily get more when needed.
  739. for the price, it's excellent. the bowl looks and feels nice, and the shaving soap has a pleasant yet nondescript smell, and lathers nicely. The only place where you see the cost coming into it is the brush. The handle is cheap plastic with visible mold lines, and every so often bristles come off it and stick to your face. it works to spread the soap though, so you get exactly what you pay for. excellent starter set so you know what you're looking for when you upgrade.

  752. I was a bit skeptical about the quality of this set, given how inexpensive it was. There are lots of shaving snobs out there, many of whom would turn their nose up at this item. I am very pleased with the quality of the soap block -- it lathers up beautifully and provides a much better shave than regular shaving cream. It's very low odor and not laden with artificial scent. The bowl is heavy and feels durable. The brush is supple and applies the lather beautifully. I am a novice and don't know what to expect with brush shedding, but after a few weeks of use, the brush does leave behind a few hairs during every application of lather. Not a deal breaker, but the reason it didn't get 5 stars. If all brushes do this, then my fault for not knowing that yet. Overall, an awesome buy for the money. If you haven't tried a more traditional shaving kit yet, I'd strongly suggest it.

  758. This set was a great intro to using a brush with soap. The bowl will last a long time. It's attractive, deep and easy to use without making a mess. The soap is great quality and it's not perfumed.I like unscented products and this soap does not bother me. The bowl and soap are of good quality and I have saved a great deal of money not buying shaving cream ! A bar of shave soap for me lasts a pretty long time. I use just enough water to make the lather foam. Too much and it's not as rich. I believe the brush exfoliates my skin well in preparation for shaving so the razor does not get caught on a stray dead skin cells. I like shaving prep with this brush but it has not been durable. Granted I have not been prissy with it. I make new lather on the remnants of yesterday's which might not be the best idea. It is probably bad to leave the brush in the bowl on top of the wet soap instead of drying it out. Maybe that is why it's gradually falling apart? The boar bristles are held together by a block of resin and that is set in the plastic handle. It fell out of the handle after a few months and I like using it so much that I have used the bristles in the block of resin without the handle for a few months more, but now the bristles are shedding. They shed a bit in the beginning and once and a while but now they shed every time i shave so it's time to get a new one. I am going to try a nicer brush in hope that they are more rugged and maybe I will research if I did something wrong. This is the second boars bristle brush from CVS that has fallen apart so that is why I am on Amazon. I hope I find something that will last 3+ years without extra steps. Is this overly exuberant middle aged optimism? Maybe. If the Badger Hair brushes are not any more durable I'll probably go back to using one of these since it's cheap.

  785. Been shaving for years, and for my money, best soap around. I've tried creams that come out of a tube, like Neutrogena, canned shaving gels and foams, and even Caswell-Massey almond cream out of a jar, with a touch of benzocaine to slightly numb the skin. And none of them even come close to the Van De Hagen soaps. My brush is holding up wonderfully, the bowl/mug is..well...it's a bowl. But it is the soap that you're going to rave about.<br /><br />I set aside a small pitcher of water and microwave it for about one and a half minutes to get the water just hot enough for a nice, warm rich lather. I wash my face with a good soap and rinse with lots of hot water, and then whip up a rich later with the Van Der Hagen soap. I use a Gillette Mach whatever ...I think they're up to 116 blades now...one with the little AAA battery to make it wiggle and shake alike an electric toothbrush. And with the skin softeners in the soap, best shave in the US. Even the local barber can't touch it. If you already love your brush and mug, go for the soap. Highly recommend.<br /><br />[[ASIN:B001A3FLF0 Van Der Hagen Select Shave Soap, 2.5-Ounce Boxes (Pack of 12)]]

Kinda hard to find these type of supplies at the local store anymore.The soap and bowl was just a bonus since I had shave creme already and a simple coffee mug would do just fine for making shave creme. But on to the review. I've been using the brush for a week now and I find it to work just fine. It has shed a few hairs but nothing like some other reviews have posted. So I guess that the quality is going to vary. I suppose I'm not picky but a handle is a handle. As long as i can grip it and it doesn't bite me it's ok. The bowl is nice but I have found at least for me that holding it in the palm of my hand or on the counter while mixing shave creme is somewhat difficult without a handle. So the 1 star deduction is for no handle on the bowl. I'm sure for others it's no big deal. I certainly wouldn't not buy it because of this. I use the bowl to soak my brush in hot water prior to shaving. The soap works well also. doesn't lather up as nice as I had expected but has a subtle smell that is nice but not over powering. so for anyone starting into wet shaving but is on a budget I would definitely recommend this.   793. Simply put, for a man there is no luxury that can be better had at this price point than this.   795. I'm new to the \\"wet-shaving\\" scene. I didn't want to drop a lot into something I might not like. I knew I could handle the shaving part, but I was unsure if I wanted to actually build my own lather or use the foam in a can. I picked this up for $10, and considering a decent non-plastic bowl will run you $5, I feel it was well worth it.<br /><br />Method<br />------<br />It took me about three times using it to really get the hang of building the lather. It's just something you have to get a feel for and no amount of reading will make it easier. You get the hang of how much water the brush needs, how much soap to build on the bristles, how much pressure to place on the brush, the angle to hold the brush, and the speed to whip. Considering the soap will last forever and it's cheap to replace I would recommend practice building lather a few times till you get the hang of it.<br /><br />I let the brush soak in hot water for 5 min, shake off the excess water, dip the end in warm water, swirl on the soap, and build lather in my bowl.<br /><br />Soap<br />-----<br />The soap that's included works well. It lathers up fine and has an ok smell. It just smells like..well soap to be honest. It smells like something I would wash my hands with. This is actually fine for me as I like fresh/clean smell.<br /><br />Brush<br />-----<br />I was hesitant after my purchase as I had read that boar hair was horrible and this brush would be useless. I seem to have no problems building lather, so if this is what a \\"useless, poor lather\\" is like I would really hate to see \\"luxurious\\" lather as mine came out as thick as any can cream I have used.<br /><br />Bowl<br />----<br />The bowl feels like it's a good solid product. Perfect size for lather building in my opinion. I used a coffee mug to throw my soap in instead of leaving it in the plastic package.<br /><br />Conclusion<br />----------<br />For $10 I think this was a good buy. If you're starting wet-shaving I would recommend this product. There is no point in spending a nice bit of money on more expensive products to find out wet-shaving or lather building aren't for you. You might end up loving the wet-shave, but decide to just use the canned cream/gel (which still work fine).

  807. I got this for my nineteenth birthday and now I use this about everyday. This shave soap lathers incredibly well and the bowl is very nice. The boar brush is actually quite nice and although many will tell you it is nothing like a badger, many members of a certain shaving forum have stated that after the bristles soften the difference is barely there, if at all. It has become an extremely soft and comfortable brush, and just feels nice to use. It is also extremely fun knowing I am doing something that my grandfathers did. It takes a little bit of time to lather up, but unless a minute or two is too long for you it's completely worth it. The soap also smells quite nice, although it took me some time to get used to. I often add Barbasol Arctic Chill (for the menthol) and the Sensitive Skin formula (for the ingredients) and I find the lather is just as good. I highly recommend this product, and better yet, it can be found at pretty much any drugstore or Wal-Mart!

It's a cheap brush okay, don't treat it like a 100 one, you'll end up crushing the thing.<br />Soap is okay. Smells okay. It's okay, okay?<br /><br />Cons:<br />The bowl, from my experience, becomes next to absolutely useless. Not the fault of the bowl (who blames bowls?) but because the soap comes in a handy little plastic 'bowl' thing. You wet the bar of soap, spin the brush around, and you have lather.... why did we need a bowl again?<br /><br />The brush is cheap. Strands will come off and piss you off in the middle of your shave. At this moment you will SHOUT AT THE TOP OF YOUR LUNGS, FROTHING FROM THE MOUTH as you go to write your amazon review BUT WAIT... you can pick the strands off your face and continue to shave.. you big baby.<br /><br />Conclusion:<br />It's not premium. It's not amazing. It does NOT suck.<br />Oh boo hoo, you've bought a cheap shaving set now all your friends will laugh at you, and all those dweebs on the shaving forums will laugh at your unwillingness to throw down serious cash for a titanium straight razor with diamonds and soap made from the congealed mists of Mount Olympus itself.<br /><br />NO. This shaving set WORKS. It's spartan, it's cheap, but it WORKS.<br /><br />Welcome to wet shaving.
  809. My first cake of soap lasted about six months. That is far longer than any shave cream or soap I've used. My second cake will exceed the first one. The bowl and brush are nice. I've now used the brush daily for nearly a year and it's still working great. Given the cost of some brushes, this one is a bargain, and it works great.
  810. I like this much better than the shaving cream I used to use on my husband. I swear it makes his skin softer. He's bedridden and using the shaving cream got all over him no matter what I did to stop it. Now I just put it where I want it, and boom, no more foam all over the place. After using it a few times I notice his skin felt softer, and I'm really pleased with how wonderful it is to use something that actually works well. The brush is soft, but firm enough to go where you want it, and the bowl doesn't take up a huge space either. The soap is doing something good, cause he gets a much better shave now, and part of that is from this product, I'm sure.
  811. I have very sensitive skin. I decided to start shaving every day because of my job. I ended-up with severe razor burn and a huge rash. I tried switching between Schick, Gillette, and Dorco, but I didn't find any real difference. After doing some research, I found that the real problem was likely the shaving cream I was using. I found this kit at the grocery store. Since I started using it, the razor burn has been reduced by 90%. The aftershave lotion I bought takes care of the last 10%. Shaving is almost fun. It's a Boar's hair brush instead of Badger. Who cares?? Swirling a brush around a bar of soap to make thick bubbles is not rocket science. I haven't had any Boar's hair injuries as far as I know. Perhaps a badger hair brush would be better, but I haven't found a reason to complain about this one yet. The bowl is pretty useless. The brush actually does a great job of building a lather on its own, despite being boar's hair. Maybe I'll wash the bowl out and use it for Cheerios in the morning. The soap is AWESOME! It gives me a good lather and leaves my face silky smooth without making me smell like Old Spice aftershave. It basically leaves me burn-free. Bottom line -- This is a great shave set for people who want something different. In my opinion, the upscale &#34;luxury&#34; sets are highly overrated. You're going to come out with a hairless face either way. I haven't had a single co-worker laugh at me because I use Boar instead of Badger. Even if I told them, they wouldn't care. Believe me, it's a heck of a lot better than the blue goo I used to slather on my face. Update to my previous post: The plug on the shaving brush fell out after using it for three months. The soap and the bowl is really good, but the soap is $1.67 and well...it's just a stupid bowl. All in all it's really a cheap set. If you're new to wet shaving, I would skip this and spring for a good badger brush and some good soap or cream.
  812. I bought this set as a gift for my husband. I just wanted a cheap kit for him so he could see if he liked using a badger brush instead of canned shaving cream, and I was happy with this purchase. The brush lost some hairs but I mean, you get what you pay for, it's still going strong after about 2 months and he uses it almost daily. I REALLY like this soap, it smells wonderful. Very light, fresh and clean. It doesn't lather like I expected but it does the job (maybe we're doing it wrong, like I said, we're noobs). I accidentally broke the bowl, which is depressing because the bowl was actually really great. I'll probably buy a different, higher quality badger brush when this one craps out, but it was a great starter kit.
  813. I like the soap and bowl but the brush is lacking. But, I got what I paid for.
  814. You need to keep in mind that this is pretty much an economy shaving set. The soap and mug are okay though I don't really have anything to compare to. The brush is pretty stiff and I don't think it is probably as good as the old badger hair one I bought 20 years ago. That said, the set does its job and I am perfectly happy with the quality for the buck.
  815. The brush and the bowl are great. The shaving cream is ok but not the best. Could just be my skin being sensitive but it was a little rough of a shave with it.
  816. This thing is great! The lather is perfect, the soap is comfortable, the cup is good. If you are considering taking the plunge into shaving with straight razor, I highly recommend starting with this. Its a good place to get your feet wet without spending too much money. I promise you will be impressed!
  817. This is a great starter set for straight edge shaving. Very nice soap dish, quality brush, and okay soap. If you want to do an upgrade, buy some aloe soap to replace the soap in the kit. I didn't find this necessary, but I don't have sensitive skin.
  818. I like this starter set. great bowl. and good starter boar brush. I don't care for the soap but it will do for now till I get something else.

  820. Overall all it'll do. By mistake I ordered 2 sets and will use the next bar of shave soap.   826. It has been nice to get a really god shave again! I decided to start using a 40+ year old double edge razor again that my dad gave me many moons ago. I had forgotten how superior a quality single edge blade is to all these fancy and expensive multi-blade razors in use nowadays. The soap smells great, lasts forever and the cup and brush are perfect! I actually enjoy shaving now! No kidding!
  827. After trying electric razors for a couple of years to try to combat the rising cost of replacement blades, I gave up, I just didn't like it, and electrics gave me worse razor burn than a dull disposable blade. I decided to try to make the switch to wet shaving with a double edged safety razor, and picked this up as a cheap starting point to go with a more expensive, higher quality razor. The soap is ok, the brush lost some bristles the first few times, but that's to be expected, and the soap bowl is perfectly usable. I can see myself eventually replacing the brush, and buying better soap when this runs out, but for starters, it's a good deal.

  841. I got this when I started DE shaving, and it helped me see what I wanted in my next kit.<br /><br />BRUSH: Not bad at all for a starter brush. It's boar bristle which I don't mind. It can make and apply a good lather for sure. I'm still using it.<br /><br />BOWL: Small and slippery. I immediately replaced this with a sturdy mug, because I dropped this almost every day. When it gets wet and soapy, it slips from my hands like a greased watermelon seed.<br /><br />SOAP: Very ok. Not good, not bad, just middle of the road soap. It doesn't smell very good, and it takes some work to make a lather from it. I have since experimented with other soaps and found some I like much better.<br /><br />OVERALL: Good for the price, and if you are not 100% sold on more advanced shaving techniques and the time they take. It's a safe jump. But right off the bat, read up on it more, spend a little bit more and get a sturdy kit that you can use forever.

  875. Used every day. Since switching I've saved over $200 in the last year alone. The soap in this set is very smooth and allows for a even closer shave with less irratation than conventional canned gels, and the brush is fantastic. For an entry level setup this is a fantastic way to get into the safety razors shave system. Very easy way to feel a little &#34;taken care of&#34; or even mildly &#34;pampered&#34; each morning.

But anyway the the brush does work pretty good. And the bowl is great also. To get the soap in the bowl is simply lather the soap in the package and let it set for a few. And the take the soap out and press it gently in the bowl. Dont try to smash the soap lol. With the bottom of the wet it will stick in the bowl like glue and will not move untill its gone.
  878. I bought this kit almost two years ago when I switched to shaving with a safety razor. It was cheap and came with everything I needed so I figured why not. The bowl is probably my favorite part. I had another one for the soap so I used this bowl to lather it up. It is perfect size to fit in your hand comfortably and retains heat nicely. It is a little small for larger brushes but will still get the job down. I would recommend this to anyone who is starting out or wants a cheap way to get a nice puck of soap and good lathering bowl.

  899. This is the exact shave set I see on the shelves of CVS and Walgreens. I purchased this as a gift for someone who wanted to try &#34;old school&#34; brush shaving. The first shipment arrived with the bowl broken and had to be replaced. The replacement set I received was fine. For the price, and for someone who just wants to take the brush shaving soap ritual out for a test drive this set is a good choice. For someone who is going to use shaving soap on a daily basis I suggest they consider going with a shaving mug with a handle. This set has a bowl, and the bowl is typically held in one hand while lathering with the other. Soap is slippery by design, so it doesn't take much of an imagination to see how this no handle bowl could slip out of a hand and break on the vanity or bathroom floor. After all, there's a reason shampoo bottles are no longer glass and glass bottles aren't allowed poolside.

  909. I bought this becuase I decided not to support the manufacturing and distrobution of shaving cream cans. I went to soap for environmental reasons. I also did it for sentimental reasons, remembering my grandfather's shaving kit. I love the soap, I'm thinking I'll go with a different brush, but I really like this way of lathering my face.   912. This is a very good set for the price.<br />The bowl is of perfect size for the soap which comes with it or most other round shaving soaps.<br />The soap can provide a rich lather with about 15-20 rotation of the brush, and it smells fine.<br />I don't think the brush is 100% boar as the box indicates. It looks like some of the bristles in the center are synthetic (nylon). The few bristles which fell out from the center of the brush didn't look like natural hair, and they looked more like nylon.<br />During the first use, it lost about 15 bristles. I don't know how it is going to hold over time. It is a larger brush and it is stiff as most boar and synthetics are. I do prefer stiffer brushes, and badger brushes are too soft for me. So, I do like this brush.<br />Handel is 52mm (2in), and bristle part from base to tip is = 53mm (2-1/8in) long.
  913. Brush is stiff worked good on the soap. Bowl worked ok. The problem I have is the sodium laurel<br />sulfate.missed that when I ordered, causes skin irritations.

  925. I gave this 5 stars because it is excellent for its purpose; to get you STARTED with wet shaving. I wouldn't recommend the brush as a quality shave brush but it will get the job done until you decide if you enjoy wet shaving enough to invest some money in it. I bought it at Walmart to try out the whole wet shaving thing and I have no regrets.<br /><br />That being said, the soap is actually pretty decent. You can get a great lather with it and I would put it up there with just about any glycerin shave soaps. The bowl is great, a bit narrow for my taste but it does it's job and looks pretty great while doing it. The brush is somewhat coarse and it loses a hair or 2 every use but what do you expect for an 8 dollar Walmart Special?<br /><br />All in all, this is NOT the best bowl, brush, and soap you can find but it IS the best starter kit for someone curious about wet shaving or even someone who wants to experience it but can't afford to invest in it as a hobby. I see no problem with someone using this kit until the brush wears out, you'll get a great lather from it.

  932. I recently started wet shaving with a safety razor. I started off using the same routine as I did with my old Gillette Mach 3. I was very happy with the results as it looks like I will finally be rid of razor burn for good. Simply moving to the safety razor fixed that. Anyway, back to the review of VDH kit. I was originally going to spend $20 to $40 on a badger brush and some very reputable shaving soap or cream. However, I decided to try this kit first. Since I keep reading that badger is so much better than boar bristle, I wanted to experience boar bristle myself so if I ever go to badger, I can form my own opinion. This kit comes with a 100% boar bristle brush. I brought it home, took the brush out and let it soak in hot water for a while. Then I washed the brush with dish soap (Dawn) and let it soak in that for a while, then rinsed clean. I then did two practice rounds of working up a lather using the soap, bowl and brush since I had never done it before. This stuff really lathered up great (I got my technique from badgerandblade.com). The next day I used it for the first time with my shave. After lathering it up, the brush had enough lather for 3 passes (lathering my face each time) with plenty left if I wanted to do another pass. The soap really provides a good lubrication and the smell is faint. I use a cold splash of water on my face after the shave, followed by some Neutrogena Mens Post Shave Lotion. Nice shave.
  933. I purchased this product because I recently started shaving with a double edge razor. If you are under a budget then this product is worth purchasing. You can buy this at RiteAid and I have seen it at Brookshires grocrey store also for $10. I bought this product for the brush. It is functional and lathers well. It is not as good as my Omega Badger Hair brush, but for the price it works fine. I have not tried the soap yet, I currently use C.O. Bigelow shaving cream and have been using it for years, it is awesome. I would recommend this product if your are new to wet shaving or on a budget. For about $25 you can get a nice badger brush that will last years.

  940. This product was a nice choice for a first experience using a brush and bowl. I haven't tried the soap bar yet, the first time will be today; because I've been using Dr. Bronner's peppermint shave gel which works excellent. I had to learn to use these 2 together to make enough foam; experiment, if you will? Firstly, I would squeeze about a teaspoon or less of Dr. Bronners' gel into the bowl. Then, I would run really hot water on the brush, shake excess water out, then stir both clockwise and ccw, use a twisting motion, then something like a jackhammer...more than enough shave foam made. I noticed 0 out of 1 thought this review was helpful....well; la dee da! Perhaps I focused too much on how I'm using the product rather than the quality or features of it. Anyways, it's not rocket science...it's a brush; a bowl and a bar of shaving soap. Been using for a few months and I think it's great, the brush is holding up well and the soap isn't too bad. Peace out bro.

  959. For those of you who have been shaving with a double edge \\"safety razor\\" for years and bought this because it was one hell of a deal... you should have known better. Is this a top of the line set? No, but for the cheap price it shouldn't be. This set is great for beginners. I own this set myself and still use all but the soap everytime I shave. It work just fine. Don't be a snob! Here is what is included:<br /><br />-Shaving soap: works fine, just not my style.<br />-BOAR hair brush: notice I said boar, not badger. It is not as soft, and does shed a bit. Bottom line is it still lathers up good and applies the lather.<br />-Shave Bowl: Made of ceramic, works great!<br /><br />As stated before this is a beginners kit, it is a great cheap kit for figuring stuff out, and getting your routine down. I still use the brush and bowl. I do not use the soap as it dries our my skin. I use Proraso Shave Cream instead (its amazing!) Someday I may upgrade to a badger brush, but this one still works good. At the end of the day with this kit I can build a lather, apply the lather, and get a close shave... what else is there?!? Here are some TIPS to prolong your kit.<br /><br />1) Do not stand your brush on end using the handle while letting it dry! This will allow water to seep into the handle thus shortening the life span of the bristles. Invest in a holder to allow your brush to dry bristles down. This is the number one mistake made my new shavers.<br /><br />2) If the soap does not work for you, try PRORASO Shave Cream (Menthol). It costs about $10-15 per 5.2 oz tube, but all you need is a dime sized drop in your bowl and you can lather up that face all morning long! A tube will last me all year long! It lathers up well with this brush.<br /><br />3) When done shaving, rinse your brush, and squeeze all the extra water out from the brush! Again, dry in a stand with bristles down!<br /><br />4) Enjoy your shave! In my opinion there is no better way to start my day than with a goodclean close shave.
  960. This is a very nice set, especially considering the price point. Would definitely purchase again. The brush may seem like it could be smoother and nicer but Im not complaining for $10. Probably will buy a nicer brush in the future now that I know I will be sticking with this style of shaving. All in all, a good trial set if you are just looking for something to try out.

  968. This kit started me on my quest for the perfect shave. The soap surprisingly is much better than other discount soaps. Qualities of the soap that I find important are in this price range there are few soaps that lubricate as well as this, and work into a rich lather as well either. I am not a lover of the scent but I don't hate it either.<br /><br />I have badger brushes and this boars brush and I can honestly say that Boars brush offers a different shaving property than badger. Boars brush you soak before you shave as the hair of a boar is similar to human hair... It absorbs water. Lathers differently than my badger brush with more water in the brush. Boars bristles are bit more stiff than badger but whether one is better than the other is purely speculative. I have heard that there are hybrid brushes that use the properties of both and some people like. Perhaps that will be next on my list.<br /><br />Bowl is decent no frills bowl. I do not lather in a bowl anyway and prefer to lather in my hand, but honestly usually I just froth up the lather directly on my face. I do not like looks of the bowl.<br /><br />But for a decent soap, a decent brush one can tolerate the ugly bowl :)

The dish and soap are wonderful, the brush has a tendency to shed, and am constantly pulling the bristles out of the soap. I ended up putting a little bit of water in the dish and soap and putting it in the microwave to melt it into the dish. It prevents the soap from just spinning in the dish when making lather.   997. The boar-bristle brush hard-wearing, but doesn't really give you a good lather. I got the best results as follows: Wash your face with warm (not hot) water and leave it wet. If you have hard water, soak the brush with cold/room temperature water and set the bristles to drip into the sink. If you have soft/distilled water, you can use warm/hot water more effectively. rather than cutting pieces of the soap into the dish like most tutorials will tell you, take the brick of soap out of the plastic and put it in the mug it will stick in place after a few uses. After ~ 30 seconds, or the brush stops dripping, swirl the tips (ONLY the tips) of the bristles on the surface of the soap until they are coated with soap. Then, swirl the brush on your wet skin where it will lather, and use the brush to spread the lather.<br /><br />The soap included with the kit has this weird fat smell that I never liked, but it is very moisturizing. Muhle makes a soap with a scent that I like much better.
  998. Great price for the set. Bowl fits nicely in hand. The bowl is ceramic.
  999. A great set. The bowl and the brush are surprisingly high quality for the price. The soap itself is nice too. Not much else to say really.
  1000. Very nice to get started with; I'm please with how smooth of a shave I get with this set.
  1001. awesome material to make material. 5 stars
  1002. Brush smells bad and lots of bristle loss each time I have used the brush. I do really like the cup -- good size, nice look and feel to it. I also like that it has no handle, which always seemed silly to me for shaving cups / bowls to have handles like a coffee mug. Probably would not buy again due to the brush, but if the cup broke, I might be tempted to buy another and throw out the brush.
  1003. I bought this to go with my new straight edge that I got recently. There's just something amazing from using soap and a brush instead of using goop in a can. It left my face smooth and soft, not irritated like every shaving cream I've ever used. The brush itself, made of Boar, is sturdy feeling, despite losing a bristle or two already (probably because I pulled on them.) All in all this stuff works, gives an amazing lather, and leaves your face feeling amazing. 5/5
  1004. does the job, nothing special. came on time and as advertised.
  1005. No rich lather for soap. Brush quality poor.
  1006. Works well arrived on time
  1007. Thus was a price too good to pass up, special sale of 7$ I think so I jumped on it.<br />It us getting harder to find a good shave soap, so if it comes in a set I usually purchase the whole thing.

  1011. I have been using this for a bit over a month now. Here's what i've noticed:<br /><br />The brush sheds. I thought after reading many reviews for this kit and for other, better brushes that the shedding would eventually stop. Still to this day, some 10-15 shaves later, it's still shedding between 2-5 hairs a shave.<br /><br />The soap lathers alright and is okay, but after one use I decided to put it on the shelf as a backup and use my Col. Conk's Bay Rum shaving soap instead. It smelled better and had great reviews. I bought it at the same time.<br /><br />The dish is perfect sized for both the shaving soap that came with the kit and the Bay Rum one I also purchased at the same time. I guess it's a fairly universal size. Nothing good nor bad to say about it really. I'll be upgrading to a wooden dish soon, but that's just to match the stand I bought and the brush I am about to buy.<br /><br />Overall, it works but it's nothing fancy. Slowly, you'll likely find yourself upgrading these items one by one until these are just sitting on your shelf as a back-up kit. Great way to start off if you're unsure about wet shaving though, as this kit is much much cheaper than many semi-decent brushes on the market alone. Heck, just my wooden stand cost over double what I paid for the kit! If I did this again, I might have bought their &#34;premium kit&#34; though as it looks to be a bit higher quality than this is.
  1012. Bought this as a first kit for moving to wet shaving. I can see upgrading bits in the future (badger brush instead of boar, different soap, etc). But as an initial foray into wet shaving, this is a great place to start
  1013. I have been disappointed in the brush as it continues to lose hairs even after two months of use. The brush is also fairly stiff. For the price this set works, but there is better available. I will be looking for a different brush.
  1014. I've been very happy with this set. The soap has lasted me 6 months and only costs $1 to replace. My only complaint is the brush. The head has come out of the handle once. I was able to easily fix it with just a hot glue gun and it has lasted nearly a year now. I have no experience with other soaps or creams other than the typical aerosol shave creams. This is by far better than any of those. Had it not been for the brush, I would have given it 5 stars.

  1017. Shaving with soap and a brush is coming back, as many men are finding it offers a better shave over gel or canned foam. It also offers better value - I first began using soap and a brush when I was in a tight financial bind, and you can find a number of inexpensive products such as this one.<br /><br />The Brush - It's boar, not plastic or badger hair. This means it is better able to handle the punishment of a new user, but it still needs to be allowed to dry out. I am using this to build up the habits needed to use a badger brush now that I can afford one.<br /><br />The Soap - VDH soap is reliable and foams up nicely after some rubbing with the brush. Nothing fancy, but a good product for the price.<br /><br />The Bowl - It's a ceramic bowl. It does the job just fine, even if you decide to use a cream instead of the soap. Avoids accidentally using the shave bowl for cereal.

  1030. I bought this kit 5 months ago and I am still in love with it.<br /><br />I never liked the idea of paying so much for the shaving gels in a can that you go through so fast. With this I am still on my first bar of soap shaving 2-3 times a week and have barely made a dent. Originally I bought an extra bar not knowing how long/how fast I would go through them but I am set for a VERY long time with just the two bars. On a side note my wife loves the smell after I shave and the only other product I use is a splash of witch hazel to close the pores.<br /><br />On the brush side yes I do get an occasional bristle coming off the brush but that is expected with any brush. I love the feel of lathering up and could never think of going back to the gels.<br /><br />With the shaving soap I have tried a few different razors and I have gotten the best results from a single blade. I don't have the old school double edge razor yet, but I'm talking about the very cheap single blade razors you get 12 for 5 bucks. I have tried this with a Gillette 4 blade and it was just painful. The Gillette just rips out the hair, but even with the cheap drug store single blade razor I get a very close shave and a very enjoyable experience.<br /><br />This was an excellent product starting me on my life to great shaving.
