  1060. This was purchased for my son. He absolutely loves it. Wants to order another one for next 1 he bus.
  1061. If you are just starting out, this is a perfect kit, the soap isn't bad, nothing particularly special, but definitely not bad. the bowl is.... a bowl. so... not a lot can go wrong there... since... its a bowl. the brush is boars hair, a boar is a pig. pigs, can smell unpleasant, and it doesn't hold heat as well as badger, however, a good silvertip badger brush can run $60+. the brush has a good spine (stiffness) and creates very good lather, when using the soap its best to pre warm the bowl with water as hot as you can stand, then drain and hit it with fresh hot water after it warms up, then drain and get at it with the brush, heat a water are the main ingredient of lather, don't ram the brush into your skin. light circular and sweeping motions is all you need. when done, rinse thoroughly with cold water, then either hang it upside down, or do what i do and use the old lady's hair dryer to completely dry it out. i bought this kit a month ago and use the brush every. single. day. yes, it did shed at first, all brushes do. if you care for it properly it will stop for the most part, a hair or two every now and then is totally normal, and even if this brush only lasts a month or two and you get a good feel for it, buy a better one. its $9, not a lot can go wrong. you wont regret it.
  1062. Bowl - OK<br />Soap - OK<br />Brush - not so good.<br />After a week of use, it's still shedding hairs, which always seem to end up in my mouth or caught in the blade.<br />I guess eventually the shedding will stop... or I will be left with a brushless handle but I'm a little disappointed in this product and will now have to purchase another brush from a different manufacturer.
  1063. First time &#34;wet&#34; shaver so no basis for comparison. Bought this alternatively from piecing together mid-high end brush/soap/bowl. Pleasantly light fragrance that doesn't linger long (which I prefer) and IMHO doesn't smell &#34;girly&#34; or &#34;manly&#34; AT ALL, just more of a clean soapy smell. I also like the boars hair brush, but I've never used a badger haired brush to compare. After some trial and error with the lathering process, I've found a solid system for this product that works for me: Soak the brush in the bowl with hot tap water. Also add enough hot water to cover the top of the soap cake...this will allow for quicker brush loading. Do all of this before showering if possible or at least 3 minutes prior to lathering. Dump bowl water and shake out brush 1-2 times, so just a small amount of water stays in the brush. Brush load at least 30-45+ seconds and lather in the bowl 1-2 minutes, adding a few drops of water AS NEEDED. Remember, you want a THICK and SILKY lather. Too much water will make it flat and loose. Happy shaving mates :)
  1064. Love this product. Met all my expectations and makes a wonderful Christmas gift for the men who use razors.<br />Would highly recommend.
  1065. Another great starter item for people just getting going with safety razor shaving. I picked this up because of the price and great reviews. Was just starting out, and wasn't ready to commit to a nicer brush or more expensive soap. I've since moved on to badger brush from Art of Shaving and the Proraso's Sensitive soap, but still use the brush/soap from this kit when I travel.<br /><br />I actually like the soap from this set better than the Art of Shaving soap I tried. It's generally thinner and smoother, and doesn't cause much (if any) build up on the razor. The smell is clean and ever-so-slight, and it certainly doesn't leave my skin feeling dry.<br /><br />As far as the brush, I definitely noticed a difference when I switched to Badger, but this is a mighty fine brush to start with, and more than gets the job done both in terms of exfoliating and creating a nice lather.<br /><br />I don't really use a bowl when I shave (just lather against the cup of soap) but I will say it's a pretty nice, durable ceramic bowl...not something I expect would break easily.

  1107. I am a rather new proponent to wet-shaving. I have used a few shaving soaps, creams, brushes, DE safety razors, and blades. I purchased this product on a Navy base for $9.99 and it is a nice little startup arrangement for any new proponent to wet-shaving. I chose this review because for the price you cannot get all three of these items cheaper individually. It comes with a bowl, a boar hair brush, and a puck of soap.<br /><br /> -THE BRUSH: remember, I am new to wet shaving so I haven't used the best but in my opinion, the brush does an excellent job of creating lather from the puck of soap. At first, the brush comes out of the box with a slight odor (I'm assuming boar) but is easily removed by the third mixture of lather. The bristles appear to be made from what is claimed, boar hair and they are somewhat stiff at first which is better for lathering soaps compared to creams. Plastic handle, feels nice and heavy in your hand, it is a dark nay blue handle. I have large hands and the brush handle fits well in my hands so that my fingers don’t touch the rim of the bowl.<br /><br /> -THE BOWL: In my opinion, the bowl is a little small for my comfort and experience thus far. I found it difficult to whip the lather like I usually do with my larger mugs and bowls. Having said that, it does the job of a bowl for mixing lather. It retains heat okay and compliments the brush it comes with.<br /><br /> -THE SOAP: this soap was very easy to make lather from. It comes inside a small plastic container with a very tight fitting lid so after use you can close it and store it. The fragrance is very mild for a man, nothing like sandalwood or proraso shave soap. It isn't a lasting fragrance so it is easily washed away. It is actually a pinkish color compared to the picture.
  1108. This product is much better than your standard canned shaving cream or gel. It is easy to use and comfortable on your face. I can see upgrading to a different brush when the one in this set wears out. Everything I have read says the badger hair brushes are better than boars hair, which this set had. Ultimately, I have no complaints about this set.
  1109. you can get it at the grocery store for $8 the bowl is decent, the brush does not last long, and the soap is incredible. i am considering buying the same company's luxury shave set ( the orange box)
  1110. Found this basic shave set. I have used the soap included in this set previously when traveling and carrying on my luggage. I like the scent and the lather creates a good lubricant for shaving. This set added a bowl and brush. Wanted to change up my shaving regimen and bring a little old-school flair without spending lots of money and this is a good start.<br /><br />Kit came quickly - thanks Amazon! Bowl is nice, not fancy, which works for me. Brush has plastic handle and boar hair. Supposedly nicer shaving brushes will have wood or exotic material handle and badger hair. The boar hair works and the plastic handle feels fine in my hand. Holds sufficient moisture to create a decent lather, which is the point of the brush. It also feels OK on my face. Feels like it's exfoliating a bit and lifting the beard hair, again as it should.<br /><br />I also ordered a double-sided safety razor but that is coming from overseas, so the full shaving experience will have to wait. In the meantime, I'm enjoying my new shave kit that didn't cost me a fortune and a half.
  1111. I purchased this item a couple of times because it was the only saving kit available in local shops. The bowl is poorly designed since is allows the soap no place to affix itself to the bottom and thus turns most times when you try to work up a lather. The brush is substandard and falls apart within about one year. I repaired the first one, and it disintegrated totally a few months later. I already repaired the second one, and it is still holding up two months later. Truly, the brushes are poorly constructed. the shaving soap itself is okay.
  1112. Great lather! I would buy again
  1113. I got this kit to dip my toe into brush shaving. Here's how I would sum up this kit:<br /><br />- The brush is not good. The bristles fall off every time I shave. I have already replaced the brush after only 10-15 shaves.<br />- The soap is okay but not great. It lathers decently. There is no aroma.<br />- The bowl is the best part of the kit. Its a nice size and looks good on the bathroom counter.
  1114. Overall all this is a great starter kit for any gent looking to get a set at a cheap price. The soap lathers fairly good and has a good smell to it. The brush is stiff at the beginning and will do a fairly good job. Give it at least two weeks of consistent use to break in the brush and you will see and feel a difference. Overall i would recommend this shave set any gent starting with DE razors.
  1115. For men sick of the chemical tang to shaving cream and the discomfort and cost of disposable blades, the Van Der Hagen shave set makes an excellent introduction to shaving the old-fashioned wet lather method our fathers and grandfathers preferred. While technological improvements sometimes save time and effort, shaving is one arena where older is better in my opinion.<br /><br />The three piece set includes a handsome green-glazed bowl, a puck of shaving soap, and a boar-hair brush with a solid plastic handle. Add one razor with good cartridges and you are set to go. Even disposable razors can be used, though the effect may not be as ideal. The complete kit is its main selling point, and at this low price, it makes an outstanding gift for someone considering making the transition. It can also make a good back-up or travel set, particularly for students living in dorms or a businessman who wants to leave his more expensive alternatives at home.<br /><br />I recommend replacing the shaving soap with [[ASIN:B004XC75D6 Colonel Conk Glycerin Shave Soap Bay Rum (106g)]], which boasts a much better lather, fresher fragrance, and longer lasting soap. I was not impressed by the Van der Hagen option. The puck whips up a reasonable lather and the smell isn't bad, but bay rum wins hands down for me any day. My fiance's skin felt much softer and the shave looked easier. But to each, their own, and a man can never have too much shaving soap as far as I'm concerned.<br /><br />The boar brush is considered a step below badger hair by connoisseurs, but for a foray into wet shaving, it works perfectly well. Most important is a shaving stand to allow the brush to dry between uses after being properly rinsed and cleaned. This kit does not include a stand, but excellent chrome options are available that fit just fine. The plastic handle is durable and comfortable for use, and resists cracking, scratches, and occasional nicks. After two years of use, my brother's brush looked pretty good.<br /><br />This set couldn't be better priced to get started and allows the timely replacement of components once personal preferences are discovered. The results of a good shave speak for themselves, and the Van der Hagen set will help you achieve that..<br /><br />This set couldn't be better priced to get started and allows the timely replacement of components once personal preferences are discovered. The results of a good shave speak for themselves, and the Van der Hagen set will help you achieve that.
  1116. After reading the article titled 'How to Shave Like Your Grandpa' on The Art of Manliness, I happened across this set while at Walmart one afternoon. I figured for $8 I didn't have much to lose, and I was right.<br /><br />While the bristles on this brush aren't as soft as a true badger brush are, they get the job done just fine. I love the soap, and it's lasted me almost a full 8 or 9 months worth of shaving.<br /><br />My only other complaint is the dish isn't really travel-friendly, and there isn't a stand for the brush included. Not a huge deal, again considering what I paid for it.<br /><br />Pair this set with some blades from the DollarShaveClub, and you've got yourself a nice little kit!
  1117. Recently I was given my Grandfather's shaving brush from my Dad. I'm a head shaver, haven't had a clean shaven face since junior high, so receiving this brush was a great surprise. I didn't want to just jump into using it given it's history in my family so I found this kit at Wal-Mart for about $9. Talk about surprised! The brush included is great, boar's hair & works great, the soap is even better, has that great \\"old time\\" smell, some will know what I mean there. The bowl is a bowl, looks nice & does its job. Probably my ONLY negative about this kit is I wish it would have included a stand to hold everything (or maybe just the brush) other than that you just can't beat it. I plan on using my Grandfather's brush starting in the new year & dropping the included brush down to my travel bag. Now to find a travel soap container & I'll be set! If you're just getting into \\"old school\\" shaving or looking for a nice inexpensive gift for someone I don't think you'll be disappointed at all with this, whether you buy it here or at another store.
  1118. At least I can shave like a man! Take a trip back in time to when shaving was a relaxing personal indulgence. For the price the bowl and the soap translate to good bang for the buck. The brush is not real badger hair which is a good thing because that would make it a $70 brush. Occasionally a fiber strand from the brush will come off, but no big deal. The brush is also good for applying hot water to your whiskers to soften them up! Highly recommend this shaving set!
  1119. If you've just purchased your first DE or straight razor, this is a nice started kit.   1123. I recently became interested in traditional wet shaving when I realized how much money I could save. I've been using cartridge razors for years, most recently using the Gillette Fusion razors, and I've never been terribly happy with them. I hate shaving. I have to do it for work, but I have very coarse facial hair, and it grows close to my face. This has made it difficult for me to get a good shave, and I ended up using the most expensive razors I could find in hopes of improving the experience. The problem is how much they cost. When I did the math on wet shaving versus cartridge razors, I discovered that I could buy everything I needed to start out plus enough double edged razors to shave for three years for the price of two months shaving with the Fusions. At that much of a savings, I figured I could deal with an inferior shave if I could save that much money. Oh, little did I know...<br /><br /> I chose this kit to start with for one reason, it was cheap. I did read some good reviews on it, but I had no illusions of this being the best brush ever made. But for soap, a bowl and a brush, you can't beat it if you're just starting off wanting to try wet shaving. The brush does lose the odd bristle from time to time, but it's a $4 brush...so not a big suprise here. Just pay attention and don't try to shave over one. The bowl and the soap work great, and much to my delight, not only is this a cheaper shave, it's also much better! I don't hate shaving anymore. It's not fun, but it's no longer something I dread.<br /><br /> So if you're interested in wet shaving, but don't want to sink a ton of money in initially, try this kit out. You'll be glad you did, and you can always upgrade later if you want.

  1130. I got this first and don't use any of it. I use proraso shaving cream, tweezerman badger brush, and a large mug I already had at home. The mug is too small and spills lather over the edge. A mug or bowl you have at home works a lot better. The soap is decent, I might try it again, the fact that it's so cheap turns me off of it. Or spend more and get a nicer soap or brush, but the tweezerman one seems very nice and is the cheapest badger brush I've seen. I also got a cheap metal stand to preserve my brush. I use a Parker shavette and feather blades so far are my favorite (out of shark, Astra, and feather) I have other kinds of blades but the feathers are amazingly good. They go against the grain without pulling and are far and away the easiest on my skin. Contrary to some people saying they're harsh on the skin. There are so many shaving options, and there are many people on forums who spend hundreds or thousands of dollars on equipment. There are better products than the van der Hagen set for the same price. (minus the useless bowl)

  1135. This was my intro to SE shaving starter set, so some of my initial issues were more learning curve related than product quality related.<br /><br />SOAP: Initially I had some lather generation issues, but after breaking in the brush and working my technique, the soap worked great. I've also been using Proraso (green) soap. Proraso lathers up easier and stays longer, plus has that cooling menthol effect. The VDH soap is a little bit more liquidy, will dry a bit faster, and has a lighter scent. There's plenty of glycerin and it hasn't irritated my face at all. Upon recommendation I melted the bar in the bowl (50 seconds in the microwave) and it has worked well for me.<br /><br />BRUSH: My first and only brush so far. After initially having a difficult time, I have broken it in and now have no difficulty generating a good lather. I have had maybe 20 hairs fall out over time, but again, for the price it's been great.<br /><br />BOWL: I think the bowl is a little too deep for the width. I had to keep my circles tight and constantly gather the suds creeping up to the lip. As stated above I melted the soap into the bowl and enjoyed that. For other soaps I've come to use a small ceramic cereal bowl instead of the VDH green bowl.

  1150. For the price you pay for this set, it is quite nice. Without breaking the bank I wanted a starter mug/soap and brush set and at around $10 this set fit that bill perfectly. If you are migrating from using canned shaving cream you will notice that you don't need a thick layer of lather to get a nice smooth shave with soap. You can make the lather as think as you want as you add more water to your brush but as the instructions on the box will tell you you don't need to get a thick layer of lather to get a good shave, as a customer who has tried this I can validate this. Don't expect the brush to last you a lifetime as the price is low, its lifespan too will be low.

  1156. I've been using this shave set a little longer than a Month. The set includes 1 boar hair Brush, a puck of premium shave soap, and a ceramic bowl. It is a great value. At the time it was sold as an &#34;add-on&#34; item. I got it pretty cheap.<br /><br />Soap:<br />It lathers up very nice. You can use the soap in it's original plastic package and close it up again when finished. or you can take it completely out of the original packaging and microwave the soap in the bowl melting it for about 20 - 25 sec. When it cools the soap forms to the bowl. I like to use the microwave method because it is easy to use and it is easier to clean up unused lather by rinsing it out when I'm done. For me I simply lather up a brush full about 20 sec. Then I use the loaded brush to produce a richer lather as I apply it to my face.<br /><br />Bowl:<br />The two tone green ceramic bowl is small, but adequate. It fits nicely inside my medicine cabinet, on the shelf. I like things to be neat and tidy, so I prefer to stow my shave supplies on a shelf in the medicine cabinet; but, it is also nice enough to leave out next to a brush stand if you have one.<br /><br />Brush:<br />It is boars hair. My brush was loosing it's hair initially; but I think there is a &#34;breaking in&#34; period. Some hairs still fall out occasionally even after 1 month; but it isn't horrible. I did email Van Der Hagen about the problem a week ago and I got no response from them whatsoever. Maybe customer service was having high volume levels and my message got ignored by mistake. The issue with the brush is not a horrible problem. I didn't expect a high quality brush anyway. It does the job and I do like using it.<br /><br />I recommend this. I would buy this again.

  1175. This is a good deal for those getting into straight razor shaving, or anyone who wants to start using a brush and shaving soap in their shaves.<br /><br />The bowl is a nice and made of ceramic, not much else needed to be said about that. The soap is nice and only costs about $3 at Walgreen. It does dry out my skin a little bit during the shave which fix by re-wetting my face and lathering it up again. I can't comment to much on the soap as it is the only soap that I have tried.<br /><br />I have had this product since November 2012 and the bristles stay in the brush without any issues. Occasionally I will have 1 or 2 bristles stuck on my face after lathering however this is to be expected with any brush. I grasp the bristles at the base of the handle when lathing, rinse my brush after every use, and hang it up to dry with the bristles facing down when I'm done shaving and after 2 months its in very good condition.<br /><br />The lathering process is enjoyable and the bristles aren't very hard and prickly however you can feel the tips of the bristles on your face as you lather up, but it is a $12 shaving set and you can't expect it to be the best of the best.<br /><br />All in all this is a very nice shaving set at an affordable price.

  1177. My boyfriends' thoughts on this product:<br />I am very new to brush shaving. I started shaving my head years ago since it helped a skin condition on my scalp. I've always been looking for the smoothest shave with the least amount of irritation. I've tried various shaving creams in a can as well as olive oil and natural soaps. I thought they mostly worked well but that since I was shaving my scalp, it was only normal that it would be more irritating. It would sometimes sting pretty good when rinsing due to nicks and/or cuts. I did not look forward to shaving at all.<br /><br />Recently, I decided to research on some of the forums and one topic that kept coming up for a better shave is the use of a shaving brush. I always thought brushes were more of a gimmick from a bygone era and that the creams in a can were, well, more advanced given their popularity. Based on what I read, I decided that the VDH set was worth trying out. I could not be happier with the results. It took only a couple of tries to learn how to whip up a good lather. I tried it in the shower, and I have never had a smoother, easier shave. I actually look forward to shaving! The brush lathers up well and massages it nicely over the whiskers. The bowl is a perfect size and has good weight to it. I was also pleasantly surprised by the shave soap, so much so that I went to the VDH website to see what other types they carry. I plan to try their unscented luxury and glycerin shave soaps.<br /><br />I know that this set is considered entry level set but I am extremely happy with it. It amazes me that most shave creams found in stores are of the canned variety when something so much better exists.<br /><br />The only thing I am slightly concerned about is that the brush is losing a few hairs here and there even though I am very gentle with it. Apparently some loss is normal as part of the break in process. I am very glad to be introduced to this more traditional road to a much better shave.<br /><br />Thanks VDH!

  1185. I got the set because it seemed like a bargain. However, there are some issues.<br /><br />The bowl is kinda small and very slippery when wet and soapy. I stopped using it almost immediately and got a large, round coffe mug from the goodwill for 25 cents. It's easier to hold and is better for lathering.<br /><br />The brush works fine! But the plastic handle is not nearly as nice as a wooden one. I like boar brushes but you can start seeing badger brushes for only a few dollars more. It's is usable.<br /><br />The soap smells nice, it's a bit mild. Nothing too special, but it's in my rotation.<br /><br /> So this is a cheap way to get into wet shaving, but I could recommend getting a brush and soap separately and finding a suitable mug locally. You might spend a little more (but not much) and get bett items.
  1186. My boyfriend loves a good barber shop shave so I thought he'd enjoy using this. But he hasn't tried it yet which makes me think I should have gone with a shaving cream heater. He was surprised though and that's the motivation for the gift.
  1187. It does its job. The brush, alone, is far more expensive than this set at our local supermarket.

  1201. OK so this was my first shaving brush, soap and bowl ever. I enjoyed shaving my face much more with this rather than shaving cream and disposable razors (I bought the [[ASIN:B0017QSZY4 Parker 22R - Long Handle Butterfly Open Double Edge Safety Razor & 10 Shark Super Chrome Blades]]). I can definitely feel the difference. My skin was much more smoother and much less irritated after shaving my face with this kit.<br /><br />The soap doesn't smell like an expensive fancy cologne but it does have a manly scent to it. However, my soap developed this thick substance at the bottom (I'm guessing it's the fat), lost some of it's color and nearly all of its scent so I stopped using it.<br /><br />The bowl can be somewhat difficult to hold when your hands are wet since it has no handle and is very slippery when your hands are wet.<br /><br />The brush is great and while it may not be as comfortable as a badger brush it gets the job more than fine.<br /><br />My problem was that the brush started losing its hairs, I don't mean just one or two, I'm talking chunks of hair started falling off to the point where only the edge of the rim has brush hairs and now it's pretty useless.<br /><br />I give it four stars because although it's now useless it's still much, much more inexpensive than other kits and if it wasn't for this I probably would've never known how much better it is to shave with a shaving kit rather than cheap plastic disposable razors and cheap shaving foam. Definitely worth it specially if you're unsure about shaving kits and wish to try one out.
  1202. The soap: Pretty good at doing what it's supposed to do- protect the face while shaving. In that respect it works very well. It smells ok. Not great but ok. Most shaving soap scents fade quick anyways or are covered up by aftershave or cologne so who cares? There are other soaps in the $5 to $10 dollar range that are a little easier to lather but not so as to make a huge difference. The other fancy name brand soaps might smell better or lather a little easier but this is just the quintessential, bottom line, does-what-its-supposed-to-do soap.<br /><br />The brush: Don't let the fact that it's made of boar bristle fool you. Badger costs more but most experienced wet shavers agree that boar bristle is the preferred brush for shaving soaps. If you use shaving cream, well, that's another story I'd guess but boar and hard milled soaps go hand in hand. However, this particular brush isn't the best boar brush there is. The major set back for this brush is that it sheds. I know that most boar brushes do, even the high quality ones will shed a little the first few shaves but this one sheds four or five hairs each shave (yes, I dry it upside down when I'm done). It doesn't affect my shave but it's just annoying.<br /><br />Overall: Not a bad kit at all don't get me wrong. I can recommend it with a clean conscience. Shaving snobs will scoff but this kit does the job, no more no less. If you wanna indulge and submerse yourself in a daily chore like shaving then I guess the sky's the limit. Shaver's Den ( I know there's controversy surrounding them) or Mama Bear will sell a great soap for $5 to $10 bucks and an Omega brush can cost as little as $9 bucks. Will your shave be THAT much better? Naw. Will the EXPERIENCE of shaving be better? Sure, I guess. You decide what's most important. Ultimately it's just shaving, right?
  1203. this is a nice starter set. the bowl fits the hand nicely. soaps ok not great. and brush will do the job. but its on the low end. boar brush is a stiff brush. i bought better. but use this as a talc brush. like I said its a nice starter set.
  1204. Simply put, THERE'S NO \\"BEGINNERS' SET/KIT\\" WHEN IT COMES TO SHAVING. I am a MAN and I NEED a good shave.<br /><br />THE BRUSH:<br />My main complaint is that the bristles come off the brush. I first thought it was supposed to happen on first wash of brush (prior to usage), but after a few shavings the bristles continue to come off. It is quite disgusting having the feel that I have pig's hair on my face.<br /><br />THE BOWL:<br />This one is rather nice. Ceramic and of decent size and weight.<br /><br />THE SOAP:<br />Does foam up to a good lather.   1218. Recently I made the decision to try double edge shaving because the cost of the Gillette Fusion blades I have been using is outrageous. Not knowing if I would like using a double edge razor I did not want to spend a lot of money initially to get into it. After looking at many of the items related to double edge shaving offered on Amazon I decided on this set for several reasons. First, price...for less than $10 I got three of the five items needed to get started. Second, the reviews. Most of them were 4-5 star which is usually a good sign. Third, I did some research on Van Der Hagan and again for the most part read positive reviews of their products.<br /><br />I have been using this set along with a Lord L6 razor and several different brands of razor blades for over a month and am extremely happy with my purchase. The brush is boars hair and does a good job of creating lather from the shaving soap. The shaving soap bowl has a good finish on it and cleans up very easily. I have sensitive skin and the shaving soap that came with this is their deluxe hypo allergenic soap which is nice for me.<br /><br />I do not have anything to compare against as this is my first foray into using a brush, bowl and soap but based on actual results I am happy. At some point I may buy a badger hair brush and different soap but for now this suits my needs.<br /><br />I recommend this set to anyone just getting into double edge shaving.<br /><br />Additional Suggestions: I purchased an 8 ounce bottle of Glycerin from Wal Mart for around $4 and a can of Barbasol Arctic Chill with Menthol. I let water sit on top of the soap to soften it up a little while I am soaking the boars brush in hot water. I then dump the excess water off the top of the soap and add 5-6 drops of glycerin (which helps in moisturizing my face) and then whip up the lather with the boars brush after shaking out excess water. I do this every day. Just to change things up so they do not get boring, once a week I add a squirt of the Barbasol arctic chill after I have worked up the lather with the shaving soap so I get the cooling feeling and smell of the menthol.rt of the Barbasol arctic chill after I have worked up the lather with the shaving soap so I get the cooling feeling and smell of the menthol.
  1219. Awesome shave set for the money. Where else are you going to get a brush, soap and bowl for $10? I love the smell of this soap, although it could lather up a little more, it does the job. The brush has worked well for me, I treat it gently and it treats me right; it hasn't broke and it doesn't lose too many bristles. The mug isn't my favorite color, but it's just the right size to fit in the palm of my hand, just high enough to not let foam spill out and at the same time not too deep that it's a hassle.

  1243. I shaved with Gillette gel shaving cream for years and it always left my skin very irritated.<br />If the gel shaving cream irritates your skin, THIS is the solution. Metaphorically, gel shaving cream makes the razor feel like sandpaper (even with a new blade), but the soap in this kit makes the blade feel more like rubbing a worn piece of denim, not dramatically smoother, but notably smoother.<br />I'm glad I was able to get this set because it allows you to see if this shaving method is better for your skin.<br /><br />The soap and bowl (especially the bowl) is of great quality. The brush, however, isn't the best quality which is expected because most brushes are at least $30. After well over twenty uses, bristles are still falling out here and there, which can get annoying. Maybe after longer they'll stop falling out. Regardless of this minor flaw, for this price, you get a tremendous value.<br />I'd strongly recommend this to anyone who is not satisfied with chemical shaving cream that causes irritation.

Plus, it lost bristles every time I used it. The bowl is too small to get things whipped up. The soap in the kit is OK, not great. I switched to an oversized coffee cup and a badger brush, and I was in business!<br />I really love my new shaving regimen!   1265. Great Quality....<br /><br />The brush has a plastic handle, but overall, especially given the price, better than what you would expect. I have very coarse facial hair, and I am not very gentle with it, and I can say I maybe at most, have seen 1 hair fall out. Which is probably more normal than bad quality or anything. Feels great to use, and really helps stimulate the beard hair, making it easier to shave off without irritation.<br /><br />The bowl is great. Great construction, awesome green and matte black finish. Looks very attractive and masculine, yet attractive enough to leave out for all to see in any sort of bathroom. Soap fits in it perfect, and plenty of room for lather. Bowl is a home run in this kit. You will never need another mug or bowl, even if you upgrade the brush or soap.<br /><br />The soap lathers and shaves well. It is however the only weak link I can even begin to find in this kit. Only because it does not have much of a smell. Which is completely personal preference. I love the old fashion smells, but if you dont, then you will love this soap. I added some bay rum soap I picked up on vacation and the kits perfect now! Once again, soap works perfectly, but does not have a scent.... at least not one I smell enough to determine what it is.<br /><br />Overall the only people I really see not liking this kit are purists or shaving fanatics that desire some sort of top tier experience or product appearance. However.... if that's you then you probably wouldn't buy this anyhow. For anyone else, if you are just starting to collect shaving items, you simply want to shave better than modern ways, or whatever it may be...there's literally no reason not to buy this.<br /><br />I see some people say things about quality of the items construction or products used to make them...I just don't see that. I like nice things, and this is more than good enough.You can get nicer items, but for who this would appeal to, its amazing.
  1266. Yea, Yea. I read the don't be a snob post.<br /><br />For the price, if you are just getting into wet shaving. This product is ok and a good place to start. But if you have been around for a while and have used any other actual quality products you will know that there is a substantial difference.<br /><br />BUT.. Once you actually get a good brush, bowl, and soap. you will understand that this product is only worth the price you paid for it.<br /><br />The brush is not as soft as many others and sheds, A LOT. You don't have to spend 200 bucks on a high end badger brush to get a quality brush. There are good brushes out there for 20 or 30 bucks. I don't want to have to purchase a new brush every year or every other year. But I will pay 30 or 40 bucks for a decent brush that I can pass down to my son when he is ready to start shaving.<br /><br />The bowl is small, plastic, and the finish will wear off quickly. Depending on the quality and amount of lather you desire to make it may or may not work for you. It's small, plastic, and exactly what you pay for.<br />Personally, I just picked up a black ceramic bowl from Wal-Mart for 2 bucks that works much better and will actually last.<br /><br />The soap is ok but not great. I have tried many soaps and creams. This soap works if you just need to slap on something to shave with. But if you want a soap with a good lather then you need to find a different soap.<br />If you want a cheap soap to just get this job done then you have found your soap!<br /><br />Like all products, just because you are willing to use a cheap product to get the job done does not mean its a great product. it just means it works.<br />So does that mean because it works it should deserve a great review. Hell no! It means that there are other products out there that work better. Yes that means you actually have to pay more for them. Ooo, did I say that? Yes, you get what you pay for.<br /><br />This is an entry level kit, A CHEAP entry level kit. Onethat wont leave your pockets empty should you decide you don't like wet shaving. But..<br />If you stick with wet shaving you should at least take the time to try other products out there. There are great products out there that don't cost hundreds of dollars. I picked up my first double edge razor on eBay for 20 bucks. A 1972 Gillette Supper speed. It still works great and it's a quality product.<br /><br />Additionally this complany sells a Luxury shave set listed at 40 bucks. It is a much better quality than the 8 dollar version.

It's more like a cheap paint brush than a &#34;Premium Brush&#34;. Overall, not too bad. It's a great starter set, but I'll be upgrading when the rest of the bristles work their way out of the brush.

  1277. Good set to buy for beginners. If you're on a budget, then the price is obviously going to lure you in, but it's also suitable for those who've been geeking up on shaving and want to know how \\"lower end\\" products perform. Most of the previous reviews (both positive and negative) are quite accurate. The brush works fine, but it's not the most comfortable thing in the world and it's going to gradually shed -- not the kind of thing I planned on using forever. The soap is decent. I can't compare it to anything else, but it certainly made me feel protected and slick. Only complaint is that it does leave you feeling a bit dry and in need of some lotion. I'm happy I bought it, and now I know what a boar brush and a cheap puck feels like. They're not shaving Mecca, but they're good enough products to live in a travel kit or amongst backup supplies once I have the budget for a badger brush and some higher quality soap/cream. UPDATE: The brush still occasionally sheds, but I've noticed that it has softened up a good bit after a few weeks of use.
  1278. Strictly speaking, I didn't buy this set. I bought the brush as a replacement for one I'd had for twenty years. I've had it about three years, and it is doing fine. It makes great lather, it hasn't fallen apart, and ... what else do you want?<br /><br />The soap I picked up later after Wal-Mart started carrying it. I had been using various high-quality hotel soaps that I picked up on business trips. They work fairly well, far better than the Williams soap I had tried before. The VdH proved to be great soap. Rick lather, excellent lubrication, and it doesn't dry my face out, a big problem here in the high desert areas.<br /><br />Since I picked the brush and soap up separately, I can't say anything about the bowl. It's a bowl. I use an old plastic coffee mug. Plastic so it won't shatter if I drop it in the bathroom.<br /><br />Bottom line: 5 stars for value-for-price, and 5 stars because it works as well as anything else you can get.
  1279. I gave it 4 stars, because to a normal consumer this set fits my needs well.   1303. This is a great kit to start with if you are thinking about giving wet shaving a shot. It is pretty inexpensive and it does what it's made to do pretty well for the cost. Of course you aren't going to get a Lamborghini on a minivan budget, so let's not get dramatic about how poor this product is compared to the top-of-the-line pieces. No, this product isn't THE BEST. It is, however, a great value.<br /><br />The soap - its not a bad soap. It lathers up fine and smells nice. It also fits in the soap dish well and doesn't wiggle around while making a lather.<br /><br />The soap dish - not a bad spot to put your soap. There really isn't much more to say since that's all it does. Its a ceramic bowl that holds the soap, and it does a pretty good job at it.<br /><br />Shave brush - this is the only reason I gave it a 4/5 star review. The shave brush does what it's made for and makes a pretty decent lather. The only bad/annoying things are the bristles are a bit stiff and they often come out of the handle. That's it. Yes, the handle is plastic but I don't care - that's a lamborghinis and minivans issue.<br /><br />If you want a nice, wood handle, 100% mink brush for four times the cost of this entire kit, or a bowl that has a handle, or soap that makes you look younger - don't buy this kit. However, if you want to give wet shaving a shot and you've got $8 to spare - go for it. What will it hurt?

The smell is ok, not amazing, not terrible, my wife seems to like it.<br />- the brush: since I'm rather new at this, I don't know how to rate a brush other than the fact that it does the job; it hasn't shed terribly, a hair here and there; yes the handle is plastic, but you're paying US$10.00 for a set, so it's understandable and it doesn't bother me.<br />All in all a very good purchase; I highly recommend it.

  1361. The bristles from the brush come out and it doesn't even feel good. I would rather lather my face with my hand. The only thing I use is the bowl...
  1362. This is a great little set for the price tag. None of the three items is anything spectacular, but all three are a great value.<br /><br />The scuttle is a simple round bottomed ceramic bowl. What makes it special is what it is NOT. It is not too big, too small, or square bottomed. I only wish it had a lid. I found that the puck could be pretty effectively stuck to the bottom of the bowl by simply wetting it once the first time it was unwrapped and letting it dry in the bowl. Since using up the soap that came with this set, I've switched to a smaller ceramic cup I had lying around to hold my puck more securely. This bowl still gets used as part of my daily shaving routine, however. I fill it with hot water to soak my brush and razor while I wet my face and apply pre-shave. Then I empty the hot water, fill my brush with soap, and lather in the bowl while it is still warm. Makes the first pass of shaving cream extra nice.<br /><br />The soap is basic shave soap. Smell is decent, lather is decent. It is a good starting point, but most men will want to seek out something a bit more distinctive. Different or more/less scent, different ingredients, whatever your preference. It doesn't seem to last as long as some other pucks out there, so no worries about being stuck with it. It only lasted me a couple months.<br /><br />The brush is probably the best part of this set. It takes a fair amount of use before it really starts to perform, so don't be disappointed by the first use. It didn't really break in until after the soap that came with this set was long gone. After a few months of steady use it is soft, but not too soft. It holds a substantial amount of lather, and both scrubs and applies lather well. For an inexpensive brush, the knot size is quite large. It still sheds the occasional hair, but it is a cheap brush and I'm not picky. I have a few brushes in my collection now. This is probably the cheapest one, but still sees regular rotation. For best results, let it soak in warm water for little while.
  1363. I like the cream itself but the bowl is a bit too small to mix up a good sized batch of shaving cream. The brush is Boar hair instead of badger so it doesn't hold the moisture in as much. I find I have to re wet it a little bit on my second pass of shaving but its no big deal. I would recommend buying a badger brush and a larger bowl. Still a decent product.
  1364. Got this for my husband for his birthday. He has yet to use it. But he does like it!
  1365. I bought this not expecting much, but I'm surprised at how good a value this package really is. Included is a boar hair shaving brush, a puck of Van Der Hagen Deluxe shaving soap, and a bowl to house the soap. The brush is the make-or-break item for this kit, and after a few shaves I'm fairly happy with it. It shed terribly on my first few shaves and still loses hairs here and there, but the brush gets the job done and it's hard for me to complain considering the price.<br /><br />The soap and bowl are both quality products. The bowl is just the right size; it doesn't take up a lot of counter space yet there's plenty of room to work up your lather. The soap is nice as well, it has a nice, gentle scent and easily produces a good lather.<br /><br />Overall, a good buy.
  1366. A nice lather bowl, and soap. But the brush (boar I think) is like a lather vaccum, even with a high quality cream. You would be better served to part together a set with a good bager brush.
  1367. My boyfriend orded this with his razor, strop, and oxide. He liked it, he wishes that the bowl was a little bit bigger.
